IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Despite significant advances in our understanding of the clinical high risk (CHR) for psychosis state, the longer-term outcomes (5+ years) and the trajectory of diagnoses, symptoms and psychosocial function have been seldom investigated in this population. Substantial evidence already exists for multiple biomarker abnormalities in CHR subjects that predict psychotic conversion but it is not known whether biomarkers predict longer term (>5 years) conversion and functional outcomes. Longer-term follow-up of up to 2000 CHR individuals identified over the last 20 years provides a unique and rare opportunity to investigate the full trajectory of illness in both those individuals who developed psychosis and those who did not.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cutaneous sensory neurons, in particular pain-sensing nociceptors, are required for the development of inflammation in skin in both patients and mouse models. Using mouse models, our goal is to fully delineate the pathway(s) that link neurons with the development of local inflammation. We expect that this basic mechanistic understanding will provide benefit to patients with autoimmune skin disease and those suffering from chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This proposal addresses the need for more effective pharmacotherapies to treat alcohol use disorder (AUD). Our previous findings have implicated the brain nociceptin/orphanin FQ (N/OFQ) neuropeptide receptor (NOP) as a treatment target for AUD. This project employs a translationally oriented approach to establish therapeutic potential of a novel pharmacological agent that, like the major AUD therapeutics currently in use, blocks classical opioid receptors but also activates NOP receptors and, therefore, may provide superior treatment efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed education program is relevant to public health because it increases the pipeline of diverse researchers interested in the behavioral, sociological, biological, and clinical aspects of brain aging as well as Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. To improve the health and overall wellbeing of older adults, it is imperative to address minority health disparities in vulnerability to dementia and other common comorbidities of advanced age. One way to address these disparities is to recruit more individuals from minority and/or disadvantaged backgrounds to diversify the research workforce and ensure that early career researchers and pre-health professionals develop and appreciation for aging and have access to resources, meeting the NIA mission of fostering the development of research and clinician scientists in aging. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The UNAIDS has set ambitious “90-90-90” targets and the goal of eliminating HIV by 2030: To achieve this goal, and to eventually end the HIV epidemic, simple, safe, effective, potent and inexpensive ARV-regimens will be needed as well as effective tools for point-of care monitoring. The planned rollout by the Senegal National AIDS Program of 1st-line dolutegravir-based ART with a generic, single table regimen of tenofovir-lamivudine- dolutegravir (TLD) has the potential to improve HIV-2 and HIV-1/HIV-2 dually infected patient outcomes and achieve the UNAIDS 90-90-90 targets. Evaluation of the outcomes of TLD rollout for HIV-2 in Senegal, West Africa will help ensure its promise as novel public health intervention and serve as a model for the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Expeditious diagnosis and effective treatment are essential for the positive long-term outcomes for patients with Cushing’s Disease (CD). Effective treatment of recurrence of disease remains a challenging task for endocrinologists and neurosurgeons. The proposed research will allow us to identify novel therapeutic approaches to effectively treat ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas in patients with CD by targeting the tumor directly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that pain research has historically focused on the occurrence of one chronic pain condition at a time, little is known about the evolution of multiple, co-occurring pain conditions. The proposed study will seek to address this important issue and knowledge gap, as well as provide insight into whether sleep and circadian rhythm disturbances are the underlying catalysts in the progression from a single to multiple chronic pain conditions. Key findings of the proposed study can inform development of novel intervention and/or prevention approaches to improving the care of millions of adults with multiple chronic pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: This project will develop new data-driven and machine learning methods for accurate and reproducible analysis of diffusion MRI scans of fetuses in utero, and will extensively validate these new methods and compare them with existing techniques. The final methods will be critically assessed by using them to quantify the impact of congenital heart disease on the development of fetal brain micro-structure. More broadly, the technologies developed in this project will enable assessment of fetal brain development and degeneration with unprecedented detail and reproducibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This project involves interconnected synthetic, mechanistic, structural, computer modeling, biochemical mode of action, preclinical, and extensive collaborative studies directed at bryostatin 1, a PKC modulator entered into clinical trials for HIV/AIDS eradication and for treating Alzheimer's disease and proposed as a clinical candidate for enhancing immuno-therapy for cancer, suppressing T cell exhaustion and treating multiple sclerosis. This project is directed at understanding how the structures of bryostatin and other natural as well as designed PKC modulators influence their PKC binding, translocation selectivity, clinically relevant biological activity and tolerability and the use of this knowledge to design, synthesize and evaluate potentially superior, better tolerated, disease specific and more synthetically accessible candidates for clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) lower respiratory infection remains one of the most consistently identified risk factors for developing childhood asthma; approximately 50% of all infants are infected with RSV in their first year of life, placing them at potential risk for subsequent childhood asthma. In this application, Project 1 aims to understand the age-dependent effects of RSV infection, its role in airway epithelial developmental and epigenetic programming and assessing gene x RSV interactions as a genetic approach to determine if a child's genetic risk for asthma depends on whether or not they were infected with RSV in early life. Project 2 similarly focuses on the host, using a clinical trial design in mice to determine the mechanisms through which citrulline decreases type 2 immune responses and how it may modify the response to RSV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms that lead to the development of thoracic aortic aneurysm and dissection (TAAD) remain not fully elucidated. Studies in this proposal aim to characterize the importance of endothelial CCN3 in the maintenance of vascular health and its role against the progression of TAAD. Results gleaned from our studies may facilitate the development of novel therapies to ameliorate TAAD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE End-stage heart failure is one of the leading causes of death and disability in the US, and options for these patients, including heart transplantation, are minimal. Researchers are trying to build transplantable hearts from human stem cells and organ scaffolds, but the immaturity of the lab-grown heart muscle cells is a significant obstacle. We will develop an innovative womb-like machine that provides the mechanical, electrical, and biological signals to develop bioartificial ventricles, establishing the platform for a potential new wave of breakthroughs in cardiac tissue engineering toward building a bioartificial heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a common and potentially very serious disorder that can lead to cirrhosis and liver cancer. A person’s genetic background represents an important risk factor for NAFLD and the risk involves the combined effect of many genes. The goal of this research project is to use stem cells previously generated from NAFLD patients to understand how multiple genetic risk factors combine to cause NAFLD. This information will help us tailor NAFLD treatments to individual patients based on their genetic profile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Reproduction and immune defense are both physiologically demanding processes, and each constrains the other in humans and in a wide variety of animal systems. The proposed study will determine the mechanistic basis and evolutionary consequences of reproduction-immunity tradeoffs in the genetic model insect, Drosophila melanogaster, specifically testing the hypothesis that such tradeoffs can be hormonally regulated. The conclusions from this work will be broadly applicable across human and animal systems, especially including insects with agricultural and public health importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Brain tumors are usually associated with elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and continuous ICP measurements are essential to prevent irreversible neurological damages in these patients. This research proposes to develop highly sensitive, ultrasmall and brain compatible bioelectronic sensors, that are designed for long-term and wireless ICP measurements. We envision that this clinically-needed flexible bioelectronic technology can have utility with several other types of brain diseases that are highly correlated with elevated ICP, such as hydrocephalus and stroke.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conditions affecting women's reproductive health have a significant impact on quality-of-life, overall health, and life expectancy for both women and their children. Reducing this impact through improved prevention and treatment requires researchers with a fundamental understanding of the clinical impact of these conditions and the ability to apply rigorous, innovative methods to facilitate discovery and translation into effective interventions. The Duke Women's Reproductive Health Research training program combines cutting-edge research experiences with an innovative and proven career development framework to help develop the next generation of obstetrician-gynecologist clinician-scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome editing technologies have potential to become safe new genomic medicines to address fundamental genetic causes of human disease. Although fit-for-purpose cellular methods like GUIDE-seq to define the safety and genome-wide off-target activity of human genome editing products are essential during both pre-clinical and IND enabling phases of development, fully optimized and qualified protocols for use in regulatory submissions are not generally available. Here we propose to optimize and qualify GUIDE-seq-2, an improved, highly scalable, and accurate version of GUIDE-seq we recently developed, for use in future therapeutic genome editing IND submissions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) against HIV-1 provide new opportunities for immunotherapy and prevention but the development of HIV-1 resistance to bnAbs is still an obstacle for medical interventions. Here we will study how HIV-1 strains resist multiple bnAbs and investigate indirect pathways that HIV-1 may use to escape bnAbs. We will define new ways to overcome HIV-1 resistance to bnAbs and provide important insights into the interactions of HIV-1 and bnAbs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As an orally transmitted pathogen, EBV infection causes infectious mononucleosis, oral hairy leukoplakia of tongue, and ~200,000 cases of various cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma that occurs in a space immediately adjacent to the oral cavity, some B cell malignancies, and ~10% of gastric cancer. This study will determine the functions of EBV-encoded nuclear antigen leader protein (EBNALP) in transcription regulation and may lead to identification of new targets for intervening EBV-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project will study participants who had severe drug and other behavioral problems when they were teens. The participants are now adults in their early 30s and some have stopped having addiction and behavior problems whereas others have kept having problems or their addictions have gotten worse as they developed cocaine, methamphetamine, or opiate addictions. The study will try to understand what factors predict continuing addiction and mental health problems and also try to understand what factors predict having fewer addiction and mental health problems as participants have gotten older.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) remains one of the most unmet medical challenges in our society. This project will investigate whether there is a pathologically altered efflux of CNS cell-type specific exosomes from brain in AD models and whether and how these brain-derived exosomes may possess specific antigens to trigger peripheral T cell activation in vitro and in vivo. Results from this project will unveil new mechanisms how CNS and periphery interact in AD models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Many of over 7000 rare genetic diseases are diagnosed based partially on our understanding of their clinical features or a set of diagnostic criteria that appear in combination. We will test whether a more rigorous scientific approach to these criteria based on actual patient data from over a decade of clinical evaluations of children can improve our ability to make rare disease diagnoses. From these same data, we will develop machine learning algorithms that may one day assist non-specialists in recognizing these rare diseases in their patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Industry-academia (IA) partnerships are critical for bringing neurotechnologies to market for public use and benefit, but these partnerships can introduce bias into research and commercialization processes. This project addresses a gap in our current understanding of the ethical complexities of industry-academia (IA) partnerships in the neurotechnology enterprise by engaging relevant stakeholders (e.g., industry, researchers, ethicists, university officials, patients) to identify promising solutions for navigating these complexities. The project will culminate in the development and dissemination of an innovative toolkit that helps neurotechnology research stakeholders cultivate ethical and responsible IA partnerships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are a major public health problem, and evidence suggests experiences and the environment in early life might play an important role in development of ADRD. ADRD dis- proportionally affects Black and socially disadvantaged Americans, and our study assesses early-life social disadvantage including systemic racism and ambient air pollution as modifiable determinants of ADRD. Study results have the potential to identify key modifiable factors that affect ADRD and explain ADRD disparities.

PHR: Narrative The prefrontal cortex exerts top-down control over other brain regions to regulate social behaviors, but the mechanisms have remained unclear. This project aims to understand the extent to which prefrontal neurons projecting to the posterior paraventricular thalamus regulate social motivation, and the role that parvalbumin interneurons may play in this process in both male and female mice. The results from this study will reveal a novel prefrontal circuitry in the regulation of sociability in sex-specific manner and provide novel insights into the sex differences in neural circuits that may go awry in psychiatric conditions where social motivation is significantly disrupted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Analysis of rare somatic mutations in normal tissues is important for understanding the manifestation of normal phenotypes and the genetic disposition of human diseases. This project aims to detect mosaic mutations from scRNA-seq data generated by human cell atlas and many related projects to quantify their prevalence and functional effects on the rare mutated cells. Our bioinformatic tools provide a cost-effective way to construct a full picture of mosaic mutation atlas of human organs, to understand the effects of genomic diversification on cell functions within human body, and to develop novel strategies to prevent the clinical phenotype manifestations of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The clinical use of Bone Morphogenetic Proteins (BMPs) for local bone induction in spine fusion but is often complicated but unwanted side effects. In this work we propose to locally inhibit the primary natural BMP antagonist, noggin, with a novel small molecule inhibitor and hybrid scaffolds creating a BMP-privileged zone that allows for lower BMP levels to induce bone formation. Together these strategies will provide a novel technology to safely and reliably induce spinal fusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal muscles have a uniquely important biomechanical role in stabilizing the lumbar spine and could provide a safe and effective treatment target for alleviating chronic low back pain; however, how spinal muscles degrade and begin to turn into fat in patients with chronic low back pain is unknown. This study will create a new approach to observe patterns of fat in the spinal muscles using advanced MRI methods, and then relate these fat patterns with patient movement patterns and types of molecules within the muscle tissue. Understanding why spinal muscles degrade and how spinal health relates to disability associated with chronic low back pain will support the advancement of new therapeutics and treatments targeting the muscles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2015, then-President Barack Obama launched the Precision Medicine Initiative, which dictated a patient- powered emerging approach to disease prevention and treatment that takes into account individual differences in people's genes, environment, and lifestyles – making possible more effective, targeted treatments for diseases. In personalized medicine, biomarkers serve as indicators of disease prognosis and can potentially predict a patient's response to drug treatment, thereby informing clinical decisions and aiding risk stratification. Currently, there are no established biomarkers to guide treatment of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, a disease with many drugs with distinct mechanisms of action approved for first-line use. The establishment of robust biomarkers that can reliably identify which patients will benefit from immune checkpoint inhibitor therapies in the first-line setting would bring us closer to the overarching target of the Precision Medicine Initiative, and also reduce toxicities, lower treatment costs, and improve health-related quality of life in patients diagnosed with metastatic renal cell carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preclinical data have demonstrated that antagonism of kappa opioid receptors (KOR) is efficacious in reducing the physical symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Currently, the alpha 2-adrenergic agonist lofexidine is the only approved therapy for the mitigation of the physical symptoms of opioid withdrawal but it is only modestly effective and can have significant unwanted side effects. In this application, Cerevel Therapeutics has identified a novel selective KOR antagonist with unique properties and good preclinical safety margins that we are planning to take through early human safety/pharmacokinetics and occupancy studies, into a Phase 2 study to assess efficacy in acute opioid withdrawal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Estrogen receptor positive breast cancer can be treated with anti-hormone therapies, but de novo and acquired resistance are common. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dental health is critical to quality of life, but the tools that dentists and periodontists use to inspect the mouth have major limitations related to studying the gingiva. This work will build an ultrasound-based device to non- invasively map and measure periodontal disease easily, earlier, and more accurately. The imaging approach will evaluate the entire pocket and be less variable than the existing method—this will improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this study is to assess the impact of a new cancer genetic counseling model that leverages the increasing digitization of healthcare on psychosocial, behavioral, and implementation outcomes. This will be achieved through a digitally-enhanced intervention to promote cascade testing for the at-risk relatives of probands with pathogenic/likely pathogenic variants (PV), and the optimal follow-up care of those with a variant of uncertain significance (VUS). This project has the potential to improve care for patients with a PV and their families, and patients with a VUS, and will ultimately be applicable to the practice of genetic counseling and genomic medicine across diseases and clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite decades of investigation into behavioral drivers, understanding the gradient of HIV risk among people who inject drugs (PWID) and designing effective tools to predict this risk remains a challenge. This study will evaluate novel use of the plasma virome as a sentinel bioindicator of HIV risk, as well as elucidate whether the virome can reveal potential transmission networks before HIV infection occurs. This represents a particularly innovative approach to HIV treatment and prevention and may lead to more robust molecular surveillance methods that can guide public health officials in targeting interventions to prevent HIV outbreaks and focus limited resources for the greatest impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to improve the care of older adults by characterizing and identifying systems-level practice patterns that lead to the initiation of life-supporting treatments for patients with life-limiting illness. A deeper understanding of institutional routines and forces driving care might allow us to identify misaligned incentives and specific moments when interventions can be employed to disrupt patterns that lead to overtreatment at the end of life. The research and training proposed for this Midcareer Investigator's Award will support Dr. Schwarze as she builds a new direction of research and expands her mentorship activities for an increasing number of young investigators who aim to develop a career in patient-oriented and aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A key impediment to recovery from cocaine use disorder is that exposure to cocaine-associated environments can trigger drug-associated memories and consequent profound craving. The proposed project aims to increase our understanding of hippocampal cellular mechanisms and synaptic plasticity mechanisms that maintain cocaine memories over time. The long-term goal of this research is to provide insight into how the neurobiological underpinnings of pathologically strong and invasive cocaine memories can be targeted for drug-relapse prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) is a potentially curative therapy for many malignant hematological conditions, but its broader application has been limited by a serious complication known as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Novel drugs are continually being tested in clinical trials to identify more effective therapies to mitigate GVHD. However, there remains an urgent and major unmet need of providing children, adolescents, and young adults access to clinical trials examining novel GVHD prevention strategies as well as assessing their impact on parameters important to reintegration into society after transplantation, such as neurocognitive function and health-related quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diarrheal diseases cause millions of deaths each year and enteric viruses, such as human norovirus, significantly contribute to these cases. Due to the unavailability of conventional cell culture adaptations and animal models, mechanistic human norovirus studies remain lacking. This proposal uses a surrogate virus and human intestinal organoid systems to determine the calcium signaling dysregulation that occurs during norovirus infection and the role that this plays in viral pathogenesis and replication, ultimately unveiling key parallels between enteric viruses that can be exploited for broad spectrum antiviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Pathologic α-synuclein spreading from the gut to the brain is an important driver to aging-associated α- synucleinopathy, a group of neurodegenerative diseases with no effective therapy. It remains largely unknown how aging-associated blood-borne components modulate the initiation and progression of α-synucleinopathy. Using the heterochronic blood exchange (HBE) approach, we will study how two aging-associated HBE- modulated plasma proteins (FGL1 and sLAG3) affect the pathogenesis of α-synucleinopathy. If successful, our discoveries will facilitate the development of early diagnosis and therapy for α-synucleinopathy, based on detecting and modulating these two blood-borne aging-associated factors. Our ultimate goal is to discover new ways to help people live longer healthier lives by modulating rejuvenation and age-acceleration factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative/Public Health Relevance: Vascular diseases combined account for half the morbidity and mortality in the United States and throughout the world. New single cell data is available for vascular cells throughout the body, however it is not known which cell populations contribute to vascular dysfunction and disease progression. We will build and share new computational software to integrate data from genetic association studies and single cell analysis of diseased vascular tissue to identify the genes, pathways and cell types that contribute to risk of multiple common diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The R35 proposal will develop ultrasensitive quantification tools to characterize cytokine release from the plasma membrane. Using T cells and interleukin-2 as a model system, the research will probe the temporal and directional cytokine release profiles, proximity-based membrane regulation, and the distribution between soluble and extracellular-vesicle-associated cytokines during T cell activation. The research program will enhance the fundamental understanding of the cytokine release at the molecular level and enable the search for membrane mechanisms to modulate the process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: With the growth of the United States’ aging population, acquired deafness is becoming increasingly common, and many individuals suffer hearing loss severe enough to warrant cochlear implantation. Enormous speech recognition outcome variability exists in adult cochlear implant (CI) users, which is only partly explained by clinical measures, and this unexplained variability impedes our ability to predict postoperative outcomes, identify sources of poor outcomes, and tailor rehabilitation protocols for individuals. This project will determine how a comprehensive approach including “bottom-up” sensory and “top-down” cognitive-linguistic factors predicts CI outcomes after implantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The work described in this proposal is based on experiments demonstrating that GDF11, an endogenous blood factor, can improve brain function by regulating properties of its vasculature. These studies will investigate molecular changes that take place in vasculature located in neurogenic and non-neurogenic regions, both of which are likely to impact the health of neurons and glial cells. In addition, the actions of systemically administered GDF11 will be compared with those of GDF11 expressed by hippocampal cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Variable transcription factor-DNA interaction mediates phenotypic variation, including traits and a wide range of human diseases. Our proposed studies aim to understand how naturally occurring genetic and epigenetic variation in the genome gives rise to variation in transcription factor-DNA interactions, and how this variation collectively alters the regulatory networks in the cell. Our research will have the potential to reveal novel principles for predicting the regulatory functions of genetic and epigenetic variants, a critical element in the development of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide critical information on contraceptive access and use and factors that promote sexual and reproductive health among youth with child welfare involvement – a vastly understudied topic and population. The study will use secondary data from a multi-wave survey of youth, between the ages 12 and 18 with child welfare involvement, to provide basic information on contraceptive access and use across adolescence, identify modifiable factors that promote reproductive agency and autonomy, and clarify differences by demographic and child welfare characteristics – key factors for service delivery in child welfare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of curative approaches for HIV infection is now recognized as both a necessary and attainable goal. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation resulting in a CCR5-deficient immune system has been shown to functionally cure HIV infection in two separate patients, but such an approach is not scalable to the general population. We propose here to develop novel AAV vectors targeted to immune system cells to support delivery of therapeutics such as HIV-targeted CRISPR-Cas9, chimeric antigen receptors, broadly neutralizing antibodies, or CCR5-blocking antibodies to mimic a CCR5-deficient immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For people with HIV who have cancer, consistent engagement in HIV care is integral to successful cancer treatment, but the evidence base for integrating HIV care into cancer care in resource-constrained settings like Zimbabwe is limited. New strategies to support continuous engagement in HIV care during cancer treatment in tertiary care settings in Zimbabwe are needed. The proposed work addresses this critical gap by identifying barriers to HIV care engagement during cancer treatment, and developing, refining, and testing strategies to address those barriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Discovering unique epigenetic targets in the human malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum with function and structure diverse from those in the human host is critical for developing novel interventions in malaria control. Based on previous studies and our preliminary data, we propose to define the function and substrates of PfSET7, a SET-domain containing lysine methyltransferase with unique structures and functions in two pivotal blood stages: merozoite for invasion and gametocyte for transmission. With the completion of this project, we will reveal the unique function and specificity of PfSET7 in P. falciparum and will lay a solid foundation for the development of novel apicomplexan-specific epigenetic drugs.

PHR: Project Narrative Physician-scientists perform a critical role at the interface between biomedical research and clinical medicine. This program will train a diverse group of students with outstanding potential and prepare them to enter the biomedical research workforce as research active, physician-scientists. Informed by their knowledge of science and clinical medicine, they will perform basic, translational, and clinical research that leads to new approaches to prevent, treat, or cure disease and improve the health of Americans and people around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic stroke is the leading cause of long-term disability in the United States and places an enormous financial burden. The brain has some intrinsic capacity for repair, but our understanding of the repair mechanisms remains very limited. The proposed TPM-PAM technique holds the potential to offer new insights into the spatiotemporal coordination of post-stroke neural and vascular repair, as well as the underlying metabolic requirements, which may reveal promising new therapeutic targets to enhance functional recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal aims to develop novel statistical methods and machine learning algorithms for use on real world data sets and clinical trial data in order to infer dynamic treatment regimens. The proposal will address im- portant challenges to the integration of real world data into estimation, such as differential distributions, real world treatment patterns, confounding bias and consideration of beneﬁt-risk tradeoff. The results from this proposal will complement the current knowledge base for individual patient care and will further accelerate the translation of clinical trial ﬁndings into practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE / NARRATIVE This research is highly relevant to public health because the organism under study causes serious human illness for which current therapies are not adequate. Effective antifungal drugs target ergosterol (the yeast equivalent of cholesterol), but nothing is known about how Cryptococcus neoformans moves this lipid within the cell to regulate its levels at the surface. Filling this gap in knowledge may advance treatment of cryptococcal infection. This work will also contribute to basic science knowledge, which will provide insights into other pathogenic fungi and areas of biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Redox imbalance, characterized by high reactive oxygen species (ROS) and low reactive nitrogen species (RNS), is a fundamental mechanism of endothelial cell (EC) dysfunction contributing to the inflammatory vascular and metabolic diseases such as atherosclerosis, diabetes and peripheral arterial disease. Our preliminary evidence suggests that EC metabolism and ROS are intimately connected and involved in vascular disease. The proposed studies will identify key mechanisms dictating the interplay of metabolism with ROS/NO and how this impacts endothelial function, which will lead to new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Addressing the needs of the growing population of older adults who are coping with complex health and social challenges and supporting their family caregivers are significant societal priorities. Building on our success since 2007, we will continue to prepare nurse scientists to advance science that seeks to develop and improve integrated care models, mitigate adverse social determinants of health, and equitably support older adults and caregivers throughout transitions in health (e.g., new diagnosis, illness progression) and health care (i.e., movement across health care providers or settings). Our faculty mentors will contribute rich scientific expertise, resources, and networks to provide an excellent foundation and environment for this training program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During the five-year project period, we will investigate key questions related to 1) the biochemical mechanisms underlying oxidation-induced changes in protein kinase substrate selection and 2) the functional consequences of redox modification on kinase-dependent signaling processes related to health and disease. To this end, we will build upon our recent studies, which focused on PKA-Cα and ERK2 as representative members of the AGC and MAPK kinase families, to explore the impact of redox modification on the global substrate selection of other kinase family members (including several understudied kinases in the “dark kinome”) using functional protein microarrays composed of >21,000 unique human proteins. Together, these studies will help identify points of signal integration between redox- and phosphorylation-dependent pathways while complementing existing models of pathological oxidative stress and providing new opportunities for targeted antioxidant therapeutics for many diseases (e.g., cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and several neurodegenerative disorders).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: OVERALL Over the past 20 years, advances in the treatment of brain cancer, including glioblastoma (GBM) and medulloblastoma (MB), have been only incremental at best. The research proposed in this Brain Cancer SPORE renewal application seeks to reverse this trend by developing and testing for the first time mechanistically diverse, previously-untested therapeutic strategies that attack the highly immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, which makes brain cancers recalcitrant to most treatments. These novel strategies include combining viro- immunotherapy with cellular therapy, targeting GBM-associated myeloid cells with small molecules, and applying immune checkpoint inhibitors and CAR T-cells to specific subsets of MB patients with hypermutant tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1 In a recent paradigm shift, oncolytic adenoviruses are recognized as new type of cancer immunotherapy, suggesting that oncolytic viruses may have powerful synergistic effects when combined with other immunotherapeutic strategies. In this project, we explore in pre-clinical models the biological effects of combining our novel oncolytic adenovirus, Delta-24-RGD, with home-grown genetically engineered, immunosuppression- resistant natural killer cells (called eCB-NK-TR-/GC- cells). We test in two sequential Phase 1 window-of- opportunity clinical trials the safety, efficacy and biological effects of eCB-NK-TR-/GC- cells alone and in combination with Delta-24-RGD in patients with recurrent glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 2 Immunotherapy is a powerful anti-cancer strategy, but it has not benefited patients with glioblastoma (GBM) largely due to immunosuppressive GBM-associated microglia/macrophages (GAMs), characterized by dysfunctional phagocytosis. We discovered that GAM-mediated immunosuppression is driven by downregulation of a novel complex, called QKI-PPARβ-RXRα (QPR), which regulates phagocytosis. In this project we overcome the immunosuppression of GBMs by restoring GAM phagocytosis using brain-penetrant, small molecule activators of QPR, bexarotene and KD3010, which we evaluate for the first time in preclinical studies and ultimately test bexarotene in a phase I clinical trial with a window-of-opportunity component in patients with GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 3 Current survival for patients with Shh-α medulloblastoma with TP53 mutation is near zero, and although patients with Shh-δ, can have a better outcome, they experience terrible morbidity from craniospinal radiation and near- certain mortality after recurrence. We have identified in these Shh MBs a unique point mutation in a non-coding small nuclear RNA called U1, which results in aberrant splicing of transcripts and consequent post-transcriptional hypermutation with thousands of unique epitopes being expressed in the cancer cells. This project leverages this mutation by undertaking a clinical trial using checkpoint inhibitors and by developing CAR T cells against the most immunogenic epitopes, giving hope to the many young people with this devastating disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE: PATHOLOGY AND BIOREPOSITORY CORE (CORE B) Research into brain cancer depends on the availability of tumor samples obtained from patients. These samples and the DNA, RNA, proteins, and cells derived from them (e.g. Glioma Stem-like Cell lines) are the foundation of any translational program. This Core provides the patient samples that are key to understanding and curing primary malignant gliomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: BIOSTATISTICS AND BIOINFORMATICS CORE (CORE C) Appropriate statistical analysis of data resulting from translational research is critical to the advancement and distribution of scientific information, through which the outcome of patients with malignant gliomas will be improved. The Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Core provides comprehensive biostatistical and bioinformatic expertise to ensure statistical integrity and optimize data analysis for SPORE studies. The Core incorporates sound experimental design principles in each project to enhance the interpretability of the study results, carries out data analyses using appropriate statistical methodology, and contributes to the interpretation of results via written reports and frequent interaction with project investigators.

PHR: NARRATIVE: CAREER ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM The Career Enhancement Program (CEP) fosters the scientific development of junior investigators who intend to focus their careers on translational studies of brain tumors, and of established investigators who wish to refocus their careers on brain cancer research. The program provides funding of novel projects, and equally valuable, mentoring by senior scientists with outstanding track records. In past funding cycles, an impressive 60% of awardees have gone on to secure independent peer-reviewed grant funding, and similar results are anticipated in this renewal period. .

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed U-RISE at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (U-RISE@Wπ) interdisciplinary training program combines course-based and individual research experiences with structured mentoring and coaching to strengthen our inclusive community and nurture the academic success of undergraduate Trainees — especially from underrepresented populations. An integrated team of Coaches, faculty Advisors, graduate Mentors, and peers will provide guidance, feedback, and resources to help Trainees acquire necessary skills and cultivate their self- efficacy while seeing the fun and excitement of research so that they may achieve their goals toward successfully completing of PhD programs in the biomedical sciences and engineering. The U-RISE@Wπ Trainees will enhance the diversity of the national workforce as they contribute their perspectives, scientific innovations, discoveries, and skillsets to improve public health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity, diabetes and osteoporosis are increaingly prevalent metabolic diseases that are reponsible for a great burden of suffering and death as well as large healthcare expenditures in the US and throughout the world. Academic endocrine researchers are needed to better understand these diseases and to translate research findings into new and improved therapies. The Yale T32 program in Diabetes and Disorders of Metabolism is dedicated to providing young graduate students, physicians and scientists with the research training necessary to tackle these important public health problems.

PHR: Project Narrative CrossROADS addresses a critical deficiency in the US academic workforce in brain aging and AD/ADRD research. Successful completion of the CrossROADS program will expand our network by adding 12 well- trained scientists from diverse backgrounds, thus enhancing our capacity to implement cross-disciplinary research to improve brain health and reduce the burden of AD/ADRD. This will have a significant impact in achieving the AD/ADRD National Plan and the NIH Healthy People 2030 goals to diversify academic workforce and fulfill the national mandate to establish health equity across US communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (3 sentences). A successful research career studying the biological systems and human diseases also involves the analysis of complex and multi-scale datasets; for example, many biomedical studies now routinely integrate -omic and cel- lular data with population-level covariates and digitized assessments of traits of interest. This predoctoral training program at Brown University will yield multiple cohorts of researchers who are uniquely interdisciplinary— work- ing at the interface of biomedical data generation and data science research — via didactic, research, and pro- fessional development opportunities that foster scientific “dual citizenship” at the faculty and student levels. This training program aligns with the NIGMS mission by training a new generation of Biological Data Scientists, as- suring the vitality and continued productivity of basic research as biological datasets expand in size, scale, and complexity.

PROJECT_TITLE: Predoctoral Training Program in Biological Data Science at Brown University

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wilms tumor (WT) is the second most common solid pediatric cancer in children age from 2 to 4. Although WT patients have a favorable prognosis, ~50% of patients with anaplastic WT will experience recurrence. This study focuses on elucidating the molecular changes distinguishing epithelial and blastemal types of Wilms tumors and repurposing FDA-approved drugs for better treatments of children with aggressive WT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The major objective of this proposal is to understand the role that Toll-like receptor 8-activating microRNAs play in mediating fetal membrane inflammation in response to infection, and their role in mediating FM- neutrophil communication through exosome delivery. Our studies will advance our understanding of the mechanisms by which infections cause pregnancy complications, such as chorioamnionitis and preterm birth. Our outcomes have the potential of defining new mechanisms of pathology, predictors of prematurity, and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing realization that disease susceptibility is a complex interaction between genetics, age, lifestyle choices, and environmental exposure. Training interdisciplinary scientist that can deal with this complexity, including analyzing the large amount of data necessary to quantify the different biological facets, is required if we are to develop interventions, cope with fallout from environmental accidents, and accurately inform public health officials. This predoctoral and postdoctoral training program, in collaboration with its experienced and research-intensive faculty, produces scientists with the skillset necessary to make a positive impact in addressing environmental issues using state-of-the-science mechanistic and translational toxicology.
PROJECT_TERMS: environmental toxicology;multidisciplinary;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Training in Environmental Toxicology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: HOLLINGS CANCER CENTER: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The Hollings Cancer Center at the Medical University of South Carolina coordinates scientific research to promote interdisciplinary collaborations and translation of cancer research from the bench to the bedside to the community. Through the funding of the P30 Cancer Center Support Grant, the center provides research resources in support of its scientists, and impactful engagement with its catchment area with the goal of reducing the cancer burden for the 5.2 million residents of South Carolina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Our Program Project focuses on elucidating the mechanistic underpinnings of homology-directed DNA repair (HDR) that is mediated by the tumor suppressors BRCA1-BARD1 and BRCA2 and how the 53BP1 regulatory axis restricts HDR to favor the engagement of non-homologous DNA end joining as DNA repair tool. We anticipate these endeavors to shed light on how DNA double-strand break repair pathway choice is regulated, help identify predictive biomarkers of cancer therapy response, and develop separation-of- function mutants to probe pathway mechanisms. Altogether, we will establish a mechanistic foundation to predict, intervene, and control biological outcomes of cellular responses to DNA damage.

PHR: NARRATIVE Our Program Project focuses on elucidating the mechanistic underpinnings of homology-directed DNA repair (HDR) that is mediated by the tumor suppressors BRCA1-BARD1 and BRCA2, and how the 53BP1 regulatory axis restricts HDR to favor the engagement of non-homologous DNA end joining as a DNA repair tool. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA end resection has a key role in DSB repair and DNA replication. Any aberrations in DNA end resection can lead to genomic instability and also impact the therapeutic response to DNA damaging drugs. Our discovery of DYNLL1, which interacts with MRE11 to inhibit end resection, provides a functional link between two distinct end resecting mechanisms, with one directly controlling MRE11 activity and the other indirectly regulating Shieldin dependent end resection. Here we will continue to shed light on how functional interplay of the DNA end resection machinery and its regulatory circuitry impacts upon genome stability and sensitivity to PARPi.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA end resection is a critical step in the cellular response to DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) which regulates repair pathway choice and promotes homology-directed repair (HDR). We propose to delineate novel mechanisms by which the opposing actions of 53BP1-CTC1-STN1-TEN1 (CST) and BRCA1-BARD1 regulate the activities of the long-range resection enzymes EXO1 and BLM-DNA2. Our findings will not only illuminate the mechanistic principles of DSB repair pathway choice but will also provide actionable information to help guide the development of targeted cancer therapies to treat HDR-deficient cancers and circumvent drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative The proposal is focused on the mechanisms of control of DNA double-strand break repair by the CST and BRCA2-DSS1 complexes. Using biochemical, structural and cell biology approaches we will investigate the mechanisms of i) RAD51 restriction by CST and ii) reversal of this restriction by BRCA2-DSS1 and also iii) the role of the extended BRCA complex in the reversal of RAD51 restriction by CST. Our results will guide the development of novel therapeutics for breast, ovarian, and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Our Program Project focuses on key aspects of a conserved DNA break repair mechanism called homology- directed repair and determining how this process is regulated by 53BP1, its associated factors, and the tumor suppressors BRCA1-BARD1 and BRCA2. The Protein Biochemistry and Enzymology (PBE) Core has overcome technical bottlenecks to be able to provide high quality protein preparations to Program Project investigators to facilitate their foundational studies. The proven expertise of the PBE Core in nucleic acid and DNA repair enzymology will prove to be crucial for the overall productivity, synergy, and success of the Program Project. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Homology-directed repair that is dependent on the tumor suppressors BRCA1-BARD1 and BRCA2 is the most conservative pathway to repair chromosomal breaks and damaged replication forks and is also needed for the preservation of stressed replication forks against attrition. When this pathway is lost, then cell transformation and cancer can occur. This shared resource of the Program, termed Chromosomal and Replication Analysis (CRA) Core, is directed by an experienced, NCI RO1- funded researcher in the field and will help investigators define the DNA replication, chromosomal and cellular outcomes when key regulators of the most important steps in HDR become dysfunctional. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identification of the structure function relationships of intrinsically disordered proteins are central to understand- ing their biological function in homology directed repair (HDR) of DNA double strand breaks. The Structural Biology and Biophysics Core will provide atomic resolution mapping of critical protein-protein and protein-nucleic acid interactions of complexes important for HDR. The insights provided by the Core will assist Program Project Investigators in dissecting the mechanisms of 53BP1 regulation of 5’ strand resection and the formation of RAD51-ssDNA nucleoprotein fragments, processes important for HDR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Informing mental health policy requires a broad array of skills and knowledge. The Harvard Training Program in Mental Health Policy seeks to train policy researchers, providing the knowledge and skills to inform and evaluate policy affecting individuals with mental illness, as well as to inspire pre- and post-doctoral trainees to devote their career to the study of mental health policy. The Program has successfully trained social scientists and clinicians who have expanded the evidence base for the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UC San Diego Department of Radiology is submitting a competitive renewal of its postdoctoral training program that focuses on developing clinician-scientists through a year of laboratory research followed by 32 weeks of protected research time during the subsequent 4 years of residency training. This program trains radiologists to become clinical-translational research faculty, who ultimately can be competitive for NIH grant funding, industry collaboration and entrepreneurship. Trainees will be supported by 12 radiology and 12 non‐ radiology mentors that together have 103 active grants and over $28M in grant support (current year funding).
PROJECT_TERMS: clinical training;radiological imaging;Scientist
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Clinical Scientists in Radiological Imaging

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The research experience supported by this training grant enhances recruitment of DVMs into graduate programs or other research career tracks. This translates into an increased proportion of DVMs who ultimately pursue research-oriented careers in academia, government, and industry, thereby addressing the national need for veterinary scientists who are an essential component of our biomedical research force. We will build upon this trajectory by establishing a formal relationship between the training program and a unique component of the veterinary medical curriculum at the Ohio State University: Career Areas of Emphasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The Duke-North Carolina Central University (NCCU)-Interdisciplinary Postdoctoral Training Program in Child Psychiatric and Neurodevelopmental Conditions (DN-IPT) is a partnership between Duke University School of Medicine and North Carolina Central University which will provide two to three years of intensive postdoctoral interdisciplinary research training to MD, PhD, and MD/PhD recipients with a focus on child psychiatric and neurodevelopmental conditions, as well as the developmental origins of adult psychiatric disorders. The DN-IPT will provide Trainees with focused, rigorous, in-depth training in a) our central theme of an interdisciplinary, developmental neuroscience research approach; and b) one or more of five research methodologies to interrogate this theme: (1) brain imaging; (2) computational approaches; (3) digital health; (4) interventions; and (5) preclinical models with an emphasis on enhancing diversity, equity, and inclusion at all phases of the research process.
PROJECT_TERMS: Child;North Carolina;post-doctoral training;programs;Training Programs;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: Duke-North Carolina Central University (NCCU)-Interdisciplinary Postdoctoral Training Program in Child Psychiatric and Neurodevelopmental Conditions Program (DN-IPT)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed training program is to prepare students for careers as highly creative, inquisitive and productive scientists. We seek to provide the trainees, who are pursuing their PhD in Neuroscience, with broad- based interdisciplinary training relevant to understanding a variety of diseases and disorders of the nervous system. Through didactic coursework, laboratory research, career development training, and instruction in the responsible conduct of research, the students supported through this training mechanism will be poised to make important contributions to preventing and curing a spectrum of neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as autism, epilepsy, schizophrenia, dementias, communicative disorders, and addiction.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences;pre-doctoral;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Predoctoral Training in Integrative Neuroscience

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to renew the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) Cancer Prevention and Control Training Program T32 training grant, the only one in the heart of the United States Deep South. We intend to train the next generation of cancer prevention and control scientists to conduct transdisciplinary research – an approach to creating new knowledge that builds upon standard team science approaches via exposure to new perspectives. Program components include high-quality mentorship by dual-mentor teams, experiential learning, and didactive courses that foster (a) knowledge acquisition regarding cancer prevention and control research, transdisciplinary research, and research ethics; and (b) professional, relational, and leadership skill development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To help ensure that the nation’s biomedical, clinical, and behavioral cancer research workforce remains strong, we present our vision for the next 5 years of the Case CCC Cancer-focused Summer Undergraduate Research (CanSUR) Program. The objectives of the program are to recruit 32 highly motivated undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds each year and (1) provide them with a cancer research experience including project development, execution, interpretation, and reporting of research results; (2) educate them about available cancer research career opportunities; and (3) provide Cancer-Focused Career and Scientific Enrichment Curriculum to help prepare them for the next step in a cancer research/oncology-focused career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The mission of our Neuroscience Training Program is to create the preeminent neurophotonics training program that will produce the next-generation of investigators capable of rigorously and creatively developing and applying photonics methods across a wide array of neuroscience sub- fields to advance our understanding of the brain in health and disease. Our trainees will gain the foundational knowledge of the field that will permit them to continue to grow with the field and efficiently translate their breakthroughs from the academic lab to real world applications. In addition to building a field-defining neurophotonics curriculum, combining technical training, computational / data analysis, and critical thinking skills, we will provide robust training in the professional and operational skills required for success in this highly interdisciplinary field.
PI_NAMEs: BOAS, DAVID A (contact);CHEN, JERRY L;SANDER, MICHELLE YEN-LING

PROJECT_TITLE: Graduate Training at the Interface of Neuroscience, Optical Engineering and Data Science

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  This multidisciplinary training program is designed to train pre-doctoral students (6 per year) to investigate the underlying the roles of Infection and Inflammation as Drivers of Aging. Increased training in biomedical sciences pertinent to the biology of aging is critical to address the needs of the growing number of older adults, that will make over a quarter of the US population and ~1.5 billion people worldwide by 2050. Specific training in the roles of infection and inflammation as drivers of aging will help understand and treat sources of inflammation that propagate and aggravate many chronic diseases of old age, including arthritis, cancers, cardiovascular, metabolic and neurodegenerative diseases, like Alzheimer’s and Parkinsons.
PROJECT_TERMS: drivers of aging;Infection;Inflammation;pre-doctoral;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Infection and Inflammation as Drivers of Aging (IIDA) Predoctoral Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We aim to launch the Duke Psychiatry Physician Scientist Track Program (Duke-PPST) to train world-class psychiatrist-scientists by providing coordinated and sustained mentoring and research experiences. The Duke- PPST will address the critical workforce shortage of psychiatrist-scientists including those working in child psychiatry, an area of particular strength in our department. The Duke-PPST will also add needed geographic diversity to NIMH R25 programs (currently only 2 programs are in the South, despite the South comprising nearly 40% of the US population) and will enhance diversity among the psychiatrist-scientist workforce through recruitment and support of trainees under-represented in medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since 2004, the Clinical and Translational Cancer Control Research Training Program (CCRTP) has appointed 49 exceptional postdoctoral trainees including next years’ class (36 PhDs:13 MDs) to prepare them for independent careers in the multidisciplinary arena of cancer control research through research, didactic training, and professional development. By providing exceptional mentoring and a unique, state-of-the-art environment, the CCRTP prepares trainees to better understand the numerous debilitating side effects of cancer treatment, develop novel interventions, advance standards of care, and improve quality of life for patients with cancer, survivors, and their caregivers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The AUGS/DUKE UrogynCREST program will teach participants how to utilize large datasets to perform research that will improve the delivery of high-quality health care for patients with pelvic floor disorders and encourage reproducible research. By providing creative educational activities that focus on research skills development and bringing together expertise in health services research, biostatistics, decision science, and data science, the program will add structure to the health data science education for assistant professor level faculty in urogynecology. Overall, the program will shape future scientific leaders in urogynecology by encouraging the development of clinician-scientists and provide the skills and mentorship for invigorating data discovery and tools for investigations in health service research specifically addressing pelvic floor disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Genetic counselors are vital to genomic medicine, but research questions in which they have key insights remain unanswered because most genetic counselors lack the practical experience, research methods expertise, and necessary research community to formulate, conduct, and lead large-scale research projects. PROMOTE-GC is designed to address these barriers by providing a part-time, 2-year research training experience for master’s-level genetic counselors that includes 1) mentored intensive research experiences, 2) training in research methods, and 3) support in building a durable, multidisciplinary professional research community they can call on in the future. This training benefits not only the individual genetic counselor participants, but also the genomic medicine enterprise by enhancing the research capacity of these vital members of the workforce.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Martinos Center at MGH requires reinvestment in its Siemens Eclipse HP cyclotron infrastructure to ensure continued access to PET radioisotopes for its dynamic MR-PET imaging program. Instead of replacing the cyclotron, a series of upgrades will extend its lifespan by 10-15 years and support an extraordinarily strong and growing user community. This cost-effective plan will guarantee a reliable supply of radioisotopes and radiotracers for NIH-funded investigators' research and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed training plan will educate early stage graduate students in the broad and interdisciplinary field of neuroscience. The program includes didactic coursework, training in critical thinking, experimental design and analysis, rigorous evaluation of laboratory research, and sustained experience in experimental science as well as training in personal and professional ethics, professional skill development, and career planning, all leading to a doctoral degree in neuroscience. Training takes place in an academic medical center environment with both fundamental basic research and translational and clinical research, allowing us to prepare trainees both intellectually and technically to become the next generation of neuroscientists, which is critical to the understanding and treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders.
PROJECT_TERMS: multidisciplinary;Neurosciences;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Training in Neuroscience

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Americans fear blindness more than virtually any other health problem. Approximately 14 million Americans, or approximately 6% of people aged 12 years and older, are visually-impaired. This will become an increasing clinical and public health problem as the population ages. Fundamental advances in science and technology have enormous promise for the treatment of eye disease. The premise of this proposal is to train the next generation of vision scientists in basic, clinical, and translational vision research to further our understanding of the underlying causes of ocular diseases and develop new clinical therapies for their treatment.
PROJECT_TERMS: Health;Oregon;Research;Science;Universities;vision science
PROJECT_TITLE: Translational Vision Science Research at Oregon Health & Science University

PHR: Narrative Training in the neurobiology of aging and Alzheimer's Disease is proposed to address the ever- increasing number of individuals in our society who have age-associated nervous system diseases and conditions, including Alzheimer's Disease. We propose to continue a successful interdisciplinary predoctoral training program that focuses on scientific excellence and leadership, diversity training, and preparation of trainees for successful careers in the neurobiology of aging and Alzheimer's Disease, through intensive research, research-related activities and publication of high-quality research reports.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a shortage of qualified clinician-scientists, particularly in Radiology to support and/or advance imaging science to enable non-invasive quantitative biomarker analyses to fuel discoveries aimed at detecting, treating, monitoring disease response to therapy, or understanding human diseases. The UT Southwestern (UTSW) campus and the Department of Radiology specifically, have outstanding and extensive physical and human resources and many well-funded, well-known, and experienced mentors to attract, engage and train future clinician scientists in Radiology. We developed a novel training model that engages trainee physicians in research early and keeps them engaged throughout their tenure that was highly successful during the prior award which we are renewing with yet more improvements.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Clinician Scientists as Outstanding Clinicians and Imaging Scientists

PHR: Project narrative This multidisciplinary five-year education program is designed to provide opportunities of early research exposure for high-school students, with the focus on promoting neuroimaging and data science technologies for AD/ADRD research. The program includes a set of asynchronous/synchronous short courses, hands-on practice, mentored research, scientific development activities, and a cloud-based computational platform for analyzing neuroimaging data. The expected outcome is to attract high-school students in AD/ADRD research and train next-generation investigators with computational skill-sets for solving real-world healthcare problems in AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will introduce a paradigm shift in how the microbiome alterations characterizing C. difficile infection (CDI) are viewed, one that would be highly clinically relevant toward improving our knowledge, and potentially our treatment, of a disease responsible for over 1.5 billion dollars in annual healthcare costs in the United States. The data from this project will help establish the role of fungi in CDI, especially C. glabrata; the role of fungi could help to explain the persistently elevated rate of treatment failures observed in current CDI therapy. The results of this project will broaden the scientific community’s understanding of the pathogenesis of CDI, while furthering work by Dr. Lamendella’s team, suggesting that fungi may be a therapeutic target in treating CDI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Howard University is a research-active Historically Black University that is uniquely positioned to recruit a strong cadre of talented recent baccalaureate graduates and train them for research- focus careers in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). We propose the development of the HU-ERA program to significantly address the deficit in the number of Black and African Americans in ADRD-focused PhD or MD/PhD programs or ADRD-research industry positions. Selected trainees will be provided with intensive, mentored research experiences, professional development, and career building activities to expand skills and expertise relevant to ADRD-focused biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is the deadliest of all human squamous cell carcinomas, and has a relatively low five-year survival rate. Abnormalities in stress response signaling and epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) have gained prominence as cancer promoting mechanisms. These studies will define whether radiation-induced persistent pATF2 stress response signaling, is a key node in promoting EMT and changes in the microenvironment that facilitate radiation-induced ESCC initiation and/or progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Mental health disorders are a major cause of disability that significantly reduces the quality of life. As new technologies emerge for assessing mental health disorders and as research design becomes increasingly complex, the Department of Biostatistics at Columbia University, in partnership with Columbia’s Department of Psychiatry and New York State Psychiatric Institute, has developed an innovative program to train predoctoral scholars in biostatistical methods, machine learning, data science, and interdisciplinary research in order to meet the emerging challenges brought by cutting edge technologies and big data. The program will build on the Department’s strengths and decades of success in rigorous training of biostatisticians to prepare trainees as next-generation leaders in mental health biostatistics and data science (MH-BDS).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

The diversity of professional research scientists can only result when all intelligent students are given the opportunity to ascertain their potential. The University of West Florida NIH URISE Scholars program will provide training opportunities and financial, academic, social, and professional support critical to recruitment and retention of students from underrepresented and disadvantaged backgrounds. These efforts are necessary to broadening and diversifying the pipeline of talented biomedical students to ensure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: OVERALL: NARRATIVE Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is an aggressive and clinically heterogeneous malignancy derived from germinal center (GC) B-cells. The central hypothesis of this P01 program is that different scenarios of aberrant GC immune synapse signaling to chromatin is the primary driver of these diverse DLBCL phenotypes and explains the divide between GCB and ABC DLBCLs. The various projects will synergistically probe this question from different perspectives, using innovative and cutting-edge technologies developed by the scientific cores, expecting to yield fundamental new insights into DLBCL pathogenesis and precision therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT 1: NARRATIVE This proposal explores how somatic mutations in chromatin modifier genes synergize to alter the epigenetic and 3D genomic landscapes of B-cells to drive formation of profoundly immune-evasive lymphomas. Specifically, the investigators will identify the basic mechanism through which the common CREBBP and KMT2D enhancer regulatory proteins synergize to drive lymphomagenesis and engage in aberrant cross-talk with T-cell subpopulations. Based on their mechanistic discoveries they will develop novel therapeutic regimens aimed at restoring the functionality of the immune system and making these tumors vulnerable to immune eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of our studies is to understand if a common type of aggressive lymphoma (diffuse large B-cell lymphoma) represents a biologically distinct entity when arises in elderly people. We will study epigenetic mechanisms associated with aging in favoring the activity of oncogenes and how this process may represent unique therapeutic vulnerabilities. If successful, these studies will launch the development of specific and likely low-toxicity treatments that could benefit elderly patients with incurable lymphomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT 4: NARRATIVE The activated B-cell-like subtype of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (ABC-DLBCL) is driven by chronic active B- cell receptor (BCR) signaling and constitutive NFκB activity. Here we aim to characterize the role of BCR and NFκB signaling in molding the epigenetic landscape of ABC DLBCL through transcription factors that recruit the histone acetyltransferase CREBBP. We will investigate the role of CREBBP in maintaining the expression of BCR and NFκB signaling genes, which may establish selective CREBBP inhibition as an attractive therapeutic strategy in ABC DLBCL.

PHR: CORE 1 LYMPHOMA MODEL SYSTEMS: NARRATIVE The preclinical models and therapeutics core (LMSC) scope is relevant to public health because it provides an effective strategy for developing cancer models for comprehensive tumor profiling. The proposed research is relevant to the NCI’s mission to conduct and fund research in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Niacin, or vitamin B3, is an essential nutrient linked to NAD+ metabolism, and critical to energy metabolism. It must be consumed through the diet since we are unable to synthesize or store it, and most metabolic pathways related to niacin and NAD+ are anabolic (involved in synthesis, or reclamation/salvage of the molecule). This application explores the potential relationship of 4PY, a terminal metabolite of NAD+ and niacin metabolism, with cardiovascular health, using analytical, genetic, molecular, cellular and physiological approaches, and preclinical models of disease.
