IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Recent FDA accelerated approvals of aducanumab and lecanemab for early-stage Alzheimer’s disease, and reported positive phase 3 results from donaneab, provide the first disease-modifying treatments to date, albeit with modest-to-moderate slowing of cognitive decline and the presence of potentially fatal vascular side effects known as Amyloid-Related Imaging Abnormalities (ARIA) in a subset of treated patients. Here, we will test our hypothesis that anti-amyloid antibodies with higher binding affinities for vascular amyloid are more likely to cause ARIA by comparing the biological and pathological binding characteristics of 4 clinical anti-amyloid antibodies to parenchymal plaque and vascular amyloid in human AD brain tissues and staining in amyloid mouse models. In addition, we will compare in vivo the ability of the murine analogs of 3 of the anti-amyloid antibodies to both lower plaque and vascular amyloid burden and induce ARIA in 5XE4 mice and, test antibody cocktails containing an anti-amyloid antibodies and either an anti-APOE mAb or an anti-complement C1s1 antibody to mitigate ARIA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Red blood cell (RBC) transfusion is a powerful therapeutic tool and the most common form of transplantation in clinical practice, yet the immune system of the transfusion recipient can respond to these foreign RBCs and cause harm through antibody production. We have developed a mouse model of RBC transfusion to identify the early signals that trigger the immune system to respond to donor RBCs. Such an understanding is an important step towards developing targeted therapies to block this detrimental immune response, especially in those who require lifelong RBC transfusion support such as those with sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are devastating brain disorders that disproportionately affect US minorities, who are underrepresented in ADRD genetics research. This supplement to the Alzheimer’s Disease Sequencing Project (ADSP)-Phenotype Harmonization Consortium will fund the preparation of electronic medical record-based phenotypes and research data from the Million Veterans Program (MVP)—one of the world’s largest diverse genetic research cohorts, including nearly 1 million US Veteran Volunteers—for eventual coordinated investigation by ADSP investigators. This work will therefore increase the diversity and power of future ADSP genetic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL AND SIX ESSENTIAL CHARACTERISTICS The overarching goal of the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center (SKCC) is to leverage research expertise to reduce the overall incidence, burden, and mortality from cancer in Greater Philadelphia and beyond. SKCC goals are realized through unique strengths in addressing cancer problems through collaboration across basic, clinical, and population research disciplines. SKCC is nucleated at Thomas Jefferson University (TJU) and enriched by fully integrated research consortium partner from Drexel University (DU); building on these strengths, SKCC focuses on addressing catchment area needs through nurturing transdisciplinary research, expanding innovative research capabilities, extending outreach and clinical research into the community, and enhancing the pace of bench-to-bedside discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease is a complex brain disorder that affects millions of Americans, but there are limited options to prevent or treat it. The National Institute on Aging has funded numerous research groups that use open science to better understand the disease and develop new treatments. The AD Knowledge Portal Data Coordination Center helps these researchers collaborate with one another and share their findings through online platforms to improve our understanding of Alzheimer's and find effective treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative The UC Irvine Center for Neural Circuit Mapping T32 Training Program will prepare the next generation of basic science researchers with an emphasis on neural circuit analysis of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Mental illness is a major cause of morbidity and disability in the United States and basic neurobiological mechanisms, particularly related to learning and memory function and dysfunction, remain elusive. This is a proposal for the renewal of the Howard Schneiderman T32 Training Program in Learning and Memory, which uses a transdisciplinary approach to cut across basic and clinical/translational science as well as across species and techniques. By combining advanced coursework and lab training with rigorous team science approaches, this program will continue to train the next generation of leaders in neuroscience, and equip them with the knowledge, tools, and experience to address the grand challenge of mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Obesity is a complex disease that occurs through genetic and epigenetic mechanisms and their interactions with the environment. The objective of the Training in Obesity Research Program at Pennington Biomedical Research Center is to train the highest caliber of postdoctoral fellows to understand the complex interactions between genetic, molecular, physiological, behavioral and environmental aspects of obesity and become productive research scientists in obesity with the capability of establishing successful scientific careers in academia, academic medicine, governmental agencies, and in the private sector.
PROJECT_TERMS: Obesity;Research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Obesity Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The botulinum neurotoxin, which causes the paralytic disease botulism is the most lethal toxin known to man with only 1 gram of the toxin can kill 1 million people. The toxin has the potential to be used as a weapon for bioterrorism and current antitoxin treatments for botulism are not practical in the event of a wide scale biological attack as the antitoxin has many drawbacks including limited supply, allergic reaction and limited treatment window. Our laboratory has discovered dipeptides as a potential treatment for botulism and will further study the dipeptides through chemical synthesis, enzyme assays and pharmacokinetic studies to fully evaluate the dipeptides as a therapeutic for the rapid treatment of botulism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The Training Program in Social Neuroscience Research provides rigorous training in basic and translational research in social behavior as it pertains to neuropsychiatric diseases, and seeks to identify and train a group of highly talented predoctoral students and postdoctoral fellows who will become the next generation of mental health investigators prepared to significantly advance our understanding and the treatment of social behavior deficits in neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric diseases. The goal of the program is to provide training through an integrated program of coursework, basic or translational laboratory training, seminars and retreats, teaching opportunities, mentoring, and career development activities to a new generation of creative, rigorous, and independent neuroscientists committed to the field of Social Neuroscience and to improving public health.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences Research;social neuroscience;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Social Neuroscience Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of our training program is to create a new generation of biologists with the skills to generate and analyze as well as interpret the complex data produced by modern approaches such as next generation sequencing, live cell imaging and flow cytometry. Our trainees will apply their training in Quantitative Cell & Molecular Biology to study problems related to cancer, infectious disease, microbiomes and development. At the same time, they will receive career guidance and develop transferrable skills to prepare them for leadership roles after graduation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Undergraduate students who experience food insecurity (FI) are at very high risk for eating disorders; however, the specific mechanisms linking the experience of FI to eating behaviors remain largely unknown. The proposed project aims to evaluate a mechanistic model of how daily experiences of FI are associated with 1) problematic eating behaviors, which in turn may amplify FI and eating disorder pathology and 2) poorer academic performance. Such knowledge can influence the development or modification of eating disorder treatments to address the unique concerns of students with FI and promote better health and well-being and increased academic attainment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the past 25 years, the zebrafish has become one of the most prominent model systems in which to study the genetic, molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying embryonic development, regeneration, and disease. This proposal requests support for an intensive two-week laboratory and lecture course held at the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL) for advanced graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and independent investigators that focuses on the development and genetics of zebrafish, with special emphasis on early embryogenesis, models of birth defects, and regeneration. In its 24th year, the MBL Zebrafish course is the only course of its kind worldwide, and it consistently receives rave reviews from participants, many of whom consider their experience in the course as instrumental in starting their own zebrafish research program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The core mission of the Stanford Neurosciences PhD training program is to foster development of the next generation of world leaders in neuroscience research, training, and outreach. Our program prepares students for careers in neuroscience by giving them tools to ask and answer questions about how the brain functions in health and disease, with vast implications for society ranging from treatments of neural diseases and disorders to implications for technology development, education, law, and the fundamental understanding of how our brains make us who we are. The diversity of research topics and faculty, the availability of novel technologies, the highly collaborative nature of the program, the innovative approach to curriculum, and the central role that students play in all aspects of their training are all unique aspects of the community and culture of the program.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences Research;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Neuroscience Research Training

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
PHR: This study will shed light on a wide variety of genetic, prenatal, early-life and family factors that influence the risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and on differences and similarities in the behaviors, abilities, and health of preschoolers with ASD. It will also provide insights into the experiences of adolescents with ASD as they mature. By helping to explain the causes of ASD and how ASD affects children, youth and young adults, this project will contribute to efforts to reduce the risk of ASD and improve the outcomes of affected children.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Component A: Study to Explore Early Development (SEED) Follow up Studies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Utilizing an extensive amount of qualitative and quantitative imaging, clinical, and functional data, we propose to investigate newly developed and novel chest CT scan imaging and spirometric markers to the investigation of lung tissue and airway injury and remodeling, and its evolution over time towards healing and recovery, or to chronic and disabling chronic lung disease. These investigations have the potential to enhance our ability for earlier and more effective detection or treatment, and to prevent disability.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Pulmonary Diseases in WTC Workers: Symptoms, Function, and Chest CT Correlates

It will also provide insights into the experiences of adolescents with ASD as they mature. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: As we approach the 20th anniversary of 9/11, the focus of this study is to thoroughly examine the long-term consequences of being exposed to 9/11 as a child, including mental and physical health, adult development, role functioning, relationships, independence and parenting Using our thoroughly characterized ongoing longitudinal, representative cohort of 9/11 directly exposed children, we will now conduct a third wave of physical and psychological assessments and add a thorough examination of adult developmental achievements and challenges. This will result in the largest, longest and most thoroughly studied cohort of 9/11 exposed children, and will give us the knowledge to mitigate their suffering and improve their lives, as well as the lives of children exposed to mass trauma in the future.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Longitudinal Follow-Up of 9/11 Directly Exposed Children in their Age of Transition: Independence, Occupation and Morbidity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative World Trade Center (WTC) responders were exposed to a mix of tiny dust particles as they participated in rescue and recovery efforts at the WTC in the aftermath of 9/11/2001. While all responders were exposed, the Fire Department of the City of New York (FDNY) responders were more intensely exposed to a larger array of inhaled particles. Given the magnitude and scale of events surrounding 9/11 and prior reports of cognitive dysfunction indicative of an underlying neurodegenerative disease, we propose here to examine cognitive symptoms, blood- based biomarkers, and Beta-Amyloid and Tau burden using positron emission tomography (PET) combined with magnetic resonance neuroimaging (MRI) in a group of FDNY responders to compare with work being completed now in the NYPD and Volunteer responders at Stony Brook University as part of an existing NIA-funded study of brain aging.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cognition and neuropathology in World Trade Center-exposed FDNY, NYPD, and construction worker responders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative As the World Trade Center general responder cohort ages (current median age is 59), the assessment of aging- related syndromes (e.g., falls, functional decline) and implementation of healthy aging interventions become increasingly important. The goals of this study are to: (1) validate a frailty index among the WTC general responder cohort that will allow identification of risk factors that worsen frailty trajectories and predict aging- related outcomes; and (2) implement a pilot multicomponent intervention targeting modifiable risk factors of frailty among WTC responders. This work will enable timely monitoring for frailty and the development of interventions to promote healthy aging and to prevent further clinical decline in this high-risk population.
PI_NAMEs: HUNG, WILLIAM W.,MPH, MD;KO, FRED CHAU-YANG (contact);ORNSTEIN, KATHERINE A
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Promoting healthy aging among WTC responders: Frailty trajectories and intervention strategies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The adverse health effects at the intersection of metabolic syndrome, particulate matter exposure, and pulmonary disease are a global health concern. In the context of our FIREHOUSE cohort, we will i. perform comprehensive and integrative multiOMIC profiling to identify metabolic contributors and biosignatures of disease and its potential therapeutic targets; ii. Determine long-term effectiveness of our multidisciplinary approach to improve health outcomes; iii. validate our observations made in the prior funding period and iv. determine feasibility and need using shared decision making of the technology supported nutritional intervention. This work falls squarely within the purview of the James Zadroga 9/11 Health & Compensation Act.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Metabolomics of World Trade Center-Lung Injury: Biomarker Validation, Longitudinal Assessment and Dietary Intervention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The primary goals of the current project are to examine musical rhythm entrainment as a mechanism of healthy social development as well as disruptions thereof in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), a condition defined by atypical social interaction. Building on our prior findings demonstrating that infant eye-looking entrains to the rhythmic social cuing of a caregiver during musical interactions, this collaborative project leverages infant- directed singing to examine predictability as a driver of social rhythmic entrainment, including through the use of music and rhythm to enhance predictable delivery of social information delivered during naturalistic developmental behavioral interventions for ASD. This collaborative research will inform understanding of basic mechanistic processes of social entrainment in ASD and will support the development of evidence-based music interventions for social communication in ASD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Central nervous system (CNS) stimulants are controlled substances that are associated with a (high) potential for misuse and abuse. They are prescribed for many Veterans with mild TBI, however, little is known about their prescription pattern and safety in this population. The proposed project will fill in this significant knowledge gap by characterizing CNS stimulant prescription pattern in the VA, examining their adverse effects, and developing an explainable machine (deep) learning prediction model for individual-level risk assessment.

This proposal leverages emerging technologies that facilitate the delineation of cell-type specific brain molecular signatures predictive of resilience to substance abuse.

PHR: NARRATIVE Bacterial genes acquired through horizontal transfer are silenced by small histone-like proteins and by the transcription termination factor Rho. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pluripotency refers to the ability of a cell to generate any adult tissue in the body, and can be recapitulated in different types of pluripotent stem cells (PSCs) in culture. Mechanistic understanding of how pluripotency is regulated in PSCs is important to realize their full potential for regenerative medicine. The proposed project is focused on deciphering the molecular mechanisms regulating newly discovered PSCs in our laboratory that are competent for efficient differentiation into both somatic and germ cell lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Ineffective resolution of the effects of stress and aging on cellular proteins can lead to formation of plaques, fibrils, and other aggregated species encountered in aging cells, cataract, and neurodegenerative diseases. This project aims to understand how the protein chaperones called small heat shock proteins change in response to physiological, pathophysiological, and chronic stress conditions and how their chaperone capacity is modulated. Focus will be on small heat shock proteins found in tissues of the eye (lens, retina, cornea) that are implicated in three of the most prevalent pathologies leading to blindness worldwide: cataract, diabetic retinopathy, and age-related macular degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diverse perspectives in biomedical and behavioral research lead to greater innovation and greater recognition of issues that continue to threaten the health, well-being, and inclusion of underrepresented (UR) communities. Consequently, increasing the diversity of biomedical and behavioral research scientists increases our potential to address the most urgent public health challenges, and is critical to the full realization of our national research goals. The proposed UF MARC program would recruit traditionally UR students who are considering a career as a research scientist, place them in mentored research environments with experienced faculty mentors, provide them with an integrated training curriculum to increase their technical and operational skills, and support their wellness and professional development through to their graduation with a BS degree and continuation to a competitive PhD program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROPOSAL NARRATIVE There is no guidance available on the concurrent use of opioids and biologics in individuals with autoimmune disease, despite the potential for severe immunosuppression through a pharmacodynamic drug-drug interaction between opioids and biologics. This research proposal assesses the patterns and safety outcomes of concurrent opioids and biologics use in older adults with autoimmune disease. Findings will address a critical research gap around on the safety of concurrent opioid and biologic use and inform clinical practices to optimize treatment strategies for older adults with autoimmune diseases, directly addressing Strategic Goal C of the National Institute on Aging to “…maintain the health, well-being, and function of older adults”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American Indians and Alaska Natives rarely participate in research studies on Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. This is unlikely to change unless effective communication and recruitment strategies for clinical studies are developed. In this research, we assess how American Indians and Alaska Natives seek, process and react to online information sources about Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, develop a culturally tailored website, and administer a pilot study to evaluate the feasibility of a future effectiveness trial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Neonatal hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) continues to cause significant morbidity and mortality despite introduction of therapeutic hypothermia. Neonates with HIE are often hemodynamically unstable and clinicians have only indirect measures, such as blood pressure, to determine if cerebral blood flow is adequate to meet the brain’s metabolic demands. The overall goal of this renewal is to determine if direct continuous bedside monitoring of cerebral oxygen metabolism and cerebral blood flow with our novel devices has the potential to ensure cerebral blood flow meets metabolic demands; and in future improve outcomes by improving management of hemodynamic stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia in the elderly population, affecting more than 5 million Americans and 15 million people worldwide. The development of effective disease-modifying therapeutics for AD would greatly benefit from in vivo biomarkers, preferentially those that tag the very earliest stages of the disease. It is critical to establish a panel of valid biomarkers for diagnosis and monitoring its progression, or even prevent it by targeting several pharmaceutical candidates. Despite several existing biomarkers for AD, they do not capture the heterogeneity of the disease and more importantly, lack the sensitivity and specificity for early diagnosis. To address this key challenge and knowledge gap, this proposal aims to develop an innovative multi-faceted approach enabled by multiplexed protein quantitation technology and new advancements of MS instrumentation coupled with front-end sample enrichment and separation strategies for improved glycoproteomics and PTM crosstalk analysis. These technological advancements in combination with clinical neuroimaging will accelerate novel AD biomarker discovery and validation. The successful outcome of this research will have broad impact on translational medicine and will have profound impact on the physical and emotional health of millinois of individual patients at risk for this devastating diease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One step to combat health disparities is to increase diversity in the biomedical workforce, including translational scientists. This program will provide a unique opportunity for underrepresented undergraduate students to have hands-on experience performing translational research. In combination with educational activities, students will be given the foundational tools for successful careers in translational science and will enhance the future biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because developing new quantitative methods to target and test epilepsy surgery in computer models before doing these procedures in the operating room will improve patient outcomes and reduce surgery side effects and costs. In this research we are also working with 15 major epilepsy centers to standardize treatment. For these reasons the proposal is relevant to part of the NIH’s mission to foster fundamental, creative discoveries and innovative research strategies that will ultimately protect and improve human health for the United States’ 3.3 million people with epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how cell fates are specified in the embryo is a long standing goal of developmental biology. Here we explore a previously unappreciated epithelial to mesenchymal transition in the posterior endoderm, one of the three germ layers that comprise the early embryo, wherein cells invade the neighboring tailbud mesenchyme and potentially contribute to neuromesodermal fates. Understanding signals that regulate this process, the identity of these cells and their progeny, and their potential to differentiate along a remarkably wide range of lineages may have potentially far reaching implications for the study of induced pluripotency, cell reprogramming, and directed differentiation, as well as the pathogenesis of cancer, which commonly originates in endodermally derived tissues, and propagates via epithelial to mesenchymal transition.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Family caregivers play a central role during a Veteran’s critical care (medical care for a life-threatening illness or injury) hospitalization and survivorship. Yet, up to 73% of caregivers experience anxiety and 97% experience depression during a critically ill patient’s hospital stay. Addressing family caregiver needs, including informational and emotional processing, social support and self-care, during key moments early in a family’s crisis may moderate the development of caregiver psychological distress. This research focuses on determining common key moments in the caregiver experience that can lead to distress (Aim 1), designing psychosocial intervention components to meet caregiver needs during these key moments (Aim 2), and testing the feasibility and acceptability of these components (Aim 3), which seek to moderate the development of psychological distress among caregivers of critically ill Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative: The cells lining our intestine are critical for absorbing nutrients, preventing infection, and are the source of colon cancer. These cells are not uniform, but perform specialized functions, and in turn, these different cells utilize energy differently. The proposed work is relevant to human health because it will reveal how cellular metabolism is controlled in different cell types lining the intestine; and new mechanisms of metabolic control could provide therapeutic entry points to bolster regenerating cells to repair the intestine or suppress changes induced by an obesogenic diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) has prioritized the need to examine health effects of chemical mixtures, as well as the joint effects of chemical and social stressors, to better reflect real-life exposure scenarios and inform more refined policies to protect the public. We will address gaps in our understanding of the role of metal exposures in the prenatal programming of transdiagnostic pathways to preadolescent anxiety and depressive symptomatology, including interactions with broadly measured stress domains, and the role of placenta signaling. Explicating modifiable environmental risk factors and early biomarkers of risk so that interventions can be applied early to promote optimal development may have significant implications for prevention of chronic psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The field of Redox Biology is rapidly advancing with the introduction of improved tools and insight to understand how disrupted redox-regulated signaling pathways contribute to pathogenesis of pulmonary vascular diseases. This project will establish how the content or distribution of a critical vascular antioxidant enzyme, extracellular superoxide dismutase, contributes to pathologic redox regulated signaling in pulmonary hypertension and provide the foundation for novel targeted therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative  The use of antipsychotic medication among pregnant and lactating women has increased in frequency in recent years. However, antipsychotic efficacy for psychiatric illness has not been directly tested in this population, and many unanswered questions remain about the potential effects of antipsychotics on the development of the fetus, neonate, and infant. We hope to determine whether antipsychotics are effective for pregnant women with severe mental illness and whether they have any measurable effects on infant development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the effects of vertical integration on healthcare quality, patient outcomes, and cost will be of high importance to payers and policymakers, in deciding how to respond to the vertical integration trend. If we find quality improvements, this would justify investing in and encouraging vertical integration. If we find no significant effects or negative effects on quality, this would support policies that discourage integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE  Investigating the mechanism of action of the cytokine macrophage migration inhibitory factor is essential to better understand its genetic contribution to rheumatoid arthritis, which is the most common inflammatory arthritis in the United States. Experiments with mouse models and cell cultures are excellent tools for such studies, which also permit evaluation of precision-based treatments that may be tailored to patients with high expression forms of the MIF gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a devastating pediatric disease caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading DMD boys to wheelchair, followed by premature death within the second/third decade of their life. There is not yet a definitive cure of the disease; however, the recent entry into clinical trials of gene therapies approaches aimed at restoring dystrophin in DMD boys prompted an interest to evaluate the full spectrum of alterations caused by dys deficiency and whether they can be completely or partly restored upon gene therapy. This proposal will address this urgent issue, by investigating the relationship between dystrophin deficiency and the altered tri-dimensional genome topology and deregulated gene expression in DMD muscles, and by determining whether these alterations could be reversed upon dystrophin replacement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Childhood voice disorders can have profound influences on communication that, in turn, can impact physical, cognitive, and emotional development. Here we leverage the expertise of a multidisciplinary team to develop objective measures of voice quality, specifically targeting the pediatric population in the first NIH-funded laboratory study of pediatric voice quality perception. This pre-translational research introduces a theoretical framework grounded in principles and models from auditory perception and is focused on improving diagnostic procedures and treatment outcome measures for children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The NJ/NY Hazardous Materials Worker Training Center will provide training in hazardous materials, environmental careers, and disaster preparedness in Federal Region 2. The public health impact of training provided by the Center will prevent and reduce injuries and illness due to potential risks during hazardous waste operations, emergency and disaster response. Training provided is the vital to educating workers in safety and health issues. The Center is well-prepared to conduct the training proposed in this application. Center members have significant existing collaborations with their proposed target populations. The Center has successfully met their training projections in previous years of funding. The Center has trained over 450,000 workers, providing over 3.8 million contact hours of training with funds from the NIEHS WTP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The encephalitic, arthropod-borne alphaviruses including Venezuelan, eastern and western equine encephalitis viruses can cause fatal disease in humans and equines. There are no licensed human vaccines or antiviral drugs for the alphaviruses and the trivalent veterinary vaccine, given against VEEV, EEEV and WEEV, is poorly immunogenic, requiring frequent boosts. Together, these alphaviruses possess potential for use in biowarfare/bioterrorism and also present a threat for large-scale outbreaks. Based upon recent advances in understanding of the virulence mechanisms of each of these viruses, we propose to generate highy attenuated, immunogenic and stable live attenuated vaccines that can be used either as veterinary or human vaccines. We will test the possibility of using them as single virus formulations or as multivalent formulations against the encephalitic alphaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The myelin sheath surrounding axons is essential for the proper function of the nervous system and its disruption causes many devastating diseases including multiple sclerosis. G protein coupled-receptors (GPCRs) are excellent therapeutic targets. Here, we propose to characterize how adhesion GPCR GPR56 mediates cell-cell communication during central nervous system myelin development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Dendritic cells (DC) are professional antigen presenting cells that serve critical roles in both innate and adaptive immune responses. This project investigates how DC focally deliver cytokines like interleukin 33 to T cells for shaping the inflammatory vs. anti-inflammatory responses generated within the respiratory mucosa through mechanisms dependent upon the enigmatic pore-forming protein Perforin-2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Health disparities in obesity begin in infancy and continue to worsen throughout the lifespan. Preventing rapid weight gain in infancy among communities of color and economically marginalized populations is a priority area of clinical research, and responsive parenting appears to be a promising prevention approach. Embedding a responsive parenting obesity prevention in a pediatric primary care setting that families are familiar and engaged with has the potential to bolster uptake and improve health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Cell- and matrix-mediated mechanisms drive the formation of tendon hierarchical structure necessary for proper mechanical function. Collagen XII, a fibril-associated collagen, is known to play a structural role in forming flexible bridges between collagen fibrils, and our recent data also indicate a novel role for collagen XII in tendon cell organization and communication. Using mouse models to spatiotemporally modulate collagen XII expression, our proposed studies will define the temporal roles of collagen XII in cell organization and matrix assembly during the phases of tendon development and healing, which is highly significant in both furthering our understanding of why tendons heal poorly and providing guidance for future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are currently facing unprecedented challenges in survivorship care delivery, including serious gaps in survivorship care (e.g., underuse of guideline-recommended cancer surveillance services and underuse of recommended preventive care services); these issues are compounded by the growing population of cancer survivors and the predicted oncology workforce shortage. To address these issues, we will conduct a prospective cluster randomized trial of two models of cancer survivorship care in early-stage colorectal cancer and breast cancer survivors cared for in a community-based, integrated health care setting. We will test the efficacy of an embedded PCP model (experimental condition) in which survivorship-trained PCPs are embedded within an oncology practice, compared to the oncology physician model (usual care) that is the default condition in this healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The work proposed will lead to scientific understanding of visuomotor functions in two areas of the human cortex, the posterior parietal cortex and primary motor cortex. The results will have direct relevance to the development of neuroprosthetic medical devices that can use the complimentary features of both areas. Such devices can help people with severe paralysis from spinal cord lesion and other traumatic accidents, peripheral neuropathies, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, multiple sclerosis, and stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. 15-Prostaglandin dehydrogenase (15-PGDH) degrades prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), a signaling molecule that promotes tissue repair and regeneration in multiple tissues. Therefore, inhibitors of 15-PGDH elevate PGE2 levels in tissue and may represent therapeutics for diseases characterized by ulceration or tissue damage. Here, we will use structure-based methods to design inhibitors of 15-prostaglandin dehydrogenase, determine the cell types that express and respond to 15-PGDH, and decipher the cytokine network that regulates tissue repair in response to PGE2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative – Overall The goal of this research is to understand how variation in the number of oligosaccharide chains attached to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) affect fertility and other age-related issues in women, such as osteoporosis. This integrated research program will study FSH binding to its receptor, altering receptor oligomerization, activating different signal initiators, and stimulating different pathways both in cells and in whole organisms. The potential translational outcomes of this research is potentially improved drugs for infertility treatment or for ameliorating the bone-damaging effects of age-related increased FSH in the blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: Falls are common and devastating for long-term care residents, yet fall prevention strategies have been largely unsuccessful. This study examines a novel approach for maintaining/improving muscle health with a bone health agent that should pave the way for a falls/fracture prevention trial in this vulnerable cohort.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall Addiction is a chronic relapsing brain disorder, and understanding how the brain can go awry will speed the design of more effective therapies. The University of Minnesota has thriving communities of both NIDA-supported addiction researchers and biomedical technology innovators. By bringing these communities together, our Center for Neural Circuits in Addiction would drive innovative, high-impact research at the local and national level to help curtail this growing health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of individuals with clinical Alzheimer's disease (AD) is rapidly increasing worldwide due to aging of the population, but current cognitive measures lack sufficient sensitivity and specificity to detect subtle decline within the preclinical phase. There is a critical need for tools that are sensitive to AD neuropathology during the preclinical phase that are low-cost, high-access, and fast to administer that can be used across educationally, linguistically, and culturally diverse older individuals. The goal of this project is to identify metrics for semantic impairment in diverse individuals that correlate with AD neuropathology and predict clinical decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CSHL Laboratory Course in Advanced Techniques in Molecular Neuroscience This application seeks funds to support an advanced neuroscience lab-based short course at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, New York. The course aims to provide advanced training in state-of- the-art molecular approaches in neuroscience. Trainees include advanced graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and young faculty from throughout the United States and abroad. The selection process for entry into these courses is highly competitive, and trainees leave the course armed with new techniques, know-how and potential collaborators to apply to their own areas of research. A significant proportion of trainees subsequently undertake basic or applied research in diseases of mental health and/or neurological disorders. Methods and concepts taught in the course are disseminated to the wider research community through the publication of laboratory manuals and online resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project ultimately aims at optimizing the non-invasive monitoring of exercise therapy in heart failure patients to potentially improve outcome. The research strategy is designed to systematically develop an innovative cardiac diffusion tensor MRI method that overcomes major shortcomings of the conventional methods and aims at immediate clinical translation. Successful completion of this project will result in a clinically robust cardiac diffusion tensor MRI method that can effectively monitor the efficacy of exercise therapy and potentially improve treatment of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative:  It is known that metformin (MF), a widely prescribed, firstline anti-diabetic drug, can positively modulate lipid, metabolic and inflammatory profiles. Interestingly, recent reports show that MF treatment before and after ischemic injury reduces stress and inhibits inflammatory responses. Recent published work by our group and as well as current preliminary data reveal that MF promotes the activation of counteractive mechanisms which drastically reduce tobacco smoke (TS) and e-cigarette (e-Cig) toxicity at both the brain and cerebrovascular levels, protects BBB integrity, and improves stroke outcome. Ultimately our data suggest that repurposing MF could provide a suitable prophylactic and/or post stroke therapeutic agent to be utilized for a high risk, stroke-prone populations of smokers and possibly early stage former smokers.  To this end, the goal of our current research endevour is to understand further the mechanisms and extent to which metformin can prevent/reduce BBB damage and subsequent ischemic stroke injuries in high risk populations of smokers and vapers. We are concurrently exploring the inhibition of pathological mechanisms related to the dysregulation of Nrf2, which is similarly involved in TS/e-Cig cerebrovascular impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  As pharmaceutical targets become more complex, organic methodologies that form complex carbon skeletons from simple precursors are especially desirable. The proposed research seeks to study classic carbon- –carbon bond forming methodologies and apply them in novel ways toward the synthesis of the complex hydrocarbon dodecahedrane. The chemistry developed in this proposal will provide insight into the synthesis of complex molecules from simple substrates, which constitutes basic research toward the furtherment of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Affective mood disorders, such as major depressive disorder (MDD), are challenging to treat and have a disproportionate impact on society and health care costs. A key challenge in developing effective treatments for MDD is that it is more commonly diagnosed in women that in men and coping strategies are typically different. The aim of this proposal is to incorporate social decision making and motivation in a sex-dependent manner to understand the spectrum of social stress coping mechanisms and identify the brain-wide neural signature of social resiliency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Humans rely on vision and perceptual decision-making for healthy functioning and survival. Impairments in visual processing and perceptual decision-making are significant causes of morbidity in neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease and schizophrenia, but the brain regions and computations that give rise to visual decision formation remain poorly understood. The goal of this proposal is to gain mentored training and leverage modern electrophysiological, computational, and behavioral approaches to map visual, motor, and abstract decision coding in the midbrain reticular nucleus, a potentially novel node in the distributed network underlying visual perceptual decision-making.

PHR: Narrative The principles of chemistry describe the molecular interactions that define life and distinguish between sickness and health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is a devastating neurodegenerative disease affecting ~6.5 million Americans aged 65 and older with no currently available treatment that reverses the course of the disease. BIN1 is the second most significant locus according to genome-wide associate studies for the development of late onset Alzheimer’s disease, only behind ApoE4, and we have very little idea of how BIN1 may confer increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease. I will use a novel discovery approach coupled to the latest advancements in quantitative mass spectrometry to define the BIN1 protein interaction network, which will lead to the discovery of new BIN1 functional pathways that may increase Alzheimer’s disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goals and training philosophy of the proposed MARC at Vanderbilt T34 Institutional Training Program are congruent with and contribute to the overarching mission of the MARC mechanism - to develop a diverse pool of undergraduates who complete their baccalaureate degree, and transition into and complete biomedical, research-focused higher degree programs (e.g., Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D.). Our training program is designed to ensure that future biomedical faculty and researchers are drawn from the entire diverse undergraduate talent pool at Vanderbilt to expand and enable a more inclusive and productive biomedical research community. The relevance of this training for public health cannot be understated, as it is the education and research training of young scientists that will provide the foundation for future discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease progression is characterized by cellular expression of ApoE4, reduced metabolism in the central nervous system, and protein pathologies involving Tau and Amyloid-Beta. The roles of neuronal glucose metabolism and neuronal ApoE4 in Alzheimer’s Disease development are not well understood due to both the complex metabolic interactions between neurons and glia. We will therefore clarify the role of neuronal metabolism in the progression of Alzheimer’s Disease through a combination of genomics, metabolomics, and targeted validation of these changes through quantification of protein-level changes and intracellular ATP levels, enabling us to capture a complete picture of how neurons metabolically respond to their expression of ApoE4.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Clinicians emerging from interdisciplinary fields including medicine, psychology, nursing and rehabilitation sciences are deeply familiar with the unmet needs of older adults and individuals with persistent or serious illness, yet they lack the necessary research methods training, mentorship and support to pursue rigorous clinical behavioral preventive health research. The proposed postdoctoral training program will provide a solution to this problem by providing talented MD and PhD trainees with world-class, interdisciplinary research training in clinical behavioral preventive health intervention development following the NIH Stage Model and Center for Disease Prevention framework of primary, secondary and tertiary prevention.

PROJECT_TITLE: Bridging the Science-to-Service Gap in Aging Care: Prevention, Optimization and Living Well with Persistent or Serious Illnesses

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lens cataract originates from disrupted lens microarchitecture and is a major cause of worldwide blindness. The majority of cataracts are caused by mutations in all crystallin genes, DNA-binding transcription factors (e.g. PAX6, MAF and HSF4), RNA-binding proteins (TDRD7 and Rbm24), and through mutations in 5’-UTRs of lens expressed genes (ferritin light chain FTL and solute transporter SLC16A12). Novel non-coding mutations in crystallin and other loci encoding abundant lens proteins remain poorly understood and this proposal will add insights into the function of non-coding cis-acting regulatory regions that will facilitate interpretation of human GWAS studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE WINSHIP CANCER INSTITUTE OF EMORY UNIVERSITY CANCER CENTER SUPPORT GRANT As the only NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center in Georgia, Winship Cancer Institute of Emory University (Winship) serves as the primary institution for cancer care, research, training, and education for the state. Winship's mission is to discover cures for cancer and inspire hope. Research conducted by Winship has directly contributed to FDA approval of new anti-cancer agents, first-in-human clinical trials, new national clinical trials and health care policy changes in the state of Georgia. Winship aims to: (1) conduct transformative research; (2) accelerate the translation of Winship member discoveries; (3) reduce the burden of cancer in its catchment area; and (4) promote education, training, and mentorship.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Most behavioral weight-loss interventions have had mixed outcomes, with interventions failing to make a substantial or persistent difference in racial/ethnic minority populations. This may be secondary to neglecting the influence of an individual’s social environment. The results of this feasibility randomized control trial will result in a multi-level intervention that targets individual and network-level barriers to weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells that display profound genome instability have often lost their ability to repair chromosome double-strand breaks (DSBs) by the accurate processes of homologous recombination; they also have lost their ability to activate the DNA damage response, which arrests cell cycle progression. This proposal investigates the mechanisms of repairing DSBs by homologous recombination and the interrelationship between DNA repair and the DNA damage response, primarily using budding yeast. This grant will also allow investigation of the poorly understood homologous recombination mechanisms that underlie the ability of the Lyme disease bacterium, Borrelia burgdorferi, to escape immune surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health relevance of age-related osteoporosis is enormous, since the condition affects more than 10 million Americans over 50 and causes about 2 million fractures yearly; the latter are associated with pain, loss of independence, and high mortality. Presently only a minority of patients with osteoporosis receive treatment, because few appropriate therapies are available, and because of both patients’ and physicians’ fear of serious side effects. We identified a novel cross-talk between the nitric oxide/cGMP/protein kinase G (PKG) signaling pathway and the protein sirtuin-1, a master-regulator of cellular and organismal aging; we now propose to combine pharmacological activation of PKG and sirtuin-1 to develop a new anabolic treatment strategy for age-related osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetes is a global heath epidemic, and bioengineering approaches and new technology are needed to advance the development of effective diagnostics, management strategies and cures for diabetes. However there is a shortage of a skilled scientific workforce able to work on these developments, due to the unique training required. We will leverage the outstanding previous experience, expertise, resources and institutional support at the University of Colorado to develop such a training program, in order to attract and train outstanding PhD students, to prepare them for outstanding research careers in academia and industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The public health relevance of the proposed research derives from three fundamental questions in biogerontology and biodemography: (1) To what extent have increases in life expectancy at age 65 and above been accompanied by compression of morbidity/disability? (2) Can we uncover the underlying genetic pathways and modifiable non-genetic risk factors that contribute to enhanced or diminished degrees of morbidity/disability compression? (3) Can we use the insights, information, and understanding gained from questions 1 and 2 to further compress the period of morbidity/disability near the end of life through strategies designed to delay the manifestation of signs/symptoms of severe physical and/or cognitive impairment— including AD/ADRD?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract obstruction is a leading cause of chronic kidney disease and end stage renal disease in children. The renal urothelium remodels in response to obstruction to protect the kidney from further injury. This proposal aims to identify molecular mechanisms governing urothelial development and repair and forms the foundation for novel therapeutic approaches to care for patients with urinary tract obstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: The BRCA-mutant cancers retain key features of the underlying homologous recombination defect (HRD) or “BRCAness”, conferring a vulnerability to targeted therapies that induce replication stress and DNA damage. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many types of cancer, especially breast, ovarian and pancreatic cancers, show genetic changes caused by defective DNA repair. This project will identify factors that control how DNA repair is regulated, so that new strategies can be identified to prevent or cure these types of cancer. In particular, we will study how an important repair factor, BRCA1, gets to DNA break sites to carry out repair, and prevent the appearance of cancer.

PHR: This “Predoctoral Training in a Multifaceted Translational Approach to Mental Illness (AMI)” program is focused on providing training to highly motivated pre-doctoral students in the field of translational research in mental health. UAB has a large base of interdisciplinary faculty with interests centered in basic and clinical research, therapeutics and biomarkers, as well as genetics and functional genomics in the area of mental health. With the NIMH supported T32 program, our highly trained faculty, with the support of diverse resources and an enriched environment, are committed to provide an exceptionally strong mentoring framework to train the next generation of mental health researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative ! Converging lines of evidence provide compelling evidence that the functional domain of the cerebellum is not restricted to sensorimotor control, but extends to domains as diverse as perception, attention, language, and mathematics. To date, functional hypotheses have either been largely descriptive or targeted to account for cerebellar function in a relatively narrow, task-specific manner. The overarching goal of this research program is to take a more mechanistic approach, one designed to extend our understanding of cerebellar function across multiple task domains through the integrated use of behavioral and neuroimaging studies in healthy and neurologically impaired populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH) This study is the first effort to investigate the deep mechanisms underlying the recurrent A20 mutations in Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) based upon results from a high-throughput CRISPR library screen. Gaining insight into the pathological roles of the A20-LUBAC axis in HL can lead to improved understanding of the molecular circuitry that drives tumor survival and immune escape. The therapeutic potential of targeting LUBAC will be tested using a highly specific LUBAC small molecular inhibitor, which is an approach that can provide novel intervention strategies for both targeted and immune therapies in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE On top of the persistent ~10% of new U.S. HIV infections that occur among people who inject drugs (PWID), recent HIV outbreaks in several areas of the United States including Massachusetts have caused renewed concern about HIV transmission in PWID, who often have overlapping injection and sexual risk. Despite the proven efficacy of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendation that PrEP be offered to PWID at risk for HIV, uptake in this socially marginalized population remains severely limited. A brief, multi-component behavioral intervention delivered to PWID by highsly trained PrEP Navigators embedded within syringe service programs has the potential to increase PrEP use among PWID, thus decreasing HIV incidence in this socially-marginalized population and reducing onward transmission to injecting and sexual partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this proposal is to train pre-doctoral graduate students of exceptional promise for scientific research careers in molecular biophysics, which is an area that embraces principles and concepts from diverse fields in the natural sciences including biology, physics, chemistry, and mathematics. A rigorous quantitative foundation in molecular biophysics is vital for developing a deep understanding of the biology underlying a broad swath of public health issues, as this knowledge is key not only to the development of effective therapeutic strategies for mitigating diseases but also for the development of new biological tools and technologies. The training program envisioned in this proposal will thus address an urgent and critical need for highly-qualified research personnel in an area of vital importance to public health while ensuring the country's preeminence in biomedical research.

PROJECT_TITLE: Molecular Biophysics Training Program at Northwestern University

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The efficient repair of DNA damage requires a carefully orchestrated cascade of signaling events in the chromatin flanking the damage site in order to recruit the appropriate repair proteins. In this project we aim to characterize the role of EHMT2, a protein methyl transferase that has important roles in chromatin regulation, in the DNA repair signaling pathway. If successful, this study could lead to the rational development of EHMT2 inhibitors to target the DNA repair pathway in human cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Stuttering affects 70 million people worldwide and has lifelong adverse consequences. This project examines the mechanisms underlying the development of stuttering in individual preschool children. We use a comprehensive, multilevel approach to map the development of neurological, behavioral, and experiential factors to learn how these factors unfold over time and contribute to different stuttering outcomes—persistence or recovery. This proposal is consistent with the mission of NIH in that scientific discoveries from our research will improve understanding of how stuttering develops in individual children, leading to advances in diagnostic and intervention approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a large and increasing number of older adults with dementia who are living at home with supports from family and other caregivers, and these individuals and caregivers are extremely vulnerable in disaster situations. This research will test the efficacy of a Disaster PrepWise (DPW) intervention delivered through an existing public health disaster management infrastructure, Medical Reserve Corp, on enhancing resilience and reducing stress among caregivers by providing individualized support to develop personalized disaster preparedness plans and emergency support networks. The number of federally declared disasters continues to increase in the US, thus, understanding the efficacy of this program and optimal implementation strategies can lead to promising public health approaches to address disaster-related vulnerability among persons with dementia and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop an undergraduate training program that will provide opportunities for research training and professional development, leading to entrance into a PhD degree program for students from groups that are underrepresented in the biomedical workforce. Our program will develop these students into experienced researchers, with the technical, operational and professional skill sets needed to succeed in graduate school where they will continue training to produce new biomedical knowledge to solve the complex problems of disease and illnesses that adversely affect human health. As these students pursue graduate degrees in biomedical research, our program will enhance the diversity of the biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing sedentary behavior is a new strategy that may improve cardiovascular health among young women, a group recently identify as having accelerated, sex-specific cardiovascular risk development that is even higher when the woman has experienced an adverse pregnancy outcome. This project seeks to thoroughly and efficiently investigate relationships between sedentary behavior and all-day activity patterns with ideal cardiovascular health components (blood pressure, body mass index, cholesterol, and glucose) by conducting an ancillary study set within an existing longitudinal cohort of more than 4,000 young women (i.e., Nulliparous Pregnancy Outcomes Study Monitoring Mothers-to-Be Heart Health Study [nuMoM2b HHS]). By adding gold standard sedentary behavior measurement, using emerging statistical methods in physical activity epidemiology, and adding measurement of subclinical cardiovascular mechanisms that could link sedentary behavior to cardiovascular disease outcomes, this study has high potential impact to inform novel behavioral interventions that may reduce cardiovascular risk development among young women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in precision medicine are making it increasingly possible to tailor healthcare decisions based on the individual patient’s genomic risk profile. However, large-scale validation studies of risk prediction accuracy and its clinical utility are severely lacking in diverse populations. The goal of this eMERGE-IV project is to leverage genetic and electronic health record data for diverse populations to design, optimize, validate and test the clinical utility of ancestry-tailored polygenic risk scores for common diseases of high public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African trypanosomes are parasites that infect humans and cause the fatal blood-borne disease known as sleeping sickness. Parasite survival and its ability to infect humans depends on two key enzymes that modify the structural organization of DNA, thereby impacting gene regulation of the parasite. Our research will advance our mechanistic understanding of how these critical enzymes control essential biological processes in trypanosomes, potentially leading to the development of inhibitor drugs that can be used to treat and/or cure sleeping sickness and related diseases caused by tropical parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project will determine how mutation of a single ion channel gene causes absence epilepsy by remodeling ion channels that control thalamic cell firing properties. We will explore how a combination of two clinically silent ion channel mutations can summate to create a polygenic model as found in the human disorder, and determine whether it is possible to reverse this disorder by restoring the function of one mutant gene after the clinical appearance of seizures. These findings may lead to novel targets and a gene-guided treatments for childhood epilepsy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Digestive Health Center (DHC) is the Silvio O. Conte Digestive Disease Research Core Center in Cincinnati. The DHC advances research by the delivery of state-of-the-art services from Biomedical Cores, a dynamic Enrichment Program of scientific seminars and workshops, and a strong Pilot and Feasibility Program to foster growth of digestive disease research that is relevant to child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Despite the rapid progress in DNA sequencing, the overwhelming majority of our genome encodes proteins with little or no functional annotation such as the over 1000 proteins that make up the dynamic intracellular organelle, the mitochondria. We will use innovative genetic engineering methods to precisely mutate both mitochondrially encoded and vertebrate-specific nuclear-encoded mitochondrial genes for a rich array of biological, phenotypic and biochemical tests using the zebrafish in this highly collaborative and unique research program. This combination of novel technologies, annotation and genome science will establish scalable new genome science methods and generate important new functional information on the role of mitochondria in biology that, when compromised, underlies disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative SUDEP is a major cause of death in patients with epilepsy, and in many cases is thought to be due to postictal respiratory depression. Preliminary data support our hypothesis that seizures impair breathing by disrupting function of brainstem serotonin neurons that act as central CO2 chemoreceptors, and that dietary supplementation with milk whey decreases sudden death in epileptic mice by preventing this dysfunction. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of serotonin and chemoreception in SUDEP, and in the protective effect of milk whey, potentially offering a new avenue for preventative treatment of this common co-morbidity of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Vestibular dysfunction becomes more prevalent with age and contributes significantly to falls in the elderly, but underlying causes are poorly understood. We will study synaptopathy in the vestibular periphery using a combination of electrophysiological, immunohistochemical and behaviorial approaches. Identifying impairments of the vestibular signaling pathway in aging has important implications for developing new therapies for patients with vestibular dysfunction.

PHR: Project Narrative: How immature cells integrate cell lineage and external signaling information remains a central question in developmental neurobiology whose answers will impact our understanding of disease mechanisms in developmental disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE As the number of adults over 65 is expected to double by 2050, health systems must urgently seek ways to support the many older adults managing not just one but multiple chronic conditions, while contending with cognitive decline as the result of aging. Our LitCog IV study has the unique ability to elucidate potentially modifiable, causal mechanisms linking cognitive decline and impairment to worse health; with a particular focus on the optimal involvement of caregivers. Findings will directly guide the design of effective health system interventions to support the primary care management of a diverse, older patient population.

PHR: Projective Narrative: The goal of these studies is to understand how protein folding and other conformational changes are modulated by sequence variation and features in the cellular environment. Experiments are focused on the effect of the ribosome and co-translational protein folding, the effect of post- translational modifications and cellular complexes, and how kinetic barriers, such as those that control the lifetime of a folded protein, are encoded in the sequence and structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic neuropathy is a painful and debilitating condition that affects 50% of patients with diabetes, and for which limited effective treatments are available. There is increasing evidence that atypical sphingolipids may be contributing to the development of diabetic neuropathy, and that treatment with the amino acid L-serine may reduce the levels of these toxic lipids. The goal of the proposed studies is to determine which sphingolipid molecules are most relevant to diabetic neuropathy and could serve as potential treatment targets for this debilitating and currently untreatable diabetic complication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: This research project aims to use the genetically tractable Drosophila model to dissect analgesic signaling- dampening of nociceptive responses. Given the established conservation of genes required for both basic sensory neuronal functions and for nociception and nociceptive sensitization we expect that the findings from a genetic dissection of analgesia in this model will likely be relevant to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to use cutting-edge single-cell RNA sequencing, induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC), and CRISPR technologies to understand why certain brain regions, certain cell types, and some individual cells within a cell type degenerate earlier and to a great extent in late-onset Alzheimer’s Disease. The findings from this study could uncover novel avenues for the treatment and prevention of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Dietary sugar is a major risk factor for many non-communicable diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, how dietary sugar contributes to IBD pathogenesis and how the immune system regulates sugar homeostasis in the gut are poorly understood. This proposed study aims to investigate the role of dietary simple sugar glucose in IBD pathogenesis using animal models and explore an innate immune pathway that protects against intestinal inflammation via regulation of the glucose homeostasis in the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is to optimize lung cancer screening by selecting individuals for lung cancer screening based on their personal lung cancer risk, and by tailoring screening decisions and diagnostic management of pulmonary nodules to individuals. The anticipated findings of this project will provide individualized screening and diagnostic schedules that will enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of the overall screening program by integrating lung cancer risk and life expectancy. A personalized screening framework will be developed to formalize and facilitate the lung cancer screening decision-making process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lower urinary tract symptoms secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH/LUTS) is an extremely common set of conditions among older men, yet conventional pharmacological treatment strategies fail in preventing long-term clinical outcomes in about 30% of treated patients. This project seeks to evaluate the effectiveness of contemporary treatment strategies and use predictive modeling to determine which patients are likely to exhibit long-term BPH/LUTS progression. Given the considerable cost of BPH/LUTS management and impact on the general health and quality of life in older men, identification of effective and personalized pharmacological treatment strategies is critical.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VETERANS EDUCATION AND RESEARCH ASSOCIATION OF MICHIGAN
PHR: Public Health Relevance Falls in older adults are common, have high societal and monetary costs, often lead to injury and can even be fatal. It is known that noise can damage the vestibular periphery resulting in postural instability and compromised balance. This project will investigate how natural aging is accelerated by lifetime noise exposure, and how that can lead to impaired vestibular function, contributing to propensity to fall.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Chromosomal rearrangements are a primary form of human mutation that alters genome function in diseases such as cancer and inherited genetic syndromes. This project explores a series of contextual influences on the formation of chromosomal rearrangements through DNA double-strand break repair, including local sequences, genomic factors and metabolic signaling. Results will provide novel insights into how these cellular processes normally preserve the genome and how rearrangements result when they are perturbed by environmental or genetic factors.

PHR: Project Narrative The present research activity will expand upon recent studies that have shown that light at certain wavelengths and in adequate doses can temporarily block neural transmission of pain information, resulting in strong relief. Finally, the research will include development of prototype PBM systems and evaluation of those systems in a pre-clinical model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Mitigation of Radiation-Induced Immune Dysfunction by PrC-210 Treatment PROJECT NARRATIVE Human risk of radiation exposure, possibly catastrophic in proportion, has risen. Whether from intentional or unintentional nuclear events, such events could yield thousands to hundreds of thousands of surviving victims. A US government report stated, “the ideal medical countermeasures for radiation would be those that can both mitigate and protect from injuries.., such a countermeasure remains a significant unmet medical need.” The new, proprietary, PrC-210 radiation countermeasure, when administered once 24 hr post-radiation, confers a very large survival benefit against an LD95/30 radiation dose in mice. The goals of this U01 proposal are to i) determine the optimum +24 hr PrC-210 administration route and dose, and ii) determine the full extent to which PrC-210 mitigates damage to immune and gastrointestinal organ sites. These studies are proposed as a prelude to PrC-210 clinical trials.
