IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at substantially increased risk for long- term difficulties into adulthood, including academic underachievement, substance abuse, and criminal behavior. In our effort to improve these outcomes, we have worked on identifying highly-reliable motor measures that could be used to help better guide ADHD treatment, leading to the discovery of two brain- based measures that are abnormal in children with ADHD and, importantly, also predict the severity of ADHD behaviors. We aim to determine whether these two measures, performed with brief and safe Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS), are reliable and meaningful enough to be used to help improve precision of individually-targeted and effective ADHD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary arterial hypertension is a sex-biased disease, with no cure and nearly always lethal. Our recent studies indicated that female pulmonary artery endothelial cells have a higher proliferative potential compared to the male ones, due to augmented expression and activity of Xist, a nuclear factor responsible for inactivation of one of the chromosome X in females. This is significant, as understanding the female prevalence in pulmonary arterial hypertension could guide sex-specific diagnostic and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Training Program based in a large Division of Pediatric Rheumatology (PR) with several NIH center grants and NIH-funded investigators seeks to equip PR fellows with the investigative skills necessary to succeed in research careers. The research training activities will have two focus areas: (1) application of genomics, epigenetics, proteomics, and metabolomics to advance PR translational research, and (2) clinical epidemiology, development of clinical outcome assessment tool and clinical trial design. It is expected that this program will enlarge the number of PR researchers, a pool that is far too small to meet the requirements of the next decades as molecular medicine is increasingly applied in the clinic.

PHR: Project Narrative: The microbiome is composed of complex communities of bacteria that dynamically interact the each other and with their host. The goal of this proposal is to define the bacterial properties and gene-level mechanisms that promote IgA production throughout the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cachexia (CC) is a wasting syndrome characterized by anorexia, weight loss, and muscle and fat loss, which can be caused by cancer itself and often worsened by chemotherapy; current interventions for preventing or treating CC are suboptimal. 5’-adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase (AMPK), an intracellular energy sensor, plays a central role in skeletal muscle physiology by regulating mitochondria and it also shows anti-inflammatory effects; however, the function of AMPK in CC and its potential therapeutic role in preventing muscle wasting and weakness is unknown. The proposed study will characterize the role of AMPK in cancer- and chemotherapy-induced muscle wasting and dysfunction in vivo and in vitro and evaluate the potential for promoting AMPK activation as a therapeutic target for these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/ Public Health Relevance Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) are complex, multifactorial disorders characterized by impaired host- microbiome interactions that lead to chronic and relapsing intestinal inflammation with incompletely understood etiology For the first time, we demonstrate that poly-ADP-ribosylation (PARylation), a post-translational protein modification known to profoundly affect cellular functions in other systems, plays active role in the gut epithelial cell biology, host-microbiome interactions, and mucosal inflammatory responses. We seek to determine the interplay between commensal microbiota and mucosal PARylation, work that may lead to novel approaches to IBD care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis is a leading cause of death due to an infectious disease. Most cases occur in low and middle income countries where access to diagnostics such as culture may be limited to a few reference centers. FEND for TB will identify and assess inexpensive tests that are available at the point of care where the patients first are evaluated; once validated, these tests will enable more rapid identification and treatment of TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Women represent two-thirds of Alzheimer's disease (AD) cases in the US and the drivers of this health inequality remain inexplicable. What is clear, is that both menopause and DNA damage affect gene expression within pathways that influence tissue aging and metabolism, and hence likely AD. The impact of menopause on DNA damage and epigenetic responses has not been scrutinized in the context of AD. We will identify menopause- related impacts on AD-related networks, identifying druggable pathways or targets that may lead to sex-specific strategies for treating AD and identify potential biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to identify the contributions of social and dietary factors to kidney stone risk in racially and ethnically diverse populations. If successful, the proposed research will provide insight into the reasons for rising kidney stone prevalence in racial and ethnic minority groups and help develop more effective strategies for secondary prevention. The proposed research corresponds to NIDDK’s scientific goals to identify and characterize factors that affect human health in diverse populations; and to analyze the links between biology, behavior, and the environment, including social determinants of health and structural factors, that contribute to disease heterogeneity and health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Approximately 500,000 people in the U.S. suffer from cutaneous lupus lesions (CLE),with a significant impact on quality of life.4 Yet, there is no cure, the treatment options are limited, and no new drug has been FDA-approved for over 50 years.84 There is compelling preliminary data to support anandamide (AEA) as a promising drug candidate for CLE including in vitro work using tissue from human CLE patients and two in vivo murine studies demonstrating that AEA loaded into a novel topical silica-derived particle delivery system (AEA-ZP) significantly reduces the size and severity of lupus lesions as compared to controls, including unencapsulated AEA. The goal of this Phase I proposal is: (1) confirm efficacy of AEA-ZP in a newly developed murine model of lupus and assess preliminary toxicity; (2) identify biomarker profiles that may predict response to treatment with AEA-ZP; and (3) produce AEA-ZP prototypes with higher load factors and conduct stability testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent definitive clinical trials like CANTOS, LoDoCo2, and COLCOT, have proven the inflammatory hypothesis underlying atherosclerotic disease. They have also shown that targeting residual inflammatory risk, even in those patients currently on best standards of care, can have significant benefits in clinical outcomes. We are proposing a novel, first-in- class approach to target the early signaling events that lead to systemic inflammation in atherosclerosis, as a means to address residual inflammatory risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance As a result of population aging, many lower-income countries such as Nepal face a rapidly growing burden of dementia. This proposal represents a collaboration between the Institute for Social and Environmental Research in Nepal and the University of Michigan to develop a program of research capacity building and a population-based study to investigate the scope and primary determinants of dementia in Nepal. Findings from this program are expected to have substantial relevance for a better understanding of dementia risks and associated chronic health conditions in Nepal and other lower-income countries around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our proposed prospective research, focusing on examining the effectiveness of both a telehealth platform and an innovative treatment approach for parents and primary caregivers as well as frontline healthcare providers who are currently experiencing unprecedented levels of perceived stress during the COVID-19 pandemic, is expected to provide support to these highly vulnerable groups based in the Bronx who normally encounter significant barriers to basic care. If successful, the study has the potential to offset several of the negative social determinants of health typically encountered by members of these vulnerable communities. As such, the clinical implications of our proposed research are potentially profound.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will study the role of pipecolic acid in the etiology of cerebral malaria coma, a condition that contributes to worldwide morbidity and mortality and secondly, determine how it is produced by the malaria parasite. This research will contribute to fundamental knowledge underlying the loss of consciousness associated with cerebral malaria and potentially identify novel malaria metabolic pathways that could serve as a target of future antimalarial development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The severe acute respiratory syndrome and the long-term respiratory sequalae experienced by many coronavirus-19 patients have heightened the importance of breathing, bringing us closer to those suffering from respiratory diseases such as persistent dyspnea (constant breathing discomfort). When the primary treatment option (pulmonary rehabilitation) does not alleviate the symptoms of dyspnea, brain-targeted treatment alternatives resort to opioids and benzodiazepines which produce dependence, suppress ventilatory drive and contribute to hypercapnic respiratory failure. A better understanding of the cortical and subcortical mechanisms that modulate respiratory-related afferents to shape the subjective sensations of dyspnea will inform both, treatments that reduce dyspnea without reducing ventilatory drive and mechanisms underlying cortical control of respiration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Aging is a major risk factor for breast cancer and due to the aging of the U.S. population, the number of breast cancer survivors is expected to increase dramatically. Chemotherapy is a highly effective treatment for breast cancer but is associated with cardiovascular toxicity which may accelerate cardiovascular aging setting the stage for premature cardiovascular disease. The proposed research aims to build the evidence base for optimizing exercise prescription for cardiovascular disease prevention in breast cancer survivors by investigating two novel and innovative exercise regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Pulmonary infections like tuberculosis are more severe and occur more frequently in the elderly, so we propose studies in adults across an age continuum, with and without pulmonary tuberculosis. We anticipate that active tuberculosis may serve as a novel model of premature aging, and will serve for understanding the basis for the increase in lung oxidative stress and inflammation. Our findings will provide the foundation for the development of intervention(s) at defined younger ages to significantly mitigate aging-associated health decline.

PHR: Project Narrative Disruption of cerebellar development is associated with a broad spectrum of neurological disorders, ranging from ataxia to autism, and common pregnancy complications, such as preterm birth and intrauterine growth restriction. By identifying the mechanisms that regulate the development and scaling of neuronal populations in the cerebellum, our studies will provide a foundation for understanding cerebellar disorders and the development of regeneration therapies for the human cerebellum, which is frequently affected by both genetic and non-genetic factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections associated with metallic implants occur in 1-4% of primary total joint replacement and up to 30% of revisions. Current prophylactic local delivery of high-dose antibiotics is known for cytotoxicity and could risk the development of bacterial drug resistance while prolonged systemic antibiotic treatments are often ineffective in eradicating established infections. The proposed prophylactic metallic implant surface coating is designed to discourage bacterial colonization on implants while substantially improving the efficacy of a minimal safe dose of systemic antibiotic injection in rooting out implant associated infections. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance: The pathogenesis of Nephrotic Syndrome (NS) is not completely known, and the role of HLA in disease pathogenesis has not been probed with state of the art next generation sequencing. Our studies will define the precise roles of genetic variations in HLA genes in the development and clinical course of NS in a multiethnic cohort of patients with primary, secondary and post-transplant NS. Data generated from the study will provide new insights into the risk factors and underlying mechanisms of NS, provide insight into the molecular basis for variability in the clinical response to therapy and disease recurrence following kidney transplantation, permit tailored treatment (precision medicine), and identify novel therapeutic targets for future clinical trials in NS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Life-threatening and incurable autoimmune syndromes affect millions of Americans and are often associated with exaggerated B lymphocyte activation and differentiation, and generation of self-reactive antibodies, which cause pain and damage in various parts of the body. In this application, we propose to investigate a novel role for an unconventional myosin family protein in regulating B cell homeostasis and antibody production. Insights from our study will reveal novel molecular mechanisms that control B cell function to prevent autoimmunity.

PHR: NARRATIVE Our proposed global deep learning initiative unites international experts in artificial intelligence (AI), deep learning, psychiatry, and neuroimaging to discover brain signatures that predict which patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) will respond best to repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal we will investigate the stepwise cellular and genetic changes that control central nervous system development, regeneration and aging using a unique long-lived invertebrate model organism, Botryllus schlosseri, that reproduces both sexually as chordates and asexually as invertebrates and undergoes weekly degeneration and regeneration of its CNS during its adult life. Focusing on Botryllus brain cells we will characterize the genes and programs involved in the development of sexually produced larval brains, and asexually produced adult brains, isolate neural stem cells, and determine the difference between brain development and regeneration. Additional comparisons between the neural stem cells of young (< 6 months) and old (> 7 years) Botryllus colonies, will shed light on the process of neurodegeneration and neural stem cell aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Gastrointestinal toxicity often limits the amount of radiation that can be given to cancer patients. Our studies will determine how fasting protects small intestinal epithelial cells from high dose radiation therapy (RT) with the ultimate goal of mitigating deleterious side effects associated with RT so that dose escalation regimens can be employed for efficient tumor cell killing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPDD) is a common and painful form of arthritis with no specific or effective therapies. Genetic abnormalities in a protein called osteoprotegerin were recently discovered to cause familial forms of CPDD. In this proposal, we characterize a novel animal model carrying this mutation and explore the mechanisms through which osteoprotegerin mutations cause CPDD with the ultimate goal of developing new therapies for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Bicuspid aortic valve repair is an evolving surgical treatment for aortic regurgitation that preserves native valve tissue and circumvents risks and quality of life concerns associated with conventional aortic valve replacement in young adults. The proposed research develops new multimodal four-dimensional (three dimensional + time) image analysis technology that automatically identifies the patient-specific valve defects that cause aortic regurgitation and enables the surgeon to pre-operatively visualize the motion of the bicuspid aortic valve in order to plan a valve repair surgery. This technology could potentially reduce variability in bicuspid aortic valve repair planning across institutions and increase utilization of repair as an alternative to valve replacement in young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: FRONTIER SCI & TECHNOLOGY RSCH FDN, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Women living with HIV (WLWH) have a higher risk for acquisition, persistence, and progression of cervical human papillomavirus (HPV) to precancerous lesions, which, in the absence of effective screening and treatment services, can progress to invasive cancer at five-to-six times higher rates than in women without HIV. The overall goal of the HIV/Cervical Cancer Prevention `CASCADE' Clinical Trials Network is to conduct pragmatic clinical trials evaluating the effectiveness of clinically proven interventions to optimize the cervical cancer screening, management, and pre-cancer treatment cascade for WLWH. The CASCADE Coordinating Center will (i) provide overall network coordination and facilitate scientific review of network clinical trial concepts and protocols, (ii) provide centralized support for data management for network clinical trials, and (iii) conduct independent risk-appropriate auditing of network clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Inflammatory responses to stroke cause secondary neuronal damage, therefore dampening inflammation may lead to improved outcomes after stroke. The CD200- CD200R signaling axis has an important inhibitory role in post-stroke inflammation. This proposal will study the effects of CD200-CD200R signaling on peripheral immune cell mobilization, and will potentially identify new effective therapeutic targets for stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) affect 2-5% of the United States general population and up to 31% in some communities in South Africa; yet there is little known about the nutritional, genetic, or nutrigenetic risk factors that contribute to the susceptibility of an FASD diagnosis. This application proposes utilizing existing dysmorphology, neurobehavioral, biological (circulating nutrient concentrations) and genetic data from a population-based cohort to determine the independent maternal nutritional and nutrigenetic contributions to the susceptibility and severity of physical dysmorphology and neurodevelopmental abilities that constitute traits of FASD. This application will contribute an innovative understanding to the susceptibility of children regarding multiple physical and developmental traits associated with FASD and provide insight into future candidate gene studies and possible nutritional interventions to remediate the adverse effects of prenatal alcohol exposure in children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE The goal of this grant is to uncover the molecular mechanisms that mediate pathogenesis downstream of a large number of genes strongly implicated in Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). A leading hypothesis in the field is that ASD genes converge on common pathways, however the molecular details of this remains unknown. As such, a better understanding of the fundamental mechanisms shared between ASD genes, and how pathogenic variants alter these pathways could be expected to paradigm shifting. We anticipate this work will yield novel insights into how human genetic mutations are associated with ASD and whether there are common downstream perturbations between different ASD genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This research will provide empirical evidence on how racism and intersecting systems of oppression manifest at the individual and neighborhood levels to create structural adversity that, over the life-course, become psychologically and physiologically embedded and perpetuate racialized disparities in health. Specifically, we will innovatively utilize a racially and socioeconomically diverse cohort of midlife adults followed over the course of 30+ years beginning in childhood/early adolescence that will provide a broad array of social, psychosocial, and structural determinants of health captured repeatedly across the lifespan. This will be the first study to comprehensively determine the impact of structural adversity on stress regulation, accelerated aging, and mental health outcomes and will do so by linking these cohort data with (1) new survey and biospecimen data, (2) aggregated Census data to capture neighborhood ethnic-racial inequality, and (3) contextualized data from in-depth interviews eliciting narratives that will also capture the generational context of structural adversity, stress incurred, and ways of contending with racialized experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will uncover the distinct neuronal pathways through which dopamine drives both action-outcome and habit learning. Given that substance use disorders and other psychiatric diseases are characterized by ill-informed decisions that lack consideration of future consequences, resulting from disrupted action-outcome learning and maladaptive habits, in the longer term this work could lead to novel targets for treating pathological decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Socioeconomic and racial-ethnic inequalities in obesity are well documented in the literature and it is suggested that these disparities are due, to some extent, to inequalities in the built and natural environments and housing quality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Gammaherpesviruses permanently infect most of the adult population worldwide and are associated with B cell lymphomas. The risk factors that predispose towards the development of gammaherpesvirus-driven lymphomas are not well defined and there are no vaccines or curative antivirals available for the infection. This grant application focuses on a viral protein that is shared by all gammaherpesviruses and aims to define how this viral protein supports chronic infection with the goal of generating new viral and host therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes cold sores, genital sores, ocular infections, and encephalitis; can cause permanent ocular and brain damage and death in newborns; and is associated with neurodegeneration. This work will test the ability of maternal immunization and vector-delivered antibodies to protect newborns and adults from HSV-induced corneal diseases, behavioral pathologies, and neurodegeneration in a mouse model. We will also test the role of the autophagy pathway in the genesis of HSV-induced corneal disease, and whether autophagy- modulating agents can prevent or reduce ocular damage and other sequelae of HSV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In addition to its central purpose of human reproduction, pregnancy has a profound impact on the physiology and development of a woman's breast tissue. Importantly, the age of first pregnancy has a strong influence on milk supply and predisposition to breast cancer initiation, across several mammalian species. Thus, a major open question is what are the underlying mechanisms that link age of pregnancy to modify breast function? In this proposal we will use mouse and human model systems to address outstanding questions about the evolution and molecular adaptation of breast cells to aging and its effects on controlling development, gene expression and cancer initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Redox biology and medicine, the theme of this predoctoral training program at Wake Forest University for which funding is requested, denotes the specialized chemistry of oxidation and reduction occurring in biological systems which orchestrates metabolism and signaling to elicit specific cellular responses. Redox mechanisms support well-being and are also involved in the development and progression of many diseases. The goal of this training program is to bring scientists from diverse backgrounds and diverse programs such as chemistry, physics and molecular medicine together to train in the performance of interdisciplinary redox research to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  The goal of this study is to determine the role and therapeutic significance of polo-like kinase 4 (PLK4), an important regulator of cell division, alone and in combination with other promising target-based agents, for the management of melanoma, which is one of the most dangerous form of skin cancers. Our study may ultimately lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for clinical management of melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While effective at suppressing HIV replication, current antiretroviral treatments fail to eliminate the latent HIV reservoir, the vast majority of which persists within the gut. We propose to conduct an in-depth analysis of the gut reservoir in virally-suppressed men and women living with HIV, to test potent next-generation latency reversal agents for their ability to “shock” these cells out of latency, and to manipulate signaling pathways prominent in the gut to enhance immune-mediated clearance of reactivated gut cells. These studies will not only establish a much-needed better understanding of the gut reservoir and the mechanisms that facilitate their long-term persistence, but further tests the ability of promising and novel therapeutic approaches to eradicate this important reservoir.
PI_NAMEs: ARCHIN, NANCIE MARIE;ROAN, NADIA R (contact);SHEIKH, SHEHZAD Z.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a dominantly inherited autosomal disease with most common manifestation being the development of bilateral schwannomas of the 8th cranial nerve (Vestibular schwannoma). Although our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying NF2 has significantly improved over the past 2 decades, effective therapies remain lacking for this disease and there is an urgent need to develop therapeutic options for patients. Our goals in this proposal are to employ new screening technologies to identify and develop small-molecule inhibitors into leads for therapeutic development for NF2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Emerging evidence supports the association between periodontitis and Alzheimer’s disease (AD); however, the underlying mechanisms remain unknown. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overweight and obese women with gestational diabetes mellitus are at increased risk for perinatal complications. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will yield high-quality, detailed evidence regarding maternal glycemic control and adverse pregnancy outcomes. A better understanding of the optimal glycemic targets will have an important positive impact on our understating of how to care for overweight and obese women with gestational diabetes mellitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will study the mutual effect of amyloid-related brain injury and ischemic stroke on cerebrovascular recovery. Since dementia outcomes are a national health crisis, understanding the effects of elevated Aβ on vascular and neuronal dysfunction will provide insight into their synergistic effects on post-stroke recovery and cognitive decline. Elucidating the mechanism that drives dysfunction of the blood-brain barrier and neural progenitor cells may help us develop therapeutic strategies to reduce the burden of neurological disease in CAA, stroke, and even clinical Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is an adult-onset neurodegenerative disease that causes loss of cognitive function and death. There are no effective and long-term therapies for AD partly because of the failure to translate discoveries made in rodents to humans. To overcome this limitation, this proposal will optimize an approach to study mouse models of AD in a pathogen-rich environment and with a matured immune system to accelerate basic and translational research to treat the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The social, economic, and healthcare disruption during the COVID-19 pandemic amplified the vulnerability of people with existing and at risk of developing OUD, leading to the highest overdose death toll since 2017. The rationale for the proposed research is that once we understand how the COVID-19 pandemic altered social, economic, and healthcare systems, we can design more effective interventions for people with opioid use disorder. This research will be essential for informing optimal policy responses (now and in the future) and will align with the NIH NIDA’s goal to understand the economic and clinical impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on individuals, families, and communities with existing/at-risk of opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to establish novel strategies and synthetic approaches to advance and enrich gold catalysis and, more importantly, provide methodologies for biological and medicinal related target, which are otherwise very difficult to acquire due to their scarcity, structural complexity, and high cost. This research will also open new avenues toward collections of structurally novel small molecules that enable the construction of chemical libraries for lead compound identification, optimization processes for health and medicinal related chemical production, initiation of new building blocks as biological probes and novel therapeutics. The strategies and methodologies developed in this research will significantly enrich the toolbox of both synthetic chemists and medicinal chemists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will quantify how racial disparities in colorectal cancer survival are produced by racial differences in tumor characteristics, measured by gene-expression molecular subtypes, driver genes, and clinicopathologic factors. We will conduct the first large molecular epidemiologic study to compare survival outcomes of non-Hispanic African Americans to non-Hispanic whites using tumor data measured at the transcriptomic-, genomic- and pathologic-level. The study results will inform future clinical studies of targeted therapeutics and provide the foundation to reduce the racial disparity in survival experienced by African Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: As the number of older adults increases, many older adults live with conditions that profoundly impact their health, well-being, and ability to maintain independence. Artificial Intelligence offers an unprecedented opportunity to mitigate the impact of aging, to arm health care providers with new tools and to empower older adults including those with Alzheimer’s Dementia and their caregivers. The Johns Hopkins AI and Technology Collaboratory ecosystem will serve as a national resource to promote and guide the development and implementation of novel AI and technology approaches to improve care and health outcomes for older Americans.

PHR: Project Narrative Candida lusitaniae is an opportunistic fungal pathogen known for its development of antibiotic resistance, that is a close relative to the multi-drug resistant pathogen Candida auris that is associated with hospital outbreaks. ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative There is a pressing need for new vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV2, the cause of COVID-19, which requires both animal models that reproduce COVID-19 disease signs and an understanding of the factors that drive susceptibility to virus-induced disease. Therefore, we will use the Collaborative Cross (CC) to develop improved mouse models of COVID-19 disease, while also identifying polymorphic host genes that drive susceptibility to nCoV2-induced disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Indeterminate mass lesions are present on over 1% of brain MRIs in individuals over 45 years old, and misinterpretation of brain MRI can lead to significant iatrogenic morbidity and mortality. To prevent iatrogenic morbidity, there is a critical need for scalable and reproducible methods to distinguish indeterminate brain lesions from each other, and to accurately diagnose brain tumors prior to biopsy. We hypothesize that both germline genotyping and MRI-based machine learning provide an opportunity to diagnose indeterminate mass lesions as well as predict glioma molecular subtype prior to surgery and thus personalized treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are an estimated 7 million stroke survivors living in the United States. More than two-thirds of these have residual paralysis of the upper limb, and of them, ~37%-50% have severe paralysis. There are few treatment options that are appropriate or effective for patients with severe paresis. Here, we will test whether the combination of a unique rehabilitation therapy that is easy to administer in patients with little to residual motion and a new brain stimulation technique that taps into intact neural resources would produce higher gains in upper limb function than those that can be achieved with conventional treatment in patients with severe paralysis. ! !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to analyze the role of the Plant Homeodomain 6 gene in hematopoietic stem cell aging using a combination of cellular and animal models. Our integrative approach brings together cellular and molecular assays profiling cell intrinsic and cell extrinsic mechanisms implicated in hematopoietic stem cell self-renewal and function with the goal of elucidating the specific mechanisms implicated in enhanced hematopoietic stem cell function with the abrogation of aging phenotypes in Phf6 knockout stem and progenitor cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child maltreatment is known to have pervasive effects on both short- and long-term physical and mental health. The proposed work will identify whether perturbation in the stress system in adolescence links maltreatment with disease risk in young adulthood and identify moderators that may hinder or promote potential HPA axis resilience. Findings will provide the first evidence demonstrating whether recalibration of the HPA axis in adolescence can mitigate the effects of early trauma on disease risk in young adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic hepatitis B remains a significant public health burden affecting approximately 257 million individuals worldwide, who suffer from a high risk of developing cirrhosis and liver cancer. HBV infection is maintained by a persistent viral genome called cccDNA, which could not be eradicated by currently approved drugs. We propose in this application to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of cccDNA formation, which will aid the development of novel therapeutics to cure HBV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Hemodialysis treatment non-adherence is an important modifiable contributor in end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), with critical public health relevance to patients, providers, and health systems due to its association with excessive hospitalizations, exorbitant financial burden, and increased morbidity and mortality. Compared to Whites, African American ESKD patients have a four-fold higher ESKD prevalence, persistently higher hospitalization and rehospitalization risk, and higher rates of dialysis treatment non-adherence. The goals of this proposal are to evaluate the efficacy of culturally tailored motivational interviewing on improving hemodialysis treatment adherence in African Americans ; 2) provide a strong basis for conducting a future effectiveness and implementation trial using evidence-based, culturally tailored motivational interviewing intervention to improve hemodialysis adherence, and reduce hospitalizations, morbidity, mortality, and exorbitant financial burden associated with dialysis treatment non-adherence; and 3) promote health equity by reducing existing health disparities and optimizing outcomes in ESKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dementia is a leading cause of death in the United States, and disproportionately impacts individuals with less education and income. This proposal evaluates socioeconomic interventions that increased years of education (Aim 1) and income security (Aim 2) to determine if such interventions impacted dementia risk overall, and whether structurally minoritized groups (Black Americans, individuals from low childhood SES backgrounds, and people who grew up in rural areas or the South) differentially benefited (Aim 3). We hypothesize that these interventions reduced dementia risk overall, and that structurally minoritized groups benefitted more resulting in smaller socioeconomic, racial, and geographic disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE The advent of successful gene therapy for certain retinal disorders and our extensive knowledge of the dozens of genes involved in hereditary hearing loss, together raise hope that gene therapy can be used to treat genetic forms of hearing loss. For instance mutations in the PCDH15 gene cause Usher syndrome type 1F, a devastating deafness, blindness and balance disorder. While we and others have achieved success in mouse models using gene therapy for short genes that will fit in adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors, PCDH15 is a long gene that does not fit into AAV; thus we propose to engineer short “mini-PCDH15” proteins, to test rescue of hearing and balance in mice, and to test localization and toxicity in nonhuman primates. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The project will create a comprehensive educational training program on the best practices for successfully navigating the translational pathway for neural medical devices. Our program will provide (1) virtual ‘sprints’ through a series of freely-available video lectures with topical exercises and round-table discussions and (2) three-day workshops with program faculty that will provide participants with hands-on exercises designed around relevant case studies and participant interests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pediatric in-hospital cardiac arrest is associated with extremely high morbidity and mortality and is estimated to affect at least 6,000 children per year. In an effort to prevent cardiac arrest in the pediatric intensive care unit, physicians have adopted the practice of administering small doses of epinephrine to reverse acute hypotension; however, little is known about the efficacy, safety or optimal dosing associated with this practice. To better characterize the use of peri-arrest epinephrine, we propose a prospective, randomized, dose-effect trial in patients with acute profound hypotension in the pediatric intensive care unit which may ultimately lead to saving lives and decreasing disability in pediatric patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The very preterm neonate is at risk for a discrete set of medical complications due to their unique physiology and vulnerability. Our ability to predict those who will experience life-changing complications is extremely limited. Our work will identify biologic compounds (i.e., metabolic biomarkers) that will improve diagnostics, lead to more effective therapeutic agents, and create a precision approach to the clinical management of this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The laboratory mouse is an important model system for investigating the genetics and biological principles of cancer and as a preclinical platform for testing new therapeutic approaches to treating cancer in humans. The Mouse Models of Human Cancer database (MMHCdb) is a unique compendium of expertly curated knowledge about diverse mouse strains that model human cancer. The data and analysis tools provided by MMHCdb are designed to help researchers realize the translational potential of mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative / Public Health Relevance  The southern US remains heavily burdened and disproportionately affected by HIV transmission, acute and chronic HCV, and the opioid epidemic. Applying the proposed epidemiologic modeling methods to harmonized individual and contextual data from multiple surveillance systems and creating platforms for sharing these “big data” and analyses will enhance the understanding of HIV epidemiology in the region, elucidate differences between rural and urban settings, and improve targeting of HIV and HCV prevention activities. This research will be novel and high-impact, generating evidence to inform and strengthen programs and policies to tackle HIV/HCV transmission and opioid fatalities across the South and nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE: Many important bacterial pathogens such as Salmonella, Yersinia, Shigella, E. coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Burkhodleria spp., Chlamydia spp., and Bordetella pertussis possess specialized nanomachine known as the type III protein secretion system, which is essential for their ability to cause disease. This machine “injects” bacterial proteins into the cells of the host to alter cellular functions for the pathogen’s benefit. This project intends to study how this nanomachine works. The understanding of the mechanisms by which the type III secretion nanomachine works can lead to the development of broadly active anti infective strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative COPD is the third leading cause of death in older Americans, and older adults with COPD rarely receive proactive geriatrics-palliative care before the end of life. This study will refine and pilot test a telehealth, palliative nurse coach-led geriatrics-palliative care intervention for older adults with COPD and their family caregivers. The results will support a fully-powered randomized controlled trial that will seek to improve the health and well-being of older adults with COPD and their family caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project we will determine the role of reprogramming of tumor microenvironment (TME) by p38 MAPK inhibition to promote a robust dendritic cell-driving antitumor immunity to prevent acquired resistance in adoptive cell therapy. We propose to use the clinically tested p38 inhibitor, Ralimetinib, to divert the immunosuppressive TME by combining it with CAR T cells, which enhance tumor antigen presentation, provoke type I IFN signatures in TME and hence eliminates resistant tumor cells to prevent the acquired resistance. This study may thus uncover a novel mechanism for preventing tumor relapse in cancer immunotherapy. Data from our proposed Aims may yield critically needed evidence that repurposing the clinically tested Ralimetinib from targeting p38 MAPK in tumor cells toward that of immune cells may induce a complete and durable response in adoptive cell therapy. This translationally relevant work could then lay the foundation for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Animals can utilize two distinct types decision making strategies: i) a “model-free” strategy that relies fully on past experiences to guide future choices, and ii) a “model-based” strategy that employs a learned model of the world to infer structure about their environment and make predictions about the future. This project aims to uncover how we initially learn models of the world in order to make model-based decisions, how such an internal model is stored and used in the brain, and how an initially poorly learned model can be improved through tailored training. Understanding the neural mechanisms that underpin learning models is a basic scientific question that can lead to improved treatments for neuropsychiatric disorders that produce aberrant decision making, such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the mechanisms that enable pancreatic cancer to progress unimpeded by the immune system would inform on the complex biology of this intractable disease and help to identify potential strategies for therapeutic intervention. The studies proposed here will test the novel hypothesis that fatty acid signaling within pancreatic cancer cells controls expression of genes whose products signal to the surrounding microenvironment and suppress immune-mediated tumor growth control. Together, these studies will help us understand the mechanistic basis of growth-permissive tumor-stromal interactions in the pancreatic tumor microenvironment, and may identify novel, druggable targets to help achieve therapeutic benefit in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) eventually die when their disease becomes resistant to conventional or even newer treatments, some of which include an inhibitor of FLT3, called gilteritinib, and an inhibitor of BCL2, called venetoclax. We are testing novel therapeutic combinations involving these drugs, and our proposed studies will employ expansive proteogenomic studies to define biomarkers that can be used to predict and detect resistance to these drug combinations. The ultimate goal will be to deliver better therapies and outcomes for patients with AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposes to investigate how long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs), a diverse class of RNAs with poorly understood functions, contribute to the pathogenesis of cancer, a leading cause of death in the United States. In particular, we will study the role of lncRNAs in renal cell carcinoma (RCC), a deadly malignancy with limited effective treatment options. A better understanding of noncoding RNAs could enable the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Cognitive impairments in Schizophrenia (SCZ) have been linked to abnormalities in specific sleep oscillations—sleep spindles and slow waves—, in multiple studies, although most of the evidence is in chronic patients. As first steps towards translating these observations into novel interventions, we aim to demonstrate that: 1) spindle and slow wave deficits are present alongside impairments in cognition in early course patients (EC-SCZ); 2) sleep and cognitive defects are associated with one another; 3) spindles and slow waves can be manipulated and acutely enhanced through closed-loop auditory stimulation (CLAS) during sleep in EC-SCZ patients; and 4) CLAS-related changes in sleep oscillations are associated with cognitive changes in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Advanced age is the greatest risk factor for the onset and progression of Alzheimer's disease and for the lethality of viral infections, most recently SARS-CoV-2. We are using the powerful genetics of the nematode C. elegans to better understand the biological mechanisms of aging and to discover novel therapeutic targets to counteract age-related human diseases, including Alzheimer's disease and ADRD protein aggregation diseases, and responses to viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian respiratory system undergoes cyclical mechanical strain as part of its normal function. We hypothesize that the lung has evolved specific epigenetic and transcriptional mechanisms to maintain cellular fate in the face of mechanical strain from normal respiration and these pathways are altered in the response to injury and disease. In this proposal, we aim to address key unanswered questions in cell fate regulation in lung development and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The computational methodologies we develop will be applicable to a broad range of conformational changes of RNA polymerases with biomedical relevance. In particular, oxidative DNA lesions cause transcriptional mutagenesis of RNA Polymerase II that contributes to tumor growth in skin cancer, and mechanistic insights from this work will help uncover a route to address the adverse effects of these DNA lesions. In addition, antibiotics against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) often target the dynamic motion of its RNA polymerase, and this work will provide mechanistic insights to facilitate the rational design of new antibiotics fighting drug resistance of Mtb.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Changing the course of the HIV-1 pandemic requires an effective HIV-1 vaccine that most probably will have to elicit antibodies against HIV-1 envelope glycoproteins (Envs). Here we will study differences and similarities in the shape of Envs from different HIV-1 strains and build a mechanistic model for how these differences evolve and generated in vivo, and what is required to recognize the diverse shapes of HIV-1 Envs. Our study will provide insights into the biology of HIV-1 entry and lay a new groupwork for understanding HIV Env function & inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The intestinal epithelium is a rapidly regenerating tissue that relies actively cycling intestinal stem cells (ISCs) to support tissue renewal. Here we explore the central hypothesis that extrinsic niche changes contribute to functional impairment in ISCs during aging. Through our studies, we aim to improve our understanding of stem cell niche factors and how to mobilize ISCs for tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative.  Fragile X syndrome (FX) is associated with deficits in social and spatial behaviors, yet the neural mechanisms responsible for these impairments remain poorly understood. Hippocampal areas CA2 and CA1 are key brain regions for sociality and spatial memory, respectively. In this project, we aim to uncover neurophysiological disturbances in CA2 and CA1 that may underlie impaired social and spatial cognition in FX and may point toward new symptom-specific treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance and depressive symptoms are conditions that are interdependent, particularly, in the elderly (> 70 years). A low glycemic index (GI) diet and exercise (D+E) program increases insulin sensitivity in older adults with obesity, but the effect on apathy in depression is unknown. This carefully designed series of specific aims will determine: 1) whether a low GI diet D+E program reduces apathy in the elderly; 2) whether the reduction in apathy is mediated by changes in insulin sensitivity; and 3) the potential of a novel low GI D+E intervention using whole soybean pods to promote sustainability of the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Radiation therapy has become an increasingly effective liver cancer treatment technique, especially after the introduction of stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT), which can deliver large and focused radiation doses to liver tumors to achieve superior tumor control and survival. However, current clinical practices usually treat a volume much larger than the actual tumor (with treatment margins up to 15 mm beyond the tumor boundary) to account for the uncertainties in liver tumor localization. Successful completion of the proposed work will generate a contrast-agent-free and non-invasive x-ray imaging technique for accurate 4D liver tumor localization, which will lead to substantial treatment volume/margin reduction to boost the safety, viability and efficacy of SBRT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL—PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Human aging is influenced by genetic factors, whereby differences in longevity as well as changes in health and disease risk with time are linked to variation in individuals' genetic codes. The Jackson Laboratory Nathan Shock Center will develop resources to encourage the use of a wider range of mouse models in aging research. Resources—including aged mouse models that mirror human genetic variation, metabolic and microbiome data, and methods to reveal genetic factors tied to human aging—will be available to the scientific community, accelerating research to understand and ultimately prolong healthy human aging.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this R01 application is to understand the role of RIPK2, a key initiator and propagator of inflammatory signaling, in clinically relevant animal models of ischemic stroke. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will help understand the potential therapeutic value of RIPK2 inhibitors to reduce brain damage and improve neurological recovery following stroke. This proposal is relevant to the NINDS's mission that pertains to developing significant knowledge in basic research that will create the foundation for treating ischemic stroke and reducing the burden of this neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper biliary epithelial cell (BEC) specification is essential as it allows intrahepatic bile duct formation and proper liver function. This proposal will establish a deep functional understanding of how the transcription factor Sox9 regulates: (1) BEC specification during development and (2) BEC expansion following liver damage. Our studies will define the requirement of Sox9 in establishing proper intrahepatic BEC networks during development and ductular reaction which will help develop an understanding of basic mechanisms of liver repair that can be used to identify novel targets for therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to identify molecular targets that can be exploited to repair the blood-brain barrier after seizure-induced neuroinflammation and dysfunction. This therapeutic strategy is expected to improve seizure control in patients with epilepsy. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH/NINDS mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of neurological disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using powerful technologies, we will comprehensively study the impact of maternal obesity and health on breastfeeding and the composition of human milk, and how they affect child growth and health. This project is enabled by using samples and data from ongoing birth cohorts including 1,615 Cincinnati mother-infant pairs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the thousands of chemicals used in commerce, our understanding of their effects on human health is not well understood. The Comparative Toxicogenomics Database (CTD) is a unique, publicly available resource that provides information about human exposures and how these exposures influence our genes, our biology, and ultimately our health. This project will build on our established infrastructure to expand the data content and analysis capacity of CTD to provide new insights into the complex relationship between our environment and human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause severe and long-lasting neurological disease, with an initial infection in the hippocampus resulting in some of the neuropathology and neuroinflammation seen in Alzheimer's disease (AD). In this proposal, we will test the hypotheses that prior exposure to the WNV worsen AD-related behavioral alterations, cognitive injury, neuropathology, and that these effects are apolipoprotein E isoform-dependent and are associated with neuroinflammation. The generated results will facilitate the identification of novel biomarkers and targets for novel therapeutic strategies for AD and other age-related neurodegenerative disorders, including those of mixed etiology dementias (MED).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Enhancing healthy lifespan is one of the key challenges of the 21st century. Metformin is an anti-diabetic drug proposed to be a candidate therapy to target aging in humans, and we identified metformin-mimetic peptide drug candidates and will test if they are involved in the anti-aging effects of metformin, which in turn can potentially help define individuals that will respond to metformin and possibly serve as alternative healthspan-enhancing treatments. Our studies will define a completely novel direction in understanding the actions of metformin on delaying aging, and will establish novel biomarkers as well as complementary/alternative anti-aging approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE This application is focused on understanding the role that lipids play in regulating adipose senescence. The studies address how immune cells affect adipocytes lipolysis and how fatty acids regulate SIRT1 and oxidative stress. Oxidative stress in turn produces reactive lipids that induce senescence in preadipocytes. The work will establish that intracellular fatty acids, particularly monounsaturated fatty acids, are potential bioregulators of senescence and represent an untapped therapeutic opportunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults experience a loss of mobility that leads to disability, which is a serious health care issue in an aging US population. Mitochondrial respiration is a key property of skeletal muscle that supports walking speed, physical function and fitness in older adults. The primary goal of this project is to explore the role of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in age related changes in muscle oxidative capacity and physical function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of function mutations in RBFOX2 gene are identified in infants with hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Our goals are to determine how loss of RBFOX2 function leads to cardiovascular developmental defects observed in hypoplastic left heart syndrome patients. Our findings are expected to pave the way for novel therapies to restore RBFOX2 function in hypoplastic left heart syndrome patients in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Under the HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) Act, kidneys from donors with HIV can be used for transplant in recipients with HIV. Early studies of this practice demonstrate excellent short-term patient survival and survival of the transplanted organ; however, kidney rejection rates were high and long-term outcomes are unknown. This research will compare HIV+ and HIV- donor kidney transplant in HIV+ recipients in order to determine 1) the impact of HIV+ donor kidneys on rejection and 2) long term outcomes, and also includes scientific studies designed to improve our understanding of rejection in people with HIV and the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE Anxiety and depression are leading mental illnesses often linked to stress and systemic immune state by unknown mechanisms. Here, we will study the effects of gastrointestinal inflammation and stress by modeling these inputs separately and in combination in mice and comprehensively examining their effects on behavior and brain reward/aversion circuitry function. We will also study a novel underlying signal transduction pathway as a critical mechanism mediating this comorbidity and test a number of interventions to rescue the maladaptive effects of inflammation and stress, possibly providing a path to therapeutic interventions.

PHR: We examine the contribution of dopaminergic neurotransmission, dopaminergic networks' activity, and brain energy metabolism, to physical performance fatigability in older adults. We propose these neuro-energetic markers, individually and in combination, may explain fatigability beyond what is predicted by skeletal muscle energetics and cardiopulmonary function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is associated with increased risk of slow and/or incomplete healing of a bone injury. The reasons why are incompletely understood, and there are presently no treatments that directly address this problem. This project focuses on modulating the mechanical stimuli present at the injury site, identifying the effects of these changes on bone tissue formation by young and aged cells, and using this knowledge to determine ways of overcoming the aging-associated deficits in bone healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative To advance scientific discoveries toward improved human health and societal well-being, the Scripps Research K12 Scholars Program will educate and train early-career researchers in the newest translational methods for evaluating promising findings in preclinical studies, clinical trials, and community-engaged implementation. Using our Translational Institute’s strengths of genomics, digital medicine, informatics, and community engagement, with new initiatives in data science and population health, our program will mentor the methods that accelerate new innovations across the translational spectrum to increase access for all people. Our program will expand the biomedical researcher workforce with graduates experienced in cross-disciplinary teamwork, inter-institutional public-private partnerships, open communication, inclusive research standards, and resource-sharing approaches – skills and characteristics that drive investigational breakthroughs toward greater public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  These investigations will clarify the mechanisms responsible for Hajdu Cheney Syndrome, a rare but devastating disease characterized by craniofacial manifestations, lysis of the distal phalanges and bone loss with fractures. The proposed work will serve to establish the function of an important Notch target gene that is responsible for the manifestations of the syndrome. In addition, the work proposed will target the mutation in models of human disease, as a means to treat and cure a rare but devastating clinical disorder. The work will form the basis for treating other genetic disorders affecting the skeleton.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative BK polyomavirus reactivation in kidney transplant patients results in graft loss for 10% of patients. The goal of this project is to apply our understanding of host pathways that are required by BKPyV for viral production in human primary kidney cells to determine if these can be exploited as antiviral targets. Identification of effective BKPyV antivirals the potential to treat this devastating viral reactivation without reducing immunosuppression in kidney transplant patients, which increases the risk of graft loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Advanced age is associated with increased incidence of pressure ulcers. Our preliminary data suggests that hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1α) is dysregulated with aging, and that stabilization of HIF-1α using an FDA approved molecule (deferoxamine, DFO) heals pressure ulcers in small animal models. Here we will confirm aberrant HIF-1α signaling in aged skin and pressure ulcer biopsy specimen from human patients, and test transdermal delivery of DFO (DFO-TDDS) to treat pressure ulcers using a human-like porcine pressure ulcer model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is an increase in cardiovascular disease with age, stemming from the fact that as blood vessels age, they become more calcified and stiff. Over time, these changes impair critical organ function (e.g. brain, heart, and kidneys). The aim of this research is to understand how proteins called ectonucleotidases, which reduce inflammation and the tendency for clot formation, influence how blood vessels age. Gaining this knowledge will hone future strategies to treat vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Apolipoprotein E4 (APOE4), the greatest genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD), confers a pro- inflammatory state in the normal aging and AD brain parenchyma, but its functions in brain border immunity are still unknown. Here we propose to apply single-cell multi-omics profiling of ex vivo human border cells and in vitro border cell modeling to investigate APOE4's effect on border cell states and function in normal aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to determine the role of cellular senescence and epigenetic modifications in primordial follicle exhaustion, and thus ovarian failure. We will study the emergence of these age-related hallmarks in a cell-type specific manner at different time points throughout the reproductive lifespan of mice; which will allow us to determine the chronological order in which these changes occur in different cells in the ovary. We will also determine if the removal of senescent-like cells and/or their inflammatory phenotype will extend reproductive lifespan, which is currently the overall goal of reproductive research throughout the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative For both SARS-CoV-2 and influenza the difficulty of inducing long-lasting immunity that can protect against evolving viruses continues to complicate vaccine design. My proposed research will provide a functional assay to evaluate seasonal CoV immunity, characterize of the diversity of influenza mutations after a controlled human infection, and develop a protocol for a seasonal CoV controlled human infection model. These tools are necessary to advance the development of a controlled human infection model with the seasonal CoV OC43, which will provide an efficient mechanism to evaluate broadly protective CoV countermeasures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) Chronic pain is a critical public health problem that affects over 100 million people in the United States and is the leading cause of years lived with disability. Yet, most common chronic pain treatments fail to significantly and reliably relieve pain and improve physical and psychological functioning for many people. Thus, the proposed project will develop and test a novel multicomponent breathwork intervention in people with chronic low back pain, which will inform future work investigating whether this intervention is an effective treatment for chronic pain that also has the potential to improve emotional well-being and whole person health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Merkel cells constitute a rare population of skin cells that are specialized to perceive gentle touch responses. As we age, our skin gradually loses Merkel cells and its sense of touch and this deficit is a major factor for determining quality of life and the ability to live independently for the elderly; however, the cellular and genetic factors responsible for age-related loss of Merkel cells are largely unknown. If proven, our application will unlock how stem cells in our skin maintain the Merkel cell lineage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is one of the most aggressive subtypes of breast cancer and management of this cancer is challenging because it does not respond well to most of the FDA-approved breast cancer drugs. The goal of this study is to develop targeted, tumor-penetrating nanoparticles to more effectively deliver chemotherapeutics to TNBC tumors and metastases. The proposed studies may in the long term have high clinical impact with respect to our current treatment options for TNBC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance This project addresses an issue of direct public health relevance, the findings of which will be broadly applicable to populations around the world. Altered immune function, leading to decreased vaccine responses or increased respiratory infection, is a serious global public health concern. This project will advance our understanding of how ubiquitous environmental exposures, such as polychlorinated biphenyls, affect these outcomes, moving us closer to effective primary prevention strategies to further reduce the burden of infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Although more Latinx are going to college, <10% earn degrees in the sciences. Improved STEM skill-sets that include environmental health literacy can help students learn how to solve environmental challenges and enter an expanding science-based labor sector. With the Monterey Bay Aquarium, CHAMACOS, community art partners, and the Monterey County Office of Education, we aim to improve local environmental health literacy in schools serving predominantly Latinx youth in the low-income agricultural Salinas Valley. We will integrate environmental health literacy into NGSS-aligned teacher training programs addressing ocean plastics, climate change, and agriculture; develop student-driven action projects infused with the arts and research experiments; evaluate the impacts of these training programs on student knowledge; and work with youth to develop art productions to bring environmental health literacy education to wider audiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Endocrine disorders such as diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemias, thyroid disease and polycystic ovarian syndrome are all associated with enormous costs; both with respect to their morbidity and mortality and their burden on the health care system. This proposal aims to provide resources that train young investigators at the MD or PhD level who will play a key role in extending our understanding of basic metabolic processes at the subcellular, cellular, organ and system level. Moreover, translating these new insights into both mechanistic and translational advances for disorders related to metabolic dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative There is an urgent need to evaluate whether new proposed presymptomatic Alzheimer's disease (AD) treatments are efﬁcacious in preventing cognitive decline. Current clinical endpoints, such as cognitive scores, are too noisy to access the cognitive decline after an intervention; however, neuroimaging can generate better biomarkers to monitor cognitive decline. We aim to develop a machine learning framework to extract useful biomarkers from neuroimaging data to predict cognitive decline, which then can be used as endpoints to evaluate presymptomatic AD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Haye, Joanna, Elizabeth Project Narrative: DNA mismatch repair is a highly conserved process that functions to protect the integrity of the genome from prokaryotes to eukaryotes. In humans, defects in MMR results in Lynch syndrome, a cancer syndrome that results in colon and other types of cancers. The proposed project aims to provide further understanding of how MMR proteins are regulated and recruited to DNA, using the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Studies show that virtually all increases in children’s (5-12yrs) BMI occur during the summer, no matter children’s’ weight status (ie, normal weight, overweight, or obese) at summer entry. Recent preliminary studies show that children engage in healthier behaviors on days that they attend summer day camps, and that BMI gain does not accelerate for these children. The proposed randomized dose-response study will identify the dose-response relationship between amount of summer programming and summer BMI gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The central dogma lies at the heart of gene regulation, but the coordinated dynamics of single- gene transcription and single-mRNA translation have yet to be visualized in living cells. This has made it difficult to measure the relative contributions of transcription and translation in complex gene networks that are deregulated in human disease. To address this shortcoming, we will develop and apply technology to image in up to four colors the full central dogma with single molecule resolution in living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The next generation high-resolution high-performance neurometabolic imaging techniques as established in this project will enable quantitative and whole-brain imaging of key metabolic rates and other important neurophysiological parameters associated with major energy metabolism pathways in healthy and diseased human brain on an FDA-approved 7 Tesla clinical MRI scanner. The success of this project will provide translatable neuroimaging tools that can be applied in a wide range of biomedical, neuroscience and clinical research for assessing human brain energetic status and its changes. New insights from these areas of research are invaluable for understanding the energetic mechanisms of neurological disorders and ultimately improving our ability to diagnose, monitor progression, and assess the effects of treatments for brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to fill a key knowledge gap by conducting an unprecedented evaluation of the molecular landscape of the tumor and tumor microenvironment in a large sample of Alaska Native colorectal cancer (CRC) patients using cutting-edge molecular profiling technologies. Results from this project will improve our understanding of CRC tumorigenesis, molecular subtypes, and clinically actionable mutational, genetic, and immune-related features in the Alaska Native people who experience the highest CRC incidence and mortality rates worldwide. Insights gained through this work may inform the development of novel therapeutic strategies, may result in clinically useful predictors of CRC-specific death that can be used to guide clinical decision making, and, ultimately, decrease mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the choroid plexus has been implicated in neurodevelopment and a range of brain disorders. Evidence demonstrates that the choroid plexus is critical for brain maturation, immune/inflammatory regulation, and behavioral/cognitive functioning, however current neuroimaging segmentation tools are poor at accurately and reliably segmenting the choroid plexus. The proposed studies will utilize large patient cohorts (n=22,000+) from high resolution (Human Connectome Project and Connectome Related Human Disease) and conventional (inclusive of high risk for psychosis, first episode and chronic psychosis, bipolar disorder, and Alzheimer’s disease) neuroimaging datasets to develop an open- source deep learning choroid plexus segmentation method that will be used to elucidate changes in the choroid plexus across the lifespan and within various brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This project will use data from two prospective cohorts to examine whether nutrients modify the relationship between prenatal air pollution exposure and autism spectrum disorder (ASD)-related outcomes. We will examine joint effects of individual nutrients (prenatal folate, polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), and vitamin D), as well as broader diet, with particulate matter (PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and ozone exposures in association with risk of quantitative ASD-related traits as well as ASD diagnosis, and will consider potential critical time windows for these interactions. Because diet is a readily accessible, individual-level modifiable factor, this line of research presents the potential for a large public health impact.
