PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because ascending thoracic aortic aneurysms and dissections are frequent causes of death in the United States, largely because current medications are ineffective. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer draining lymph nodes are important for the generation and maintenance of anti-cancer immune responses. However, the presence of metastatic cancer cells in these lymph nodes inhibits immune responses and the efficacy of new therapies intended to boost anti-cancer immunity. In the proposed work, we will identify and overcome the mechanisms of immune suppression in metastatic lymph nodes to improve therapeutic outcomes for patients with metastatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In sickle cell disease (SCD), red blood cell-derived extracellular vesicles (REVs) are at elevated concentrations, and are capable of independently initiate inflammation and thrombosis, promoting clinical complications. This proposal will leverage microfluidic systems and functional assays to elucidate the roles of REVs in complement activation and thromboinflammation, and to use REVs as a biomarker to evaluate complement activation and thromboinflammation in individuals with SCD. This project will yield a more precise evaluation of clinical outcomes, as well as effective screening and selection of candidate therapeutic interventions in SCD, and the knowledge that will be gained in this project can be adapted to other hemolytic disorders such as atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Resolving Spatiotemporal Determinants of Cell Specification in Corticogenesis with Latent Space Methods Applicant: Genevieve Stein-O’Brien, PhD MHS Proper development of the brain requires precise regulation and coordination of spatiotemporal cues. We hypothesize human genetic variation manifests phenotypic differences by introducing small biases in spatiotemporal determinants that have accumulated effect over development. To test this hypothesis, we build novel computational and experimental tools to resolve transcriptional regulation of anatomical identity (space) and cell cycle length (time) in the brain and apply these tools to induced pluripotent stem cells from ALS patients in a model of brain development to show the effect of genetic background.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease is a devastating neurodegenerative disorder resulting in cognitive impairment and progressive dementia, and currently no effective cure has been identified. Our proposed studies aim to understand the multifactorial role and underlying mechanisms of action of an E3 ubiquitin ligase IDOL in AD pathology. This research will have the potential to reveal a novel therapeutic target for the treatment of Alzheimer’s diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy People 2020 has identified motor vehicle crashes as a significant public health issue for teenagers and young adults, and cellphone-related distracted driving has been recognized as an epidemic hazard in traffic safety, particularly among young drivers whose cellphone use and crash rate are high. The findings of this study will determine the effectiveness of a cellphone app and driving mode in reducing cellphone use and high- risk driving events. This study will help inform public health and safety researchers and organizations, cellphone service providers, and cellphone manufacturers regarding the use of cellphone apps and driving modes for reducing cellphone-related distracted driving in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because it is expected to identify a set of objective markers of emotional reactivity, speech preparation and production and cognitive control vulnerabilities that are identifiable very early in development and contribute to the onset and pathogenesis of stuttering. The identification of these markers of risk for stuttering persistence, in combination with other predictors of stuttering, will allow clinicians to better pinpoint targets for assessment, set the stage for novel therapeutic approaches, and allow researchers to better evaluate the effects of early intervention due to an improved ability to distinguish persistent from transient cases. Thus, the proposed research supports the mission of NIDCD by discovering new knowledge that has the potential to improve health and outcomes of young children who stutter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Controversy about the safety of water fluoridation has led scientific advisory groups to recommend additional research on fluoride toxicity. This study will use a novel biomarker (dentin) to rigorously test the safety of chronic fluoride exposure among potentially vulnerable populations at levels relevant to the U.S. and Canada. The use of the dentin matrix will allow us to measure chronic fluoride exposure levels and to identify the possibility of discrete periods of susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Neuroscience Training Program (NTP) at the University of Wisconsin–Madison provides integrated predoctoral neuroscience training, equipping students to carry out research aimed at understanding fundamental neurobiological processes and mechanisms underlying diseases and disorders of the nervous system. Our goal is to prepare our students to lead the next generation of scientists with independent careers in academia, healthcare, teaching, industry, and public service.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Neuroscience Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A renewal of our T32 pre- and post-doctoral training grant (T32EY027721) is being submitted to continue to provide research training in basic science disciplines relevant to vision research and to support interdisciplinary, collaborative and translational research so that trainees are prepared to enter and compete within emerging, interactive research environments. The Vision Research Training Program (VRTP) represents a collaborative interaction between the Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences (DOVS) in the School of Medicine and Public Health (SMPH) and the McPherson Eye Research Institute (MERI) at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The interdisciplinary training supported by the grant will cross traditional department, school, and institute boundaries and will provide exceptional scientific training as well as provide a structure for interactions with clinical scientists and clinicians to meet the goal of understanding, preventing and treating diseases of the visual system. Eighteen faculty currently comprise the group of eligible trainers in the proposal, and they are organized according to four areas of research emphasis: (a) Development and Diseases of the Anterior Segment of the Eye, (b) Development and Diseases of the Posterior Segment of the Eye; (c) Ocular Epidemiology and Genetics; (d) Higher Order Visual Processing.
PROJECT_TERMS: Training Programs;Vision research
PROJECT_TITLE: Vision Research Training Program

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Our predoctoral Neuromuscular Plasticity Training (NMPT) program provides a diverse group of Trainees with a common foundation in rehabilitation and translational science. Over the last funding cycle, the program has supported 18 Trainees including physical therapists, speech-language therapists, and basic science trainees. Graduates leave the program with an established professional network of rehabilitation scientists, experience with interactive scientific presentations, and foundational knowledge in neuromuscular plasticity in the context of rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative We present our proposal to acquire a Perkin Elmer IVIS SpectrumCT instrument that will be installed in the Einstein IVIS core facility. This technology is important for studies in cancer biology and infectious diseases and is a critical need for 40 different investigator laboratories at Einstein. Our current IVIS instrument is over 12 years old and service by the vendor will be discontinued. In addition, parts are also difficult to obtain due to age of the instrument. Overall, a replacement instrument is urgently needed to maintain reliable IVIS access for investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a public health epidemic, with a prevalence of greater than 10% in the United States. Diabetes and associated metabolic disorders cause significant health complications and generate enormous costs for healthcare systems. In order to develop new and more effective treatments and care strategies for those affected by diabetes and other metabolic disorders, there is a critical need for researchers in this space who can change the course of diabetes through discovery, analysis, and development of new care strategies. The Duke University T32 Research Training Program in Endocrinology and Metabolism will leverage its world-class faculty, resources, and environment to combat the diabetes epidemic by recruiting and training outstanding physicians and medical scientists for careers in diabetes and metabolism research.

PROJECT_TITLE: Endocrinology and Metabolism Training Program

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The multidisciplinary University of Alabama at Birmingham Training Program in Brain Tumor Biology is focused on preparing highly motivated pre-doctoral and MD/PhD students for a career in fundamental and translational brain tumor research. Trainees are therefore selected for their commitment to neuro-oncology research and excellent performance in the first two years of the UAB Graduate Biomedical Sciences Program. Our dedicated and collaborative training environment provides the ideal setting for implementation of an educational program in brain tumor research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: We propose to renew our Comprehensive Musculoskelelal Training Program , which has been highly successful in training the next generation of musculoskelelal biologists, physicians, and engineers for research careers in MSK. We will offer trainee positons from three to four for each group: predoctoral students, postdoctoral fellows, and summer medical student interns. The training program will integrate current musculoskeletal research and teaching programs in the basic, clinical, and engineering sciences through the Indiana Center for Musculoskeletal Health, and train young scientists for research careers as basic scientists, bioengineers, clinical and translational investigators pursuing the causes of, and solutions to, musculoskelelal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Animal species differ dramatically in their aging rates and susceptibility to age-related diseases including Alzheimer’s disease. This Program Project Grant will identify mechanisms responsible for longevity and disease resistance in long-lived mammals. This knowledge will enable the development of novel interventions to extend human healthspan and treat Alzheimer’s disease based on longevity mechanisms selected by millions of years of evolution.

PHR: The rapidly developing field of precision and genomic medicine offers enormous opportunities to transform research and clinical practice. This postdoctoral training program brings together three outstanding components to build a world-class training program in genomic medicine: 1) an internationally-recognized faculty of experienced mentors with expertise in precision and genomic medicine, 2) outstanding institutional resources bridging clinical, genomic, and data sciences, and 3) deep engagement with cutting edge, collaborative initiatives at the regional, national, and international levels to provide rich training experiences. Our goal is to provide rigorous, multidisciplinary training for a new generation of scientific leaders who can drive progress in the field.
PROJECT_TERMS: Genomic medicine;precision medicine;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Mass General Brigham Training Program in Precision and Genomic Medicine

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The main goal of the Structural Biology and Molecular Biophysics Training Program at the University of Pennsylvania is to train a cadre of superlative students and put them on the trajectory to achieve success and leadership roles at the highest levels of academic and industrial science in this core area of biomedical research. We will leverage the immense resources, 45 outstanding faculty trainers, and talented graduate students of UPenn to accomplish this goal. The program will do so with a premium put on training in the technically challenging aspects of experimentation in this area of biomedicine, scientific thinking, integration of structural biology and molecular biophysics research within the broader biomedical scientific community, presentation skills, career-focused exploration, and achieving success through promoting and rejoicing diversity and inclusion in the scientific workplace and community.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biophysics;Molecular;structural biology;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Structural biology and molecular biophysics training program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - A[TWD-A]

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, 19 to 25 million children make more than 29 million emergency department (ED) visits each year. The Pediatric Emergency Medicine Training Program offers unique training in biomedical informatics and genomics for the next generation of leaders in pediatric acute care research. Thus, when ill or injured children arrive at the ED, they can receive the best evidence-based care, with the most effective diagnostics and treatments possible.
PROJECT_TERMS: Emergency Medicine;pediatric emergency;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Pediatric Emergency Medicine

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although clinical guidelines recommend that sexual health be routinely discussed clinically for all patients with a cancer diagnosis, a lack of training for oncologists in how to discuss sexual health effectively with patients serves as perhaps the single most critical impediment to clinical communication about this topic. The objectives of the proposed project are to (1) develop a novel, virtual group-based course to train fellows in hematology-oncology in effective clinical communication about sexual health (SHIFT; Sexual Health Integrative Fellowship Training), and (2) evaluate the acceptability and impact of the course across two fellowship programs. This project has public health relevance because enhancing hematology-oncology fellows’ communication skills about sexual health with their patients could enhance delivery of cancer care and improve outcomes for patients’ sexual health and overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Washington University T32 training grant “Multidisciplinary Training in Alzheimer and Related Dementias” (ADRD-T32) is designed to prepare the next generation of researchers in Alzheimer disease and related dementias. The program provides training in collaborative, multidisciplinary research for predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees from a variety of disciplines, emphasizing translational research and utilization of large scale NIH-supported data sets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) remain critically essential in training a significant number of diverse Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) graduates. The effects of COVID-19, and other emerging public health threats continue to have an unrelenting impact on all aspects of society and will require continued development of new therapeutics to help prevent deaths, which requires a diverse representation of educators and researchers, particularly from HBCUs, to make innovative contributions in this area. The proposed HBCU/MSI Mentored Research Program in the Structural Biology of Human Pathogens at Meharry Medical College will provide a 10-week intensive, hands-on mentored research experience for students (community college, undergraduate, medical) to gain the skill of solving protein structures using X-ray crystallography.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disseminated candidiasis, the 3rd most common hospital-acquired infection, results in kidney damage. Interleukin-17 plays an unexpected kidney protective role in disseminated candidiasis. The objective of this project is to understand in detail the mechanisms of IL-17-mediated renal protection with a long-term goal of using this knowledge for therapeutic benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Duke University/University of North Carolina (UNC) Advancing Diversity in Aging Research Program is an innovative research training program designed to offer training and support to undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds at Duke University and UNC-Chapel Hill to pursue careers in aging and resilience research. By combining the unique strengths of both institutions, this program will sow the seeds for the development of a cadre of diverse scientists with expertise in aging research and promote a strong community of researchers who are equipped to optimize reserve and resilience among older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center is one of only a small number of freestanding, NCI-designated, comprehensive cancer centers, and the only comprehensive center in New York State (NYS) outside of Manhattan. Roswell Park has a rich history of leadership in basic discovery, translational, clinical and population- based science in cancer research. In recent years Roswell Park has pushed the boundaries of excellence in cancer research and has experienced exponential growth in faculty recruitment, programmatic and scientific excellence, a robust clinical trial portfolio and accrual to investigator-initiated trials, population cancer science development and a broader footprint in the WNY catchment area and community with a focus on diversity, equity and inclusion. We propose here to be a leader in the development of innovative approaches in cancer research to improve the quality of care for our patients in our catchment area and beyond, to enhance collaborative efforts between scientists and physicians toward a more effective translation of our discoveries into paradigm changing patient practices and interventions and policies, to train and develop the next generation of investigators through innovative oncology-focused programs, to focus on the needs of our catchment area of WNY relevant to our cancer burden and related disparities through research and outreach using effective strategies for education, prevention, treatment and survivorship and to cultivate, value and support diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging across our cancer center employees, scientists, physicians, nurses and healthcare staff, students and trainees and leadership toward a more productive and diverse workplace and to serve our community more effectively. Roswell Park continues to play a primary role in discovery and innovation that enable us to deliver the best cancer care to our patients in New York State, around the country and around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Mental illness affects approximately 15% of the population, creates enormous disability and cost, and has been stubbornly persistent over the decades. To fundamentally alter this trajectory we must recruit and train the next generation of physician-scientist researchers who will generate the advances in diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and cure that we need to alleviate this burden. Yale’s T32-funded Clinical Neuroscience Research Training Program, of which this is a renewal application, has an exceptional track record of training psychiatric physician-scientists, which we here aim to continue and enhance.
PROJECT_TERMS: Clinical;Neurosciences Research;Psychiatry;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Clinical Neuroscience Research Training Program in Psychiatry

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the rise in the impact of cardiovascular disease on U.S. and world health, and the rapid advances in imaging technologies and cardiovascular biology, it is critical to train the next generation of investigators in technology- based cardiovascular imaging research. Stanford University has world-class faculty, the necessary resources, and the collaborative milieu to address the major public health problem of cardiovascular disease. This multidisciplinary T32 training program in Cardiovascular Imaging at Stanford (CVIS) is designed to train postdoctoral fellows in clinical, engineering, and molecular imaging technology, and to foster their development into investigators dedicated to identifying innovative solutions and capable of translating basic research into clinical success to combat cardiovascular diseases.
PI_NAMEs: NIEMAN, KOEN ;PAULY, JOHN M.;WU, JOSEPH C. (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: cardiovascular imaging;multidisciplinary;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Multi-Disciplinary Training Program in Cardiovascular Imaging at Stanford

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to maintain and expand a residency research training program that recruits medical graduates with demonstrated research experience and prepares them to become independent physician- scientists with careers in psychiatric or neuroscience research, a key NIMH goal. This 4-year program will provide participants with extensive mentorship, formal research training, access to pilot funding, and protected research time. Program trainees will be well-prepared to rapidly progress on the path to NIH K or R awards, accelerating the transition to careers as independent investigators who can address cutting edge psychiatric and neuroscience challenges with public health impact.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Mass spectrometry is a powerful and robust technique for the analysis and quantification of complex collection of proteins, peptides, lipids, and small molecule metabolites. Currently, there is only a single mass spectrometer at the University of Rochester (UR) available for proteomic experiments. This instrument is currently being used at full capacity and lacks functional capabilities that are required or advantageous for several ongoing NIH-funded projects being conducted by the user-base of the UR Mass Spectrometry Resource Laboratory (MSRL). The proposed purchase of the timsTOF HT mass spectrometry system will facilitate proteomic experiments at UR by providing researchers a suite of novel tools that take advantage of the Trapped Ion Mobility (TIMS) analyzer and Parallel Accumulation and Serial Fragmentation (PASEF) features of the instrument. Specifically, the rapid sequencing speeds of the instrument will greatly alleviate project backlogs, reduce turnaround times and bring down the per-experiment costs of proteomics projects. These capabilities will enhance the ability of UR researchers to conduct large-scale proteomic experiments that require high proteome coverage and large number of samples and replicates. A number of projects described by the users of this instrument have clinical implications and will be analyzing proteomes within disease models that have direct relevance to the development of therapies that can improve human health. These projects, which are funded by 20 NIH grants, either require or will be significantly aided by the requested timsTOF HT instrument.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE. The fields of microbiology and immunology (M&I) have been at the epicenter of recent transformative scientific discoveries as well as unprecedented public health challenges that have fueled demand for professionals in these fields. Translating these discoveries into novel strategies to combat pathogens and improve human health involves complex interdisciplinary research and requires the broad perspectives of a science and healthcare workforce that reflects the diverse skills and peoples of our nation. To fill this acute workforce need, the Supporting Under-represented Minorities in Microbiology and Immunology Research (SUMMIR) program will utilize the robust resources of the University of Maryland School of Medicine and partner institutions to provide integrated research experiences, courses for skills and professional development and multi-faceted mentoring that will inspire undergraduate interns who comprise the next generation of leaders in these fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The goal of the Penn Dermatology Research T32 Training Program is to train the next generation of independent investigators to become leaders in cutaneous biology and dermatology. Skin diseases are very prevalent, represent a major health burden, and have a profound impact on quality of life. By training diverse, multi-disciplinary investigators that span basic, translational, and clinical research, we seek to improve mechanistic understanding and identify novel therapeutic targets for skin disease, leading to improved health and overall quality of life.
PROJECT_TERMS: Dermatology;Research Training;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Penn Dermatology Research Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current and future success of science in solving the drug addiction problem is dependent on collaborative partnerships between diverse researchers, clinicians, and affected communities that deliver discovery to addiction prevention and clinical care. Attaining this goal is increasingly dependent on interdisciplinary, team- based, clinical and community translational research and the ultimate objective of this training program is to develop this next generation of addiction investigators. As the sole NIDA T32 training program at the only academic medical center in the state of Arkansas, the proposed program seeks to use training and career development to meaningfully impact the immense public health problem of drug addiction at both the national, regional, and state levels.
PROJECT_TERMS: addiction;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Translational Training in Addiction

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This long-standing training program in Environmental Health Sciences at Johns Hopkins University provides state of the art training for the next generation of scientists in environmental sciences with the purpose of detection and evaluation of the health impacts of hazardous environmental agents on susceptible populations and the development of prevention/treatment strategies that will mitigate the impact of these exposures on human health.
PROJECT_TERMS: Environmental Health;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Environmental Health Sciences

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cell and Molecular Biology Training Grant seeks to broadly train PhD students in cell and molecular biology to adapt to changing needs in the biomedical research work force. This Predoctoral Training Program includes education and research opportunities to investigate the molecular and cellular basis of fundamental biological processes that range from cell signaling and architecture to gene expression, employing a wide array of model systems and state of the art imaging, molecular/cellular assays, and high throughput technologies. Career development opportunities are also central to the training program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Training Program in Precision Environmental Health Sciences (TPEHS) is a joint initiative of Baylor College of Medicine, The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston Schools of Public Health and of Biomedical Informatics, and The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. This multidisciplinary program provides the next generation of pre- and post-doctoral trainees the skills to be successful working at the intersection of Genomics/epigenomics, Environmental Health, and Data Science to improve our understanding of environment influences on human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) pain is heterogeneous with distinct mechanisms across stages of OA pain that are poorly understood and contributes to the variable therapeutic efficacy of treatments for OA pain. Moreover, OA pain is more common and reported to be more severe in females compared to males. This grant explores whether pathological changes in innervation of the OA joint and adjacent muscle determines transition between mid- stage and advanced OA pain and whether this occurs in a sex dependent fashion that increases susceptibility of females to develop more severe OA joint pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias refer to a wide group of relentless neurodegenerative diseases, with as yet unknown etiologies. This renewal application seeks continued funding to train predoctoral students studying clinical and translational aspects of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. Trainees from diverse backgrounds will receive support to participate in didactic coursework, mentored research and professional development in preparation for a future career in clinical and translational research in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Although soft tissue sarcomas can be treated surgically, for patients with advanced disease there are few effective systemic therapies. By discovering the molecular alterations that drive the formation and growth of sarcomas, we have an opportunity to identify new types of therapy for these deadly diseases. This insight into sarcoma biology will also allow for more precise diagnosis and prognosis and will identify biomarkers that predict how the tumor will respond to specific treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RP1: Molecular Determinants of GIST Pathogenesis Narrative Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), a common subtype of soft tissue sarcoma, often exhibits aggressive clinical behavior, and is incurable in advanced and metastatic settings. Through genomic and clinical analysis of large cohorts of patients with GIST, we associated MAX/MGA/MYC genetic alterations and arm-level deletions of 1p with metastatic GIST and poor relapse-free survival in resected GIST. Here, we propose comprehensive, collaborative, and multidisciplinary studies to investigate the mechanisms of MAX/MGA/MYC perturbation involved in aggressive GIST behavior, identify, and validate molecular biomarkers predictive of recurrence risk, and develop a combinatorial pathologic-genomic nomogram to guide adjuvant imatinib therapy decisions and identify novel strategies to target metastasis in advanced GIST.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RP2: Targeting Hippo Pathway Dependence in Genetically Complex Sarcomas NARRATIVE New treatment options are urgently needed for the most common and clinically aggressive types of sarcoma with complex genomic alterations: well-differentiated and dedifferentiated liposarcomas, myxofibrosarcoma, and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. The proposed studies will elucidate the role of the Hippo signaling pathway and the translation factor eIF4A in these deadly sarcomas and will include preclinical testing of a new eIF4A inhibitor. By advancing eIF4A inhibition toward clinical trials, the proposed work will likely lead to more effective treatment for patients with genetically complex sarcomas and perhaps other eIF4A-dependent cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RP3: Identifying Targetable Epigenetic and Immuno-Oncologic Vulnerabilities in Synovial Sarcoma NARRATIVE This project will develop and evaluate new treatment strategies for synovial sarcoma by (1) examining how a specific genetic alteration affects epigenetic regulation and identifying anticancer drugs that target the resulting vulnerabilities, (2) developing an engineered T cell-based therapy to recognize the protein resulting from the fusion of two genes that occurs only in synovial sarcoma, and (3) evaluating the efficacy and immunogenicity of an mRNA vaccine designed to induce immune responses to the fusion protein and other synovial sarcoma- specific antigens, in combination with an immune-modulating antibody in a clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Drexel University proposes to establish a robust and innovative program, Drexel DREAM (Diversity, Research, Experiential Learning, Research Skills and Aging Science, and Mentorship) Scholars Program, to enhance the diversity of the biomedical, behavioral, and clinical research workforce in aging research. The DREAM Scholars program is built upon 5 pillars: 1) leverages the university’s commitment to diversity in students, faculty, and staff, and health equity in the communities we serve; 2) faculty expertise in aging research approaches that span the continuum from the bench to policy in three key thematic areas: preventing and managing chronic conditions, enhancing active and purposeful living, and enabling aging in place; 3) experiential learning; 4) an innovative virtual learning community where students obtain digital badges for mastering new knowledge in research skills and aging science; and 5) faculty mentorship for each DREAM Scholar throughout their undergraduate studies. We will recruit and train 22 underrepresented minority (URM) students who completed freshman year to participate in the DREAM Summer track- a noncredit full-time 10- week paid summer aging research training and 38 URM students in their sophomore, pre-junior, or junior year, to participate in the DREAM CO-OP Scholar Track- a noncredit full-time 26-week paid aging research training program as their cooperative education rotation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Molecular mediators of muscle spindle mechanosensation. The ability to move through an unpredictable environment relies on stretch-sensitive sensory neurons in the muscle and many conditions, including aging, chemotherapy treatment, and neuromuscular diseases, can impair the function of these neurons. This research investigates how altered function in proteins necessary for the function of these sensory neurons, including the mechanically sensitive ion channel PIEZO2, impairs their ability to sense and transmit muscle movement information. The results of these studies will provide important information about how these sensory neurons work and determine whether the consequences of dysfunction in these proteins differs if it occurs throughout the lifespan or starts in adulthood.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: New research methods have made it possible to study hundreds of human diseases in parallel. By combining a high-throughput CRISPR technology with state-of-the-art sequencing, this project will generate hundreds of distinct models of human diseases in zebrafish, then quantify the molecular and functional changes that occur in every disease model. Computational methods will be used to categorize diseases, elucidate the underlying disease processes, and predict targets for treating them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative In a national laboratory-industry partnership, we propose a novel sensor for magnetoencephalography (MEG), a pulsed optically pumped magnetometer (OPM) featuring 1) exceptional gradiometrically inferred sensitivity (2 ft/rt-Hz), 2) wide bandwidth (220 Hz), 3) simultaneous triaxial signal detection using a single sensing volume, and 4) closed-loop operation on all three axes. In a demonstration of the versatility, utility, and high performance of the new OPM, we will noninvasively measure gamma waves in infants, which have high frequency and low amplitude and are involved in cognitive phenomena and large-scale brain-network activity, and detecting them non-invasively will inform a broad range of studies examining neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders. Due to individual sensor placement and the resulting increased in signal-to-noise ratio, MEG using OPMs is the best method to detect and localize gamma waves in infants, and our OPM compared to existing commercial OPMs will show marked improvement in gamma wave detection through dramatically improved sensitivity, bandwidth, and accuracy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) displays tumor heterogeneity with distinct transcriptome changes, however, the specific molecular determinants of treatment response remains unclear. This project will investigate how high levels of DNA replication stress in SCLC creates a therapeutic vulnerability that can be exploited with new druggable targets in the replication stress space.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite recent advances in targeted therapy and immune checkpoint blockade, medicines that target DNA replication continue to play a major role in cancer treatment. Unfortunately, responses can often be transient due to a variety of resistance mechanisms. This project aims to understand the fundamental biology of Schlafen family member 11, a potent sensitizer to replication stress in small cell lung cancer.

PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE Project 2 will investigate the mechanisms of replication stress tolerance in naïve and chemo-resistant SCLC cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The limitations in our understanding of replication-fork lesions and their mechanisms of repair in small-cell lung- cancer (SCLC) presents a critical barrier for improving treatment and addressing resistance. This project is highly significant because it examines complex levels of DNA damage and repair pathways in SCLC that have direct relevance to treatment outcome. Our proposal addresses key issues that are directly related to therapeutic response and resistance in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Current therapeutic interventions for small cell lung cancer (SCLC) are limited in scope. In this study, we propose using mouse models with different co-genetic alteration to better understand the heterogeneity and replication stress that hindered the treatment outcomes for SCLC patients. Furthermore, we will utilize these models to evaluate rational drug combinations that can generate effective and durable responses for this dismal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Hearing loss is commonplace: (1) 2-3 children out of every 1000 born in the USA have some form of hearing loss and (2) by the age of 75, over 50% of adults have disabling hearing loss. Language impairments, such as aphasia, also affect a significant number of Americans: 150,000+ each year. Thus, the proposed training program is extremely relevant to public health because it will help identify, motivate, and train the next generation of auditory and communication neuroscientists to exploit the explosion in computational and theoretical techniques from the very earliest stages of their scientific careers so that they can help lead the way to better diagnoses and treatments of a wide range of hearing and communication disorders.
PI_NAMEs: BALASUBRAMANIAN, VIJAY ;COHEN, YALE E (contact);GEFFEN, MARIA NEIMARK
PROJECT_TERMS: Communication;Neurosciences;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Cross-disciplinary training in computational approaches to the neuroscience of audition and communication

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The competing renewal of the TGP training program is proposed to train the next generation of postgenome cancer researchers, including multidisciplinary training in: 1) translational cancer research, to gain exposure to mechanistic studies in translational research and their importance to the human organism; 2) precision medicine, to gain experience in state-of-the-art ways to diagnose and target treatment of cancer patients based on genomic profiles; 3) translational genetics and genomics, to gain competency in translational genomics needed for future understanding and implementation of cancer precision medicine; 4) bioinformatics, to learn how to read and interpret large genomics datasets; 5) exposure to relevant tumor boards and to industrial collaborations with academic faculty mentors on large scale genomic applications to cancer precision medicine. An outstanding training faculty has been assembled from the MD Anderson Cancer Center, the number one cancer center in the country, to provide state-of-the-art, inclusive education, training and mentoring for predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows to further the mission of MD Anderson to provide outstanding state-of-the- art research-driven patient care.
PROJECT_TERMS: Genomic medicine;Malignant Neoplasms;precision medicine;Training Programs;translational genomics
PROJECT_TITLE: Translational Genomics and Precision Medicine in Cancer Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Training of the next generation of neuroscientists will have a long-term impact on a multitude of diseases of the nervous system as well as widely impacting the lives of countless individuals. Our Broad-based Research, Analytics, and Innovation in Neuroscience (B2RAIN) Predoctoral Training Program is designed to provide a group of innovative young scientists with rigorous state-of-the-art neuroscience training. In addition, the B2RAIN Training Program will provide participants with the quantitative tools and literacy necessary to tackle a wide range of future challenges in neuroscience research. Our program will be the only NIH Jointly Sponsored Ruth L. Kirschstein Institutional Predoctoral Training Program in the Neurosciences in the State of Florida.
PI_NAMEs: BIZON, JENNIFER LYNN (contact);CANDELARIO-JALIL, EDUARDO JESUS;GIASSON, BENOIT I

PROJECT_TITLE: Broad-based Research, Analytics and Innovation in Neuroscience (B2RAIN) predoctoral Training Program

PHR: The Training Grant in Diabetes, Metabolism, and Endocrinology at the Vagelos College of Physicians & Surgeons, Columbia University, provides training in basic, translational, and clinical research to individuals with a background in biomedical research, holding MD and/or PhD degrees. The program aims to leverage the considerable human, scientific, and clinical resources of Columbia University to help trainees achieve academic distinction, establish themselves as leading investigators, and improve the practice of medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CaNCURE: Cancer Nanomedicine Co-ops for Undergraduate Research Experiences The CaNCURE: Cancer Nanomedicine Co-ops for Undergraduate Research Experiences Program seeks to provide training and education in research at the interface of nanotechnology, cancer biology, and medicine to attract, retain, and encourage young scientists & engineers, particularly those from underrepresented minorities, to pursue careers in cancer research. The program will achieve this central aim by creating meaningful and rigorous research experiences mentored by outstanding academic and clinical researchers and supplemented with high-impact learning and professional development opportunities. The program combines Northeastern University's model of co-op education with the outstanding cancer nanomedicine research infrastructure at Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center to create an immersive and inclusive training environment for knowledge and skills acquisition for the next generation of cancer researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement The heterogeneity of tumor microenvironment provides a unique physiological milieu for tumor progression and metastasis. The findings of this proposal will reveal a stromal progenitor cell hierarchy in squamous cell carcinoma to provide a foundation for cancer organoid culture, high-throughput screening, personalized medicine, and biomarker identification in head and neck cancer. The long-term goal of this proposal is to develop an applicable model to achieve the cure of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Genetic Dissection of Cells and Organisms Training Program (GDTP) training aims to enable diverse predoctoral students to acquire fundamental knowledge and skills required for ethical, impactful, rigorous, and reproducible research in genetics, as applied to basic biological processes and human health. The GDTP will prepare trainees to successfully pursue a variety of career paths that intersect with genetics. This integrative predoctoral genetics training program and the discoveries made by its trainees will contribute to the NIH’s mission to develop, maintain, and renew scientific human resources for the nation, fostering its capacity to enhance health, extend lives, and reduce disease burden.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NICHD/NRSA-supported Population Science Research Training Program, housed at UNC’s Carolina Population Center, combines disciplinary PhDs with interdisciplinary predoctoral and postdoctoral training in demography and population science. Hallmarks of this longstanding program are: the integration of social and health sciences, an outstanding and experienced training faculty from 11 departments in the College of Arts & Sciences and the Gillings School of Global Public Health, the interdisciplinary team orientation of much of the training and research, and a well-established track record of success in the recruitment, training, and placement of trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Inspiring Undergraduate Student Training in Alzheimer's Research (USTAR) is a 20-month undergraduate research educational program that will provide Black/African American undergraduate students with mentored didactic, clinical, and research experiences to stimulate interest in pursuing research careers related to Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). As an innovative, highly structured, and supportive research education program, USTAR has potential to increase diversity in the national workforce that conducts health disparities research pertaining to ADRD. This goal aligns with the NIA mission to meet the nation's biomedical, behavioral, and clinical research needs and to ensure health equity for all Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Although it is now clear in human neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) patients that sex differences exist in the effects of early life pain and stress on later psychological functioning and chronic pain, the mechanisms underlying these effects remain unclear. This project investigates the behavioral and neuroendocrine changes that occur in a rodent NICU model of neonatal pain and stress in both male and female rats, testing the hypothesis that there will be sex differences in the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: The University of Virginia School of Data Science and Center for Public Health Genomics will collaborate to train 45 Masters-level genomics data scientists, through both classroom and research experiences. UVA’s Masters in Data Science (MSDS) program is ideally suited to this effort because it affords 1) a year-long capstone experience, 2) space for elective courses which allow students to acquire vital genomics content knowledge alongside their data science curriculum, and 3) an emphasis on responsible data science and research ethics that is crucial to training of the biomedical and informatics workforce. Robust supports for student recruitment and mature relationships with minority-serving institutions (MSIs) will ensure that the students trained in genomics data science represent the diversity of the patients that will be impacted by their work.

PHR: Musculoskeletal diseases affect about one-third of the U.S. population. The estimated total cost of this disease burden in the U.S. is approximately 5.2% of the country’s gross domestic product. We propose to improve the research infrastructure by training predoctoral students and postdoctoral fellows with the long-term goal of decreasing this societal burden through creation of a workforce that is adept at acquisition and application of new knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance Statement Superwarfarins are long-acting 4-hydroxycoumarin derivative anticoagulants developed and widely used for pest control, but their availability and affordability have led to both accidental and intentional poisonings. The only existing treatments are vitamin K and infusion of plasma coagulation factors which are expensive, have limited accessibility, and may be required for months or years. The proposed studies will develop new therapeutics in a high-throughput, tractable model system that are desperately needed to treat affected patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Neural Systems and Behavior Course (NS&B) provides an exceptional and singular training opportunity that enables the next generation of researchers to tackle the problems central to issues of mental illness. This 8- week course is characterized by a rigorous and innovative curriculum that is focused on discovery research and integrates across diverse levels of biological organization thus leading the alumni and faculty to a better understanding of the human brain and the truly complex causes of mental illness. Since its inception in 1978, NS&B has prepared students to understand how the brain generates behavior by using unique and complementary inquiry-based laboratory exercises to teach experimental techniques, concepts and experimental design at the cutting edge of systems neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The purpose of this renewal application is to continue a translational and interdisciplinary training program in alcohol research. This multidisciplinary program provides training in bio-behavioral factors associated within alcohol-use disorders at the pre-doctoral level; graduates of this program are actively involved in research, teaching, publishing articles, and becoming independent researchers in the alcohol field. We aim to advance our program of excellence in translational or interdisciplinary research training because the need for a translational or interdisciplinary program is greater today than ever before, and the proposed continuation of this training program fills a unique niche in alcohol research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is an interdisciplinary predoctoral program in computational cognitive neuroscience. Funds from this program will support the training of advanced predoctoral candidates who are capable of applying a combination of empirical and theoretical approaches that decisively addresses their scientific questions about the mind and brain. Training a generation of such scientists holds great promise for making transformative gains in our understanding of mental health and brain diseases and disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Georgetown Lombardi Comprehensive Cancer Center (LCCC) is applying for this renewal of its CCSG as a consortium cancer center with the John Theurer Cancer Center of Hackensack Meridian Health. LCCC’s vision is to impact our diverse catchment area, the nation, and beyond by pushing scientific knowledge, creativity, and application; serving all with compassion, equity and respect; and preparing individuals who will devote themselves to reducing the severity of cancer on the individual, family, and community through improved access to care. LCCC remains the only NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center based in the nation's capital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In 2007, Massachusetts General (MGH) and McLean Hospitals piloted an integrated Research Concentration within the MGH/McLean Adult Psychiatry Residency Program to address the critical shortage of physician- scientists engaged in mental health research careers. This program has been highly successful in its goal of retaining MD/PhD trained physician-scientists and recruiting and developing new physician-scientists. This application will provide support and infrastructure to continue, improve, and expand this well-integrated research education program that serves to attract and train residents to become future psychiatrist-scientists in basic, translational, and patient-oriented research, while increasing research literacy among all residents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The Yale Cancer Center Advanced Training Program for Physician-scientists (YCC-ATPP) is specifically designed to prepare YCC Hematology/Medical Oncology (Heme/MedOnc) fellows for independent careers as physician-scientists in cancer-related research. Through the program, T32 fellows receive essential training and support including protected research time, funding, dedicated mentorship from a three-member Mentor Team, research projects, individual development plans, didactic courses, opportunities to mentor students and residents in the summer Diversity Enhancement Program in Oncology, community outreach and engagement initiatives, as well as transitional pathways to facilitate the establishment of a solid foundation for their future careers as physician-scientists.
PROJECT_TERMS: physician-scientist training program;Yale Cancer Center
PROJECT_TITLE: Yale Cancer Center Advanced Training Program for Physician-Scientists (YCC-ATPP)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY/ABSTRACT Accelerating the future development of new cancer treatments requires educating the next generation of leaders in this field in the complex interactions between tumors, their surroundings, and the immune system, and preparing them to efficiently conduct research in today's regulatory and administrative environment. The T32 Investigational Cancer Therapeutics Training Program (ICTTP) at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center addresses this need by providing fellows in medical oncology who are committed to careers in translational cancer research with comprehensive mentored research and didactic training for two years. The ICTTP program is designed to optimally train physician scientists to translate discoveries regarding the biology of cancer into new, approved molecular/cytotoxic, immunotherapeutic, and cell-based treatments through state-of-the-art experimental trials.
PROJECT_TERMS: Malignant Neoplasms;Therapeutic;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Investigational Cancer Therapeutics Training Program (ICTTP)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Institutional Training and Education Study Section (F)[NCI-F]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this T32 Training Program renewal is to develop a new generation of pediatric endocrinologists who will be equipped to carry out innovative and scientifically rigorous patient-oriented and laboratory-based research in diabetes and endocrine disorders of children. This will address a major public health need which is the critical shortage of academic pediatric endocrinologists in diabetes and endocrinology research. The Program will support 3 Fellow Trainees per year for up to 2 years of mentored research training at the fellowship level working with NIH-funded Training faculty from the Children’s Hospital and the Perelman School of Medicine at University of Pennsylvania.
PI_NAMEs: KATZ, LORRAINE E LEVITT (contact);KELLY, ANDREA BRIDGET
PROJECT_TERMS: Childhood diabetes;Endocrinology;Research Training;Translational Research
PROJECT_TITLE: Translational Research Training in Pediatric Diabetes & Endocrinology
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Diabetes, Endocrinology and Metabolic Diseases B Study Section[DDK-B]

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The central goal for this application is to provide CRISPR/Cas methods and resources for conditional gene studies and improved precision genome editing to enhance zebrafish animal models for biomedical research. We expect by the end of the funding period to significantly expand our Cre and conditional allele resource to established fields of zebrafish studies (embryonic development, major tissue and organ systems) as well as understudied, rapidly emerging areas (epigenetics, mitochondrial biology) to facilitate new zebrafish models of human health across the lifespan. Our methods to improve GeneWeld and DonorGuide precision genome editing in zebrafish will be widely applicable, given the near universal application of CRISPR genome editing in model and non-model systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: NARRATIVE The P01 proposal ExpLoiting thErapeutic VulnerAbilities in hepaTocEllular carcinoma (ELEVATE) aims to interrogate molecular mechanism of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) arising from obesity-induced non- alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and evaluate a variety of combinatorial treatment options, based on underlying molecular abnormalities, using an authentic NASH-HCC mouse model. The studies will generate translationally relevant data from preclinical models having the potential to significantly impact the management of HCC patients, facilitating prolonged survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1: NARRATIVE Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), especially its aggressive form, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), is a leading cause of cirrhosis and hepatocellular cancer (HCC). The I148M variant of the patatin-like phospholipase A-3 (PNPLA3) gene is one of the best-described genetic determinants of HCC risk across multiple etiologies of chronic liver disease, including NAFLD; however, the mechanisms by which PNPLA3I148M leads to HCC are poorly understood. The focus of this application is to examine the role of the PNPLA3I148M variant in promoting HCC development and further identify the underlying mechanisms for developing potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 2: NARRATIVE The proposed studies will interrogate the mechanism by which two co-amplified genes, MYC and TAF2, cooperate to promote hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development and progression and evaluate therapeutic efficacy of combined inhibition of MYC and TAF2 along with immune checkpoint inhibitors in endogenous mouse models of HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3: NARRATIVE This project addresses a novel innate pattern recognition receptor (i.e., SRA/CD204) in the tumor microenvironment that can impede immune surveillance and promote therapeutic resistance of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). By gaining an in-depth understanding of the underlying mechanism of SRA function in these processes and successfully testing blocking antibodies targeting this receptor in preclinical models, we can significantly advance the current treatment options for HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 4: NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is associated with significant morbidity without a currently effective therapy. We describe a novel molecular reagent, a Fusion Superkine, and an innovative delivery approach permitting safe and efficient targeted systemic administration of therapeutic agents, including viruses, that employs microbubbles and focused ultrasound to release therapeutic agents in the liver. The novel reagent and innovative strategies we have developed, including an effective combinatorial regimen, have the capacity to transform and enhance the clinical management of HCC.

PHR: CORE 3 - BIOSTATISTICS AND BIOINFORMATICS CORE: NARRATIVE The Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Core (Core 3) will provide dedicated expertise and cost-efficient support in biostatistics, bioinformatics, and research data management for the ELEVATE Program Project Grant P01 application. PHR: Multiple-X-ray Source Array-based ComputedTomography (MXA-CT) Narrative We propose the development of a brand-new type of x-ray tube which uses six or more sources of radiation (sometimes simultaneously), and to use this new x-ray source to develop a faster computed tomography scanner with much better image quality than existing systems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals who identify as African American, Hispanic/Latino/a/x, Native American, and/or Pacific Islanders comprise approximately 39% of the college population but earn only 13% of doctoral degrees in the life sciences and constitute only 13% of recent medical graduates and 7.3% of full-time medical faculty. The objective of the proposed INfectious Diseases Summer Research Program Integrating Research at Emory (INSPIRE) training program at Emory University is to prepare 48 underrepresented undergraduate students from throughout the country for a career in infectious diseases research by implementing a 10-week summer research experience, delivering courses for professional and research skills development, and establishing a mentorship program that directly addresses identity and underrepresentation. At the same time and in preparation, the program will strengthen the capacity of the institution to mentor underrepresented trainees by conducting workshops in mentoring and facilitation for 75 post-doctoral fellows and junior faculty who are underrepresented and 87 faculty who are research and identity mentors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ENGAGED program takes advantage of the broad, multidisciplinary research established in the area of aging at Wake Forest University School of Medicine and our partner institutions, Wake Forest University and Winston-Salem State University. ENGAGED provides undergraduate students who are under-represented (UR) in careers in the biomedical sciences (BMS) an opportunity to participate in educational and research training in the field of gerontology/geriatrics. The overall goal is to advance diversity in research in aging and the health disparities of aging, specifically, and in BMS research, in general, by creating career pathways for well-trained UR students interested in biomedical, behavioral, and clinical research careers.

PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol misuse is a significant public health concern. This training grant draws from multiple disciplines to prepare postdoctoral fellows to investigate biological, behavioral, psychological, and social mechanisms that underlie alcohol misuse and its treatment. It sets clear and objective standards to assist fellows in successfully achieving a career in alcohol research, encourages professional development and networking opportunities, and emphasizes health disparities and social determinants of health, data science, social media research, and mobile technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD4+ T cells from Cftr deficient mice have recently been shown to have increased CD4+ Th2 cytokine production, and our preliminary studies suggest CFTR may function as a GATA3 responsive negative regulator of CD4+ Th2 polarization and effector function. In this proposal, we will use CD4+ T cells from mice and humans, a murine in vivo allergen model of Th2 inflammation, and electronic health record data to investigate the mechanisms of CFTR in Th2 inflammation and test whether CFTR modulation can reduce allergic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Communication disorders affect millions of individuals, with significant impacts in terms of disability and quality of life. The development of assessment and treatment strategies for these disorders requires that the next generation of researchers understand the mechanisms underlying these communication disorders; however, progress has been hampered by a shortage of clinically-knowledgeable communication scientists with the methodological skills required to study these underlying mechanisms. The current training plan seeks to prepare predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees studying the cognitive neuroscience of communication by supplying them with the necessary methodological expertise and tools to conduct and disseminate impactful research on communication disorders while making meaningful connections between trainees and the clinical populations they study.
PROJECT_TERMS: cognitive neuroscience;Communication;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in the Cognitive Neuroscience of Communication

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While digestive diseases continue to affect over 60 million people, causing nearly a quarter million deaths per year at a cost of over $135 billion, there remains a shortage of physician-scientists in the field who can identify new strategies for treatment and prevention. Our T32 program at Columbia trains physicians in the design and execution of high-quality, clinically relevant research in digestive and liver diseases, and we seek to continue our highly successful program in preparing future physician-scientists in the GI field.
PROJECT_TERMS: gastrointestinal;Liver;multidisciplinary;Research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Training in Translational Gastrointestinal and Liver Research

This interdisciplinary training program trains a pre-doctoral students apply modern technologies to these multiscale challenges.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biological;Structure;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Multi-scale Analysis of Biological Structure and Function

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biofabrication merges materials science processing with controlled cellular behavior, with impacts on fields such as tissue engineering and regenerative medicine, drug delivery, three-dimensional cell culture, and in vitro tissue models. To further impact these fields and to educate a future workforce, new training programs are needed that not only educate in quantitative fundamentals and biofabrication techniques, but also drive the intersection of basic research and commercialization. Through our innovative training program, including a biofabrication course, industry exposure, co-mentorship to harness the expertise of Preceptors, and a bi-weekly seminar series, our Trainees will be poised to make a meaningful impact on society through biomedicine.
PROJECT_TERMS: biofabrication;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Biofabrication Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune rheumatic diseases are a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Defining pathophysiologic mechanisms, recognizing disease phenotypes and trajectories, identifying risk factors, and directing interventional and prevention programs requires a cadre of well-trained investigators in rheumatic diseases. Our goal is to provide training to highly qualified individuals who will become the future leaders in academic rheumatology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE

The goal is to foster the development of interdisciplinary scientists who can comfortably apply complex imaging methods to understand the neuroscience of misuse and dependence of cocaine, opiate, nicotine, alcohol, and other substances, as well as treatments for these problems.

This UF Substance Abuse Training Center in Public Health does just that, thus, serving an importance niche in NIDA’s portfolio.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This is an application for support for advanced predoctoral and postdoctoral training in quantitative neuroscience. By instructing our trainees in computational modeling and advanced data analysis techniques, we aim to train scientists that will be able to bridge the key gap in our understanding of how the brain works: how do myriad single molecules and neurons collectively give rise to the mind? This is important for both basic science and clinical science - these modeling and data analysis techniques will give trainees a rich vocabulary and a powerful toolkit for exploring how pathologies of small-scale elements (e.g., deficits in neurotransmission at dopaminergic terminals) can lead to mental disorders (e.g., schizophrenia).
PI_NAMEs: DAW, NATHANIEL DOUGLASS;NORMAN, KENNETH A (contact);WITTEN, ILANA

PROJECT_TITLE: NRSA Training Grant in Quantitative Neuroscience

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Rapid and inexpensive DNA sequencing technologies have revolutionized medicine by revealing the landscape of mutations that contribute to human disease. Over the next decade, whole genome sequencing of many thousands of individuals, coupled with novel genome editing approaches to determine the impact of specific human mutations in experimental model systems, will provide unprecedented insight into disease mechanisms and empower new strategies for prevention, diagnosis and treatment. This training program will train the next generation of scientists to be able to take full advantage of this sea change in human genetics and prepare them for productive careers in science that will lead to improved human health.
PROJECT_TERMS: Genetic;Genomics;human disease
PROJECT_TITLE: Genetics and Genomics of Human Disease

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this training grant renewal, Training Program in Population Studies, is to provide exceptional demographic training to the next generation of social and behavioral scientists. Through mentoring, coursework, and professional socialization, our predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows will learn the necessary skills to identify, analyze, and produce scholarship critical to addressing society’s pressing social and public health issues. Our predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows will benefit from the innovative and high-quality scholarship and expertise of our training faculty and they will learn to conduct research with the highest ethical research standards, scientific rigor, and reproducibility.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Tissue resident macrophages have critical functions in maintaining tissue homeostasis and in the pathogenesis of many human diseases, including Alzheimer’s Disease and multiple sclerosis and in HIV infection. This project will fill a critical need by providing validated humanized platforms for investigating human tissue resident macrophages in vivo during development of disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Basic and translational research featuring neotropical primates is growing nationally and globally, but the development of immunological reagents specifically tailored for these animals continues to lag. To optimize the utility of the two most commonly used neotropical primates, we propose to deeply characterize the immunoglobulin repertoire of marmosets, squirrel monkeys, and owl monkeys and engineer species-matched antibodies for lymphocyte depletion. Additional cross-reactive diagnostic antibodies will be identified or generated de novo to support investigators conducting studies in established models of neurodegenerative, infectious, and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to purchase a Bruker ultra-high preclinical magnet to replace the obsolete 14 Tesla Magnex magnet procured in 2009, which has been dedicated to supporting the high-resolution anatomical and functional mapping of animals and ex-vivo human brain tissue imaging. The upgraded 15.2T preclinical scanner will support over 20 highly synergistic and collaborative research projects, in three main themes: 1) Neurovascular dynamic signaling, 2) Cutting-edge neuroimaging methodology, 3) Multimodal mechanistic signatures of animal disease models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a complex disease, and understanding its complexity is critical for creating new clinical therapies to control the current diabetes epidemic, better treat its complications, and lead to an eventual cure. Because engineering approaches have proven useful for solving complex biomedical problems, we propose to train a new multi-disciplinary work force with the skills needed to integrate both engineering and diabetes research approaches. This will be accomplished through formal course work and an unconventional dual mentor arrangement, where each student or postdoctoral trainee is supervised by one advisor with an engineering background and another from the diabetes research field.
PROJECT_TERMS: Diabetes Mellitus;Engineering;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Integrated Training in Engineering and Diabetes
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Diabetes, Endocrinology and Metabolic Diseases B Study Section[DDK-B]

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: We aim to plan and develop rapid imaging instrumentation deployment in DOE, software workflows, data sharing and visualization mechanisms, and educational software towards broad community access to a state- of-the-art, 3-dimensional form of histology, X-ray histotomography, that enables the study of all cell types in whole cm-scale organisms and tissue samples. The proposed work includes pilot studies to image samples at an unprecedented combination of 5 mm field-of-view (FOV) with 0.5 μm isotropic resolution at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and 10 cm FOV/0.7 μm resolution at Argonne National Laboratory, that will be paired with rapid access to web-based instructional material, to facilitate web-based image and file access, and to set the stage for community-based generation of tools for computational tissue phenotyping. The positive impacts of accessible histotomography are expected to advance our understanding of cells and tissues in organismal context, including the study of genetic, environmental, and disease determinants of phenotype, and facilitate the development of shared computational tools across disciplines in biology, toxicology, biosphere monitoring, and disease diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the leading cause of death worldwide and substantial residual CVD risk persists despite effective LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C) lowering. In this context, we propose an investigation of mechanisms of plaque stabilization and destabilization focused on novel functions of vascular macrophages and stromal cells, and their crosstalk, in mouse models and human CVD. Our overarching theme, pursued through three highly integrated Projects and two Scientific Cores is that inflammation and the efferocytosis-resolution cycle in macrophages regulates plaque stability through crosstalk with other macrophages and stromal cells and that detailed examination of the cell and molecular mechanisms may provide opportunities for novel CVD treatments, including in patients with clonal hematopoiesis, an emerging CVD risk factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite medical advances for the treatment of osteopetrosis, all available therapies require conditioning treatment for cell engraftment. Here we propose to combine CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing for correction of osteopetrosis-causing mutations in the Clcn7 gene with autologous infusions that do not require conditioning to restore bone resorption in experimental osteopetrosis, with potential implications for the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Quantitative Biological Systems Training (QBIST) program aims to equip biology PhD trainees from diverse backgrounds with robust quantitative and computational skills and to provide training in mentoring, leadership, and professional skills, thereby preparing scientists for a variety of careers in the biomedical research enterprise. The QBIST program will study the impact on training and research outcomes of an integrated quantitative curriculum and activities that incorporate formal instruction and facilitated experience in leadership and mentoring. In addition, by implementing a non-academic internship and entrepreneurial program, the QBIST program will expose trainees to careers outside the traditional academic track, and assess the impact of these activities on trainee career preparedness and perceptions of training utility.
PROJECT_TERMS: biological systems;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: The Quantitative Biological Systems Training (QBIST) Program
