IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to build a rigorous training program that enables PhD graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to become translational researchers who seek to understand muscle biology and decipher the mechanisms of its dysfunction in order to develop innovative strategies for effective diagnosis and treatment of muscular dystrophies (MDs). We emphasize highly collaborative multidisciplinary team science with exposure to both rigorous basic and clinical MD research.
PROJECT_TERMS: Muscle;Research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: MAXIMUS: MAXimizing Training in MUScle Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative This T32 training grant continues to successfully train the scientists of tomorrow in aging research at Einstein. This success is based on the quality of candidates, their scientific and academic achievements, the percent of trainees who have stayed in research, and the number of minority individuals trained. Within our highly collaborative environment lies a strong emphasis on translational research from a diverse group of mentors who are well-funded and who have access to a diverse pool of well-qualified trainees. We continue the Biology of Aging class developed specifically for this grant and our highly successful hackathon to teach rigor and reproducibility, while also adding new and diverse mentors and activities to enrich the training experience.
PROJECT_TERMS: Aging;Research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Aging Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Precision medicine holds promise for enhancing best care options at the patient level, thereby closing disparity gaps (caused by inefficient or non-tailored, “one size fits all” therapies) leading to immediate and meaningful impact on population health. The Kansas Institute for Precision Medicine through Phase 2 COBRE funding will provide promising junior investigators with a focused mentoring experience that will help them mature into independently-funded investigators who will contribute to the advancement and clinical realization of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to treat disorders and injuries of the nervous system requires a detailed understanding of the molecules, cells, and circuits that drive behavior. Modern neuroscience techniques for analyzing brain function across these scales can generate increasingly large and complex data sets, requiring sophisticate quantitative tools and reasoning to extract biological meaning. We propose a new postdoctoral training program at the Salk Institute: “Quantitative Neuroscience Spanning Molecules, Cells, Circuits, and Behavior” that will provide the next generation of neuroscientists with the research experience, quantitative literacy, and professional skill sets necessary to tackle daunting challenges in neuroscience, launch productive careers, and create diverse and supportive research environments.
PROJECT_TERMS: Behavior;Cells;Neurosciences
PROJECT_TITLE: Quantitative Neuroscience Spanning Molecules, Cells, Circuits, and Behavior

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Racial/ethnic disparities in obesity among youths persist. The proposal aims to elucidate the influence of both neighborhood and interpersonal discrimination on the risk of obesity among children and adolescents. The study will provide a comprehensive examination for how discrimination impacts youth, shedding light on (1) the behavioral processes involved, (2) protective factors that may mitigate the risk, and (3) the broader implications for racial/ethnic disparities in obesity that can be extrapolated to the entire U.S. population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences): Native American groups are among the most under-represented groups across STEM disciplines, including Aging Sciences. This disparity has arisen from a number of historical and institutional challenges. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cadmium is a food chain contaminant that is present in crop species (particularly cereal grains like wheat and rice), at concentrations that sometimes exceed safe limits for human consumption and has significant neurotoxicological effects at low doses especially in pediatric population. Toxic trace heavy metals such as cadmium have chemical properties similar to essential micronutrients such as zinc (Zn) and are generally transported in plants by transporters of essential micronutrients. The overall goal of this research is to elucidate the transport of cadmium from root to seed in order to improve zinc density in food crops like wheat and concomitantly reduce the possible dietary exposure to cadmium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Kean University U-RISE Trainee Pathway will expand and enhance recruitment and training of undergraduate students in the conduct of rigorous, responsible research in biomedical fields. The goal is to increase the diversity and number of students graduating with bachelor of science degrees, entering and graduating from PhD programs, and joining the research workforce. Strengthening the biomedical research workforce will speed medical progress, ultimately improving healthcare for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT PEMBROKE
PHR: The UNCP U-RISE program aims to prepare undergraduate students underrepresented in the sciences for admission into biomedical PhD degree programs. Through mentored research experiences, career exploration, and guidance from faculty research mentors, program staff and peer mentors, trainees will gain the skills and experience needed to complete graduate degrees in STEM fields. This program will prepare a diverse cohort of biology, chemistry and physics majors with the skills to successfully complete their PhD degrees and successfully transition to careers in the biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The double helix DNA structure was discovered seven decades ago, but our understanding about how DNA is replicated is still limited, particularly in eukaryotic cells. Recent advance in cryo-EM has made it feasible to study the structure and molecular mechanism of chromosome replication as carried out by the coordinated efforts of several molecular machines such as the replicative CMG helicase, the polymerase-primase complex Pol α, and the leading and lagging strand DNA polymerases Pol ε and Pol δ. Because replication errors and insufficient repair of these errors underlie many human diseases such as cancers, studying the molecular mechanism of eukaryotic DNA replication is important for fundamental biology as well as for understanding of and developing treatment for cancers and many other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Advancements in basic, translational and clinical research on rheumatological diseases have culminated in the dawn of precision medicine that aims to deliver big-data-informed, pathway-specific targeted diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic strategies with enhanced accuracy, efficacy and reduced toxicity. This long- standing UCSD Rheumatology T32 program will also focus on expanding collaboration with our community. The proposed renewal of the UCSD T32 program will provide resources and infrastructure to recruit and train a new generation of postdoctoral as well predoctoral students early in their research careers.
PROJECT_TERMS: Grant;Research Training;Rheumatism
PROJECT_TITLE: Rheumatic Diseases Research Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal application seeks continued support for the training of Pre-doctoral and Post-doctoral students in the Neurobiology of Aging and Alzheimer’s Disease. We aspire to train the next generation of research scientists with an enhanced emphasis cutting edge technology, team science and large collaborative initiatives in multiple aspects of basic and translational neuroscience to delay and treat age-related cognitive decline and neurodegenerative diseases. A strong foundation in basic science, tight integration with clinical research, and opportunities for translational research goals will assure a steady source of new talent that will stimulate the field and generate novel approaches to these problems.
PROJECT_TERMS: Aging;Alzheimer's Disease;Neurobiology;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in the Neurobiology of Aging and Alzheimers Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NMSU U-RISE will contribute to broadening participation and retention of undergraduate students from Historically Excluded Communities (HECs) in research areas of interest to the National Institutes of Health. To accomplish this goal, NMSU has assembled a two-year research education program for Junior- level students comprised of a) a thoroughly immersive research program, b) an inclusive and affirming educational seminar series built into students’ curriculum, c) a mentorship education that promotes faculty- student relationships to be grounded in open communication, support and allyship, and d) expansion of research experiences to NMSU students in the agricultural sciences and social-public health fields at NMSU. This program seeks to strengthen inclusive, equitable, and diverse scientific environments at NMSU that will welcome different perspectives, spark the most innovative ideas, and improve our research education programs for current and future scientists from HECs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To contribute to building a diverse pool of well-trained scientists in the biomedical research workforce, the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) Maximizing Access to Research Careers (MARC) Program will provide up to two years of mentored research, education, and career development activities for ten undergraduates (scholars) every two years (matriculating five each year) from groups underrepresented in biomedical research for preparation and transition into PhD or MD-PhD programs. Scholars will be matched with experienced, funded UAB faculty preceptors, who will mentor them and provide high quality research experiences in biomedical sciences. The program curriculum will be tailored to each scholars’ needs to prepare them for success in doctoral training, and will address objectives that include critical thinking, quantitative skills development, scientific writing, presentation skills, ethics in research, networking, research career and exposure readiness, and preparation for graduate school, with scholars’ progress assessed quarterly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: To date, no intervention has proven efficacious for improving the low rate of undetectable VL in women with HIV who engage in sex work. We propose a clinical trial to test the effectiveness of Motivation Matters!, a promising mHealth intervention for improving the rate of undetectable viral load in this key population. In parallel, we will conduct implementation research to examine intervention fidelity, feasibility, acceptability, appropriateness, cost, patient-centeredness, satisfaction, and engagement.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) with increasing prevalence presents a heavy socioeconomic burden, but the root cause of T2D remains unclear. We propose to understand the role of placenta mitochondria in predisposing T2D in offspring in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), using human tissues as well as a novel mouse GDM model. The expected findings will yield important insights into the study of placental mitochondrial dysfunction, and into potential therapeutic means for GDM and GDM predisposed T2D in offspring during maternal pregnancy, thus breaking the vicious cycle of diabetes and pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addiction is a major determinant of mortality and societal burden. Despite high public health significance of the problem, treatment and prevention of drug addiction are only modestly effective. The UCLA Training Program in the Translational Neuroscience of Drug Addiction (TNDA) provides multidisciplinary training that spans the fundamental bases of addiction from the genome to neural phenotypes and ultimately the syndrome of addiction, with particular strength in molecular and cellular, behavioral and systems, and cognitive and clinical neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Pain and substance use disorders (SUDs) are highly prevalent, commonly co-occurring and confer a tremendous toll on society. There is an urgent need to train interdisciplinary researchers who can better characterize these important conditions and translate discoveries to safe and effective treatments. The aim of this postdoctoral training program is to develop the next generation of scientific leaders in pain and SUDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative While current therapeutic approaches for epilepsy primarily focus on symptom management and seizure suppression, there remains a critical gap in targeting the underlying processes of brain reorganization (epileptogenesis) in individuals with epilepsy. The primary goals of this study encompass the following objectives: 1) identifying neuroanatomical and molecular mechanisms by which the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus (VMH) is involved in epileptogenic processes and 2) determining the genomic landscape of the epileptogenic processes in the VMH using spatial transcriptomics. By elucidating mechanisms and signaling pathways regulating the reorganizational processes in the VMH that lead to brainstem-tonic seizures and increased risk for Sudden Unexpected Death in EPilepsy (SUDEP), potential druggable targets for epilepsy and/or SUDEP can be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gaps in neurologic health and access to healthcare for neurologic disorders, further amplified by the COVID-19 pandemic, are widening in the US and worldwide. To translate knowledge about health disparities into evidence-based interventions that improve neurologic outcomes for the most underserved and vulnerable populations, clinician researchers and PhD scientists need rigorous training and mentoring in health equity research methods, which are largely lacking from neurology research training programs. The proposed ENgaging Leaders In Global and local HealTh Equity in Neurology (ENLIGHTEN) fellowship was developed in direct response to the need for a cohesive interdisciplinary training program in neurologic health equity research methods for global and local settings.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed U-RISE program at the University of Hartford is to develop diverse students who will become leaders in biomedical research fields. We will accomplish these goals via two specific aims, 1) To increase the number of undergraduate UHart students from underrepresented backgrounds who are interested in pursuing careers in biomedical research, and 2) To develop the research, critical thinking, and science communication skills of U-RISE trainees. The goal of the U-RISE training Program is aligned with UHart’s priorities making us an ideal institution to support undergraduate students from underrepresented backgrounds as they begin their training in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in understanding of energy balance regulation and mechanisms underlying obesity pathogenesis requires approaches that enable effective and accurate measures of energy expenditure, energy intake, substrate oxidation and physical activity. For more than two decades, the University of Washington Nutrition Obesity Research Center (NORC) Energy Balance Core has provided investigators with access to state-of-the- art rodent metabolic phenotyping services for studies related to nutrition, obesity and metabolism using a metabolic cage system that has not kept up with technological advances, and is no longer repairable, should a system failure occur. In this application, we request funding to purchase a new Sable Systems Promethion Core system, which will dramatically improve throughput of services provided to our investigators; provide several new and exciting capabilities, including the ability to interface with sophisticated neuroscience technologies, use of stable isotopes to measure substrate oxidation, and computer-controlled food access; and ensure that existing commitments to our research community are honored while offering state-of-the art support to the greater UW scientific community.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Most common human diseases are difficult to study because they are genetically complex. Conducting human genetic studies that include enough subjects with sufficiently detailed data to make definitive conclusions remains challenging, despite significant advances in genome technologies (e.g. DNA sequencing and editing). Most of these obstacles can be overcome by using standardized, genetically diverse laboratory mice, which offer known and reproducible genetic and phenotypic variation. The goal of the Special Mouse Strain Resource at The Jackson Laboratory is to: i) maintain and distribute these unique mouse populations to the biomedical research community, ii) further develop advanced resources for systems genetics and, iii) to provide leadership in best practices for research and reproducibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases are one of the leading causes of mortality in the United States, many of which are not well understood or treatable. This research will explore the underlying mechanisms of a recently identified mutant gene called TBK1 in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disease mainly attacking motor neurons, by investigating the impact on the nervous system when wild-type and mutant human TBK1 genes are expressed in fruit flies or when TBK1 orthologue IK2 gene function is perturbed. In the end, this research will provide a better understanding of ALS with the hope of developing effective therapeutic treatments.

Diversity in STEM research, higher education, and the workforce will drive the biomedical sciences forward, help to stimulate economic growth, and help create a more global and inclusive STEM community properly situated to address the needs of underrepresented populations, especially in chronic disease and health-related research. Inter-institutional opportunities are essential for providing future scientists with interdisciplinary training to address multifaceted health problems from a comprehensive perspective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
PHR: This study will shed light on a wide variety of genetic, prenatal, early-life and family factors that influence the risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and on differences and similarities in the behaviors, abilities, and health of preschoolers with ASD. It will also provide insights into the experiences of adolescents with ASD as they mature. By helping to explain the causes of ASD and how ASD affects children, youth and young adults, this project will contribute to efforts to reduce the risk of ASD and improve the outcomes of affected children.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Study to Explore Early Development (SEED) Follow up Studies, Components A, B, D & E

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We are seeking renewal funding for our graduate training program at Portland State University (PSU) in an under-represented, but growing discipline of Occupational Safety and Health, namely, Occupational Health Psychology (OHP). OHP is an interdisciplinary field that involves the application of psychological principles for improving the quality of work-life and for promoting the safety, health, and well-being of people at work. OHP researchers and practitioners draw from the domains of public health, preventive medicine, nursing, industrial engineering, law, epidemiology, and psychology to develop sound theory and practice for protecting and promoting safety, health, and well-being in the workplace. We are seeking to innovate this training by expanding to include Total Worker Health®.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Graduate Training in Occupational Health Psychology and Total Worker Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Appalachian Training Program in Occupational Health and Safety Project Narrative Appalachia is arguably one of the most underserved regions in the country, with an unacceptably high burden of occupational disease and injuries. The Occupational Medicine, Industrial Hygiene, and Occupational Safety and Health Engineering programs produce skilled professionals who understand the workplaces of this rural area, diagnose and treat injured workers, focus upon use of engineering to measure and identify hazards, understand failure modes and effects to engineer out such hazards and who are prepared for and dedicated to the public health aspects of mitigation and prevention in the region. This is the only NIOSH- supported Training Project Grant in Occupational Medicine and one of two in Occupational Safety and Industrial Hygiene located in the entire Appalachian region, comprising portions of 14 states.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Appalachian Training Program in Occupational Health and Safety

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: The National Mesothelioma Virtual Bank (NMVB) collects tumor tissue, blood samples and other protein, genomic and imaging data from consented patients with mesothelioma. Biospecimens from patients with documented occupational exposure to asbestos as well as de-identified clinical and research data are then made available for research studies. Investigators can search the study database to identify and request specific cohorts via the NMVB website which is the largest and most accessible resource for this rare and fatal disease.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Continuation and Expansion of the National Mesothelioma Virtual Bank for Translational Research (U24) - 2021

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The acid sensing ion channels (ASICs) induce neuronal death during persistent cerebral acidosis and contribute to brain damage following ischemia. This proposal will test novel methods to inhibit ASIC dependent cell death without impacting ASIC’s physiological function. The proposed work will have broad implications for the prevention of injury following ischemic stroke and other disorders accompanied by cerebral acidosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compounds capable of promoting neuroplasticity, such as ketamine and serotonergic psychedelics, have enormous potential for treating neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases characterized by cortical atrophy, but their hallucinogenic effects limit their clinical scalability. Recently, our group discovered that it is possible to engineer non-hallucinogenic analogs of psychedelics capable of promoting neuroplasticity after a single administration and producing sustained therapeutic effects across disease indications. The research described here seeks to establish new synthetic strategies for accessing plasticity-promoting compounds as well as methods for evaluating their efficacy, safety, and mechanisms of action—information that will ultimately lead to the development of new treatments for diseases such as depression, posttraumatic stress disorder, substance use disorder, Alzheimer’s disease, and Parkinson’s disease, among others.

The proposed research will address the fundamental questions of whether specific signaling pathways can be activated by EGFR inside the cells from endosomes and examines the mechanisms regulating this endosomal signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular growth, development, movement and communication absolutely require accurate intracellular cargo transport by vesicle targeting and membrane fusion. Essential components of these fundamental cell biological processes are the exocyst complex, Sec1, SNARE proteins, and their regulatory partners. These mechanisms are conserved from yeast to man, and have been implicated in a variety of human diseases, such as cancer, diabetes, ciliopathies, and infections by pathogens. Our multidisciplinary studies will lead to a molecular understanding of the regulation of vesicle tethering and membrane fusion. In addition, our research will also lead to the development of many technologies, constructs, reagents and ideas that will be valuable tools for studying how these factors regulate secretion in all eukaryotic cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Over-nutrition and obesity are important contributors to the cardiovascular disease epidemic in the United States and worldwide. A major reason for the increase in cardiovascular disease is the rapidly increasing prevalence of obesity in both adults and children, many of whom will develop cardiovascular disease, and so the burden on our society is tremendous. The Nutrition, Obesity and Atherosclerosis Training Program trains new generations of postdoctoral MD clinician-scientists and PhD scientists to tackle these problems, taking advantage of the multidisciplinary and broad training environment at the University of Washington.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / LAY SUMMARY This project explores how the cholangiocyte epigenome and downstream signaling pathways influence the progression of Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis, a serious liver disease with no effective therapy except liver transplant. We explore the molecular mechanisms that determine if cholangiocytes arrest in the cell cycle (become senescent) or proliferate (resist senescence), and how these two cholangiocyte populations influence the development of fibrosis. If successful, the results could lead to new and effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall goal of the proposed research is to elucidate the multi-step mechanisms by which platelets form hemostatic clots, and mimic and integrate these mechanisms on lipid-peptide based nanoparticle systems to create `artificial platelet' constructs that can be used for transfusion treatment of bleeding complications. Platelet transfusion can significantly save lives in heavy bleeding scenarios (e.g. trauma) but platelets are unavailable in limited resource hospitals and in civilian and military roadside/emergency medicine framework; this is where proposed `artificial platelets' can provide a unique technology solution to rapidly stanch bleeding and save lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative The relationship between periodontitis and type II diabetes (T2D), co-occurring diseases that are among the most prevalent chronic illnesses in the US, is characterized by the former’s ability to increase the risk of severe diabetic complications, including death, in patients with both diseases. This project aims to understand the effect of periodontitis, and its associated mouth microbiome dysbiosis, on metabolic dysfunction in T2D. This project has an immediate impact on the understanding of periodontitis pathophysiology in systemic metabolic dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Technological advancements in stem cells, gene therapy, and retinal prostheses show great promise for restoring or providing new light sensitivity to retinas of the blind; however, understanding of the basic circuitry for daylight vision lags behind the technology to provide light sensitivity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative This project will apply what we have learned about the way in which carbon-based nanomaterials behave chemically in order to restore function to tissue damaged by free radicals and, to develop a new therapy for severe traumatic brain injury by modifying a starting material that is already used in patients, activated charcoal. If successful, starting with this material may speed the possibility of developing a treatment that can be used in humans. Because the kinds of damage that traumatic brain injury causes is also seen in other disorders such as those associated with aging, there is a broad potential for this therapeutic approach in some of our most serious debilitating conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because defining how antibiotic-mediated microbiome disruption contributes to complications such as obesity and diabetes may, in the long run, identify ways to alleviate these conditions for millions of Americans. This work will define the impacts of antibiotics on the metabolic environment of the murine gut, host metabolite availability and weight gain. In addition to generating fundamental scientific discoveries, this research will also fulfill NIH goals by generating a mechanistic perspective on how antibiotics contribute to diabetes, digestive diseases, nutritional disorders, and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project is of direct relevance to Alzheimer’s disease, as we are studying the genetic variance found in immune populations from the CNS, microglia. We will be examining the interaction of HSV-1 infection, immune cells, and genetic susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE ColQ CMS is a rare neuromuscular disorder with no cure associated. Severe limb-girdle pattern of weakness, choking spells, respiratory insufficiency, severe scoliosis present early on during the disease progression with early death not uncommon among these patients. This project aims to validate the safety and efficacy of a new gene therapy product for ColQ CMS able to transform clinical practice from chronic administration of drugs to alleviate symptoms to a one-off, non-pharmacological treatment, administered through a single intravenous injection. The project is expected to unveil important insights on the mechanism of action of Neuromuscular Junction as well to explore the existence of a shared gene therapy development pathway for CMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of the proposed research is to integrate individual-level data from eight state agencies and county-level data from multiple open data sources and develop a prediction model for multiple viral load indicators through AI-based modeling, accounting for factors at the individual level, structural level, and socioenvironmental level among people living with HIV (PLWH) in South Carolina. The results will enable the identification of PLWH with poor viral control and further inform healthcare providers of “when” and “how” to help those PLWH achieve and maintain viral suppression. The proposed research will improve our understanding of the longitudinal dynamics of viral suppression and inform effective HIV control strategies towards the goal of ending the HIV epidemic in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Lysosomal storage diseases (>40 different diseases) are often fatal in pediatric subjects. They are caused by a specific protein deficiency that breaks down waste products within the cell. For several of these diseases, gene therapy clinical trials are ongoing or about to start, but there is no way to track their therapeutic efficacy. We have developed a series of MRI based contrast agents that are able to non-invasively track the therapeutic protein. In this proposal, we will perform the necessary experiments to translate to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatoblastoma (HB) is the most common liver cancer in children with a survival rate of <50% in patients with high-risk disease, especially those with vascular invasion (VI). Unfortunately, HB with VI patients receive aggressive therapies that are toxic and ineffective; therefore, a better understanding of the biomarkers and biology of VI in HB is urgently needed. In the current study, we propose to study the protein expression of HB cells that invade the blood vessels to create prediction models and targeted treatments for patients with high- risk HB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The choroid plexus (ChP) produces and delivers important health- and growth-promoting factors to the  , developing brain. We will use cutting-edge methods for monitoring and manipulating calcium activity in ChP epithelial cells in explants and in vivo to test whether ChP epithelial cell calcium activity increases in response to local and maternally derived stimuli and thereby regulates brain development via regulation in ChP gene transcription and protein secretion into the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). These experiments represent a critical new direction of investigation into how local embryonic and maternal-fetal environments interact with the ChP to dynamically regulate brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Faithful replication of cellular DNA is of the highest importance in maintaining the integrity of genetic information. Often, replication goes wrong because of the presence of DNA damage or other problems, leading to the activation of several DNA damage response pathways. Patients with known defects in these pathways are at a greatly increased risk for developing cancer. These processes are highly conserved from human to baker's yeast, and therefore, studies in this biochemically and genetically approachable model organism are highly relevant to understanding the analogous processes in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung transplant extends the lives of patients with advanced lung disease, but long-term survival is limited by development of chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD). To reduce CLAD and improve lung transplant outcomes, including both survival and quality of life, we propose a clinical trial testing a novel drug that prevents inflammatory cytokine signaling with complementary mechanistic studies to determine treatment effects on innate and adaptive immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our ability to finely control gene expression and chromatin state over time at specific genomic loci and genome- wide has improved vastly in the last decades due to the development of programmable DNA binding domains, but it is currently limited by the availability of potent, compact, and versatile effector domains that can be easily delivered, multiplexed, and act efficiently in different genomic and chromatin contexts. To fill this gap and create a comprehensive resource defining the functional effector domains that regulate gene transcription, we will use a high-throughput platform that we have recently developed to systematically test thousands of putative transcriptional and chromatin effector domains from human transcription factors, viral proteins, and nanobody libraries for their effects on gene activation, repression, and epigenetic memory. Characterization of these effectors in terms of their interaction partners, associated chromatin modifications, and effects at different types of endogenous loci will allow us to develop a novel and extensive toolbox for reliable transcriptional and chromatin perturbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylcoccus aureus (S. aureus) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. One of the most clinically significant aspects of S. aureus infections is the high prevalence of drug resistance and the innate ability for S. aureus to develop resistance to antibiotics making it very difficult to develop therapeutics that will have potential for long-term efficacy against S. aureus. Given the diminishing effectiveness of our current antibiotics, it is clear we must improve our understanding of molecular mechanisms fundamental to S. aureus pathogenesis in order to develop better methods to control/treat S. aureus disease and, thus, improve public health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Inadvertent fetal exposure to excess steroids or steroid mimics poses risks to reproductive and metabolic health in humans. Using a novel animal model and dietary interventions, the proposed studies will identify neural, ovarian and metabolic mechanisms by which fetal exposure to excess steroids and postnatal obesity lead to fertility problems in first- and second-generation female offspring. Moreover, these studies aim to identify lifestyle intervention strategies to not only ameliorate the pathology but, more importantly, to prevent transfer of disease traits to subsequent generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This application addresses several important central issues that have broad application in the areas of virus-host interactions, innate immunity, cellular transformation, and viral oncolysis of cancer cells. The proposed studies will demonstrate the role of key and potent viral modulator of cellular factors of the RNA helicase superfamily that mediate expanded cellular tropism, particularly in human cells, how two key viral host range factors modulation of multiple signaling pathways benefit the virus replication and expand the cellular tropism of the virus and their potential oncolysis of cancer cells. The model virus proposed here is Myxoma virus (MYXV), which infects only rabbits in nature, but has significant potential for the treatment of multiple human cancers and the findings can be applicable for other oncolytic viruses as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aortopathy including aneurysms, dissection, and rupture are life-threatening diseases that have no validated medications. The only therapeutic option is watchful waiting prior to major surgical intervention. This project will provide novel mechanistic insight into these diseases that will enable more focused efforts in understanding the disease pathogenesis and developing medical treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Cardiovascular calcification is a highly prevalent process whereby bone mineral forms in the heart tissue and blood vessels, and it contributes to a number of debilitating cardiovascular diseases, including chronic heart failure and myocardial infarction. Recent work has implicated endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT) in the development of cardiovascular calcification, but while agents targeting the EndMT process may be promising, the current assessments of EndMT have inherent limitations that impede our ability to efficiently evaluate the efficacies of investigative therapies. In this proposal, we aim to characterize a novel component of EndMT– its mechanical properties or “mechanophenotype” – with the goal of developing innovative platforms to investigate the mechanobiological mechanisms of EndMT, and to identify and test therapeutic targets for EndMT and cardiovascular calcification in a high-throughput, resource-efficient manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The lung contains resident memory immune cells that are established in the setting of local infection, and are crucial in protecting the host from future pulmonary infections by related, but different pathogens. Despite recent research advances, pulmonary infections are still a major cause of death worldwide, and vaccines that elicit protective heterotypic immunity do not exist for many respiratory pathogens. Here, we propose studies aimed at defining mechanisms of establishment and function of lung resident memory B cells, as advancing our understanding of how lung B cells mediate heterotypic immunity will aid in the development of effective vaccines for respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammograms can serve a dual function - screening for breast cancer and looking for evidence of cardiovascular disease (breast arterial calcification, BAC) – without additional radiation to the patient, without increasing mammography appointment length, and adding only minimally to breast radiologist time. Reporting BAC directly to patients as part of standard mammography practice could uniquely promote prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of cardiovascular disease in women, which is the main cause of death among women in the United States. The primary goals of this study are to investigate the effects of informing patients about their BAC results (versus a Waitlist Control) on their cardiovascular health behaviors (attending a cardiovascular appointment, improving heart healthy behavior) and on their likelihood of receiving a diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is responsible for a significant proportion of liver disease deaths, yet there are no FDA-approved therapies for the treatment of any stage of its progression, and the underlying mechanisms of disease progression are still under investigation. Mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphatase 1 (MKP-1), a key regulator of tissue inflammation and injury, is downregulated in the livers of alcohol-fed mice and ethanol-exposed hepatocytes. Complete assessment of the role of decreased MKP-1 expression in both hepatocytes and immune cells in the progression of ALD might lead to novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Toxoplasma gondii is the leading cause of infectious retinitis worldwide and is a neglected parasitic infection in the United States with over 11% of the population testing seropositive. Recent work conducted by the Subauste lab has demonstrated that T. gondii can manipulate host cell signaling to prevent degradation by the autophagolysosome, thus preventing this signaling can result in therapeutic implications by promoting autophagic eradication of the parasite. The mechanism for autophagosome formation during T. gondii infection has yet to be elucidated and will identify a possible novel mechanism of selective autophagy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic variation dictates an individual’s risk of developing common ailments such as heart and blood diseases. Traditionally, it has been difficult to determine which of the millions of sequence variants influence disease susceptibility due to a lack of technologies that enable the causal assignment of genetic variants at scale. To address this unmet need, we will develop a generalizable pipeline that leverages technological breakthroughs in precise genome editing to unravel the functional impact of genetic variation on heart and blood disease risk, offering a rich catalog of the consequences of thousands of disease-associated variants that will be of broad utility to the Impact of Genomic Variation on Function (IGVF) Consortium and wider biomedical community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative  The development, differentiation and functional maturation of the salivary gland is a tightly regulated process that requires the coordinated activity of important transcriptional networks and signaling pathways. This application focuses on examining the gene-regulatory mechanisms, and in particular the role of the transcription factor Xbp-1, in directing morphogenesis, cellular identity and fate. Such studies will lead to an improved understanding of the inner workings of the salivary gland and can provide molecular insights into regeneration processes that can help patients with salivary gland dysfunction.

PHR: Current functional near-infrared spectroscopy systems have some technical restrictions that limit the extent of whole brain functional imaging. In this application, we propose to develop a whole brain, functional near- infrared spectroscopy system that is sensitive and rapid enough for assessing brain hemodynamic activity in infants. This imaging technique will allow economical, bedside diagnostics for prognostication and, hopefully in the future, strategic therapeutic interventions that can positively alter outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The underlying mechanisms by which variants modify Alzheimer's disease risk remain unknown. This proposal combines patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells and innovative xeno-transplantation techniques to experimentally investigate the impact of disease risk modifying variants on cellular function of disease-relevant microglia in vitro and in vivo. The work here has the potential to greatly impact public health through enhancing our understanding of how genes, and their variants within them, affect immune cell function and modify disease risk and evaluating the therapeutic potential of a disease-modifying drug.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Epilepsy is a devastating neurological illness, affecting over 50 million people world-wide. In this project, we will leverage the ENIGMA-Epilepsy infrastructure to address how quantitative, non-invasive neuroimaging, clinical and genetic data can be used to predict (1) which patients will respond to anti-seizure medications versus which will remain drug-resistant and (2) which patients will achieve favorable versus unfavorable surgical outcomes. The research will be accomplished by applying a series of hypothesis-driven and data- driven (i.e., machine learning) approaches to clinical and imaging data on an exceptionally large cohort of patients with common epilepsy syndromes, providing unprecedented power to tackle critical treatment-related questions in epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This work will contribute significantly to what is known about the mechanisms promoting regeneration in living adult animals. By using complimentary genetic and genome-wide approaches in the Drosophila testis, we will identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms that enable tissues to sense damage and then activate a program to regenerate missing stem cells. These mechanisms are of strong general interest, as they will suggest successful therapeutic strategies for achieving healthy tissue regeneration more generally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This training grant provides a summer research experience for medical students at Wake Forest School of Medicine with research focus on diabetes, digestive and kidney disease, obesity, and related disorders. It has the goal to inspire medical students to become involved in research during subsequent specialty training and careers as health care providers. Dedicated faculty mentors allow students a first-hand experience conducting state-of-the-art biomedical research in the context of a learning healthcare system, supplemented by didactic seminars and workshops, to communicate to medical students how clinical care and research should inform each other, with the goal of providing more benefit to patients and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BCL-2 family proteins are essential arbiters of programmed cell death during development and homeostasis and when deregulated contribute to the development, maintenance, and chemoresistance of human cancers. A critical missing link in our understanding of the apoptotic pathway is how BAX, an essential executioner protein, self-assembles into higher-order oligomers to permeabilize the mitochondrial outer membrane. The goal of my research is to harness cutting-edge nanobody technology and the first homogeneous species of oligomeric BAX to provide new structural insight into the execution phase of BAX-mediated apoptosis and thereby inform new opportunities to modulate BAX for therapeutic benefit in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE AND RELEVANCE  Policies regulating marijuana retail sale have been designed and implemented in the absence of scientific knowledge about how individuals make purchase decisions and what regulatory measures would be effective to reduce problem marijuana use. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to test a series of hypotheses on the relationships between recreational marijuana regulatory strategies and individual preferences for marijuana products. As recreational marijuana legalization and commercialization continue to be adopted, our study findings are expected to provide critical public health implications regarding marijuana regulation and control in the new legal regime.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PREP Project Narrative Our postbac research education program will continue to develop and train underrepresented minorities to acquire skills needed to succeed in Ph.D. programs in behavioral and biomedical Sciences and Engineering at top universities. The skills developed include training in interdisciplinary research, critical thinking, mentoring and advising, networking and presentation skills (writing and communication). These activities continue to positively impact the number of minorities who go on to receive PhDs and to subsequently pursue careers in biomedical or behavioral research, which is a major goal of the PHS.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Breastfeeding peer counseling (BPC) programs have proven effective at promoting social and economic equity in breastfeeding and reducing maternal and infant morbidity and mortality, but uptake of BPC programs in clinical settings (ci-BPC) has been limited. This study will fill a critical knowledge gap by evaluating the implementation of an effective ci-BPC program and determining essential program activities, relevant contextual factors, and patient, program, system, and societal costs that are pertinent to decision-makers considering the utilization of ci-BPC. The results of this study will provide critical information to enable the design, implementation, and uptake of ci-BPC to advance perinatal health equity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Optimizing utilization of lay health workers to address maternal and child health disparities: A Comprehensive Evaluation of a clinically integrated Breastfeeding Peer Counseling Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: This proposal will investigate mechanisms by which bone is integrated with regulation of energy metabolism, and its dysregulation with aging. It will characterize a protein, which is already used as a pharmacological target to treat diabetes for its novel function in regulation of osteocyte energy utilization and activities supporting bone remodeling, and regulation of systemic energy metabolism. This knowledge is critical for the future research in which this protein will be selectively targeted in order to develop a therapy which will simultaneously improve bone quality and energy metabolism in elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the negative drinking consequences associated with drinking, young adults continue to engage in risky alcohol consumption, and believe that negative consequences are both unlikely and not very negative. The proposed project will fill an important gap in the alcohol expectancies literature by examining how peoples’ thoughts about the positive and negative consequences of alcohol use change both looking back on prior drinking events and looking forward at future drinking events (e.g., alcohol expectancies) to understand how thoughts and beliefs about drinking change over the short term. Results from the proposed project will identify how past consequences and future expectancy likelihoods and valences change over the short term which may inform future prevention and intervention efforts relating to challenging drinking thoughts and beliefs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of new chemical methods for organic synthesis is essential in the preparation of natural products and other bioactive molecules for preliminary biological studies, clinical trials, and production for market. Despite the advanced state of synthetic chemistry serious challenges remain. This proposal describes the development of new chemical reactions that will address one of these challenges, cross-electrophile coupling and cascade reactions that form tertiary stereogenic centers embedded in cyclopropanes and ring systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative. Many neurodegenerative diseases originate due to dysregulated lysosomal Ca2+ levels in brain cells. Diagnosing and treating these diseases requires information about lysosomal Ca2+ homeostasis, particularly on the different mechanisms of lysosomal Ca2+ import and release. We propose to deploy a new Ca2+ reporter in an innovative genetic model we have developed in order to identify and study novel mechanisms of lysosomal Ca2+ homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health, Project Narrative Through this project we will create a Data Administration and Coordinating Center (DACC) for the NHGRI Impact of Genomic Variation and Function (IGVF), which promises to transform our understanding of the associations between genetic variation and phenotype. Our proposed DACC will serve as the primary administration, communication, outreach and data center for IGVF awardees and provide leadership for standards and processing pipeline implementation, and facilitate FAIR databases and software. Due to our cross-cutting and unparalleled technical expertise in data management, genomics, informatics, network analysis, and privacy-preserving application as well as our role leading a large data coordination center, managing, coordinating data and metadata, as well as creating gold standard knowledgebases, Stanford is in a strong position to serve as the IGVF DACC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer-related cognitive impairment is a major public health burden that affects up to 75% of breast cancer survivors. The ENHANCE trial has the potential to expand treatment options for this prevalent, debilitating condition and to advance scientific understanding of acupuncture and its effects on cognition and sleep. This knowledge will improve quality of life and promote healthy cognitive aging for millions of cancer survivors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This revised proposal addresses HIV prevention and treatment for young couples through a comprehensive biobehavioral multilevel approach. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will uncover fundamental molecular mechanisms that regulate neural circuit development through interactions between cell surface proteins. Although our work is conducted in Drosophila, there is a subfamily of human proteins that corresponds to the Dprs and DIPs, called the IgLONs, which are important for neural circuit formation and have been linked to autism, schizophrenia, and dyslexia. By establishing how these proteins instruct precise neural circuit development, our work will build a foundation for clinical approaches to treat these debilitating diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 5% of US children and 45% of US adolescents have anxiety or depression; to identify effective treatment targets to address this growing concern we must first understand early childhood contributing factors. We will investigate the influence of early life stress and gut microbiome in relation to childhood and adolescent mental health. We will assess these questions using twins to identity genetic and environmental influences on mental health, which will pinpoint aspects of the environment, unrelated to genetic influences that are potential treatment targets for anxiety and depression.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: At the onset of COVID-19, primary care (PC) at the VA had a substantial increase in video-based encounters nationwide. However, this rapid uptake of video-based care during the pandemic varied by site. Given that the VA is committed to continue expanding VA Video Connect (VVC) as its videoconferencing platform, more research is needed to identify strategies to improve VVC use for all Veterans, nationally. [In-depth analysis of VA data will inform multilevel (patient, provider, site) characteristics and predictors of VVC use. Qualitative interviews with key stakeholders (patients, providers, and leadership) at identified high and low VVC sites, as well as qualitative analyses of VA documents from these selected sites, will allow us to develop patient-centered, provider-recommended, leadership-supported policies, procedures, and processes about how to improve delivery of VVC care at the VA. This 18-month pilot study will create context-specific VVC playbook for high and low VVC using sites, which will help improve delivery of video-based primary care at the VA.]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual reproduction in animals requires first the formation of primordial germ cells during embryogenesis since these cells are the progenitors of eggs and sperm in the adult. In mammals, these cells are selected by signaling between cells, whereas in some other vertebrates, these same cells are selected based on what they inherit from the egg. We will decode these distinct mechanisms, and how these cells can be regenerated, by use of non- mammalian model organisms enabling longitudinal analysis, direct visualization, and multiple state-of-the-art molecular technologies to understand the process at the heart of sexual reproduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) affects more than 10 million people in the U.S. and accounts for nearly half of the liver cirrhosis-associated deaths. Our preliminary studies have demonstrated that NOX2-deficient neutrophils exhibit an enhanced inflammatory phenotype and impairs resolution from alcohol-induced liver inflammation and injury. The current project aims to better understand the molecular mechanism(s) accounting for the functions of NOX2-deficient neutrophils and to evaluate the potential of targeting neutrophil-specific NOX2 as treatment for ALD. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Pyrazoles are an important class of bioactive molecules that are found in many FDA-approved drugs such as celecoxib (Celebrex®), a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory used to treat arthritis, and apixaban (Eliquis®), an anti-coagulant used to treat blood clots and prevent strokes. Although pyrazoles are commonly used in medicinal chemistry, their synthesis often relies on using potentially toxic hydrazine reagents in reactions with poor regiocontrol. A general synthesis of pyrazoles that avoids the use of these reagents is an unmet challenge. The objective of this proposal is to design a general synthesis of pyrazoles from alkynes and nitriles, forming the key N-N bond in the pyrazole using titanium catalysts. This strategy, and the related method for making N-N bonds and other heteroatom-carbon bonds, will allow synthetic chemists to access diverse molecular building blocks that will ultimately aid in widespread distribution of new drug-like architectures to the biomedical community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delivering goal-concordant care is a cornerstone of high-value palliative care and is considered the most important outcome measure for advanced care planning, but no gold standard for measurement exists. Consequently, this project will create a valid and reliable patient-reported experience measure (PREM) that measures goal-concordant care for seriously ill older adults with multiple chronic conditions (MCC), a vulnerable population who often face treatment tradeoffs that require difficult choices. In line with the NIH’s mission, this PREM establishes a patient-centered quality indicator for palliative care delivery that also provides point-of-care feedback to help clinicians better meet the dynamic needs of seriously ill older adults with MCC at both the patient- and population-level.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic/Latino (H/)L children have a 40% higher death rate of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) than Non-Hispanic Whites (NHW), after correcting for socioeconomic factor. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will explore the human stem cell model previously generated by our group for the incurable motor neuron disease: spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA). This work will elucidate the transcriptional regulation involved this disease in a human backgroung. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The signaling molecule ubiquitin controls many aspects of human biology. Despite its importance in numerous human diseases, the intricacies of how and where ubiquitin serves a signaling role are unknown. We study the means through which disease-causing bacteria hijack the ubiquitin signal as an approach to understanding its function in regulating human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients around the world underscore the fear, challenges, and toll accompanying diabetic retinopathy, a major progressive blinding disease. The proposed studies will advance our knowledge in explaining how diabetic retinopathy progresses to a later stage of neovascularization through the metabolic adaptation of the Warburg effect. Aligned with the mission of the National Eye Institute to prevent diabetes-related blindness, this project holds great promise in providing a new strategy, through the use of inhibitors of the Warburg effect, for preventing and/or treating diabetic retinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The widespread incidence of metabolic disease, including obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus, has emerged as a worldwide public health challenge. Accumulating evidence suggests that susceptibility to these disorders is increased in people who disrupt their daily sleep/wake fasting/feeding cycles, as is often the case for shift or night workers. To advance our understanding of the link between circadian rhythms and metabolism, I propose to pinpoint the molecular mechanisms underlying our recently characterized circadian clock-HIF interaction in skeletal muscle tissue, and to characterize the role of this interaction in muscle exercise physiology and diet- induced obesity-associated insulin resistance. The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying circadian timing of metabolism and to advance our knowledge of metabolic disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The relevance of this proposal is to mitigate the hazards posed by hazardous waste and other hazardous material releases to the environment and public by training the construction workforce to perform clean-up and emergency response operations in a safe and productive manner. A well trained construction workforce enables EPA, DHS and other local, state and federal agencies to not only protect the workers themselves, but to also protect the environment and public from hazardous waste and materials, and to respond to disasters whether they are man-made or natural.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE BRCA mutations confer an over 70% lifetime risk for breast cancer and the approval of several poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitors have brought new hope for patients with homologous recombination repair deficient (HRD), including BRCA1/2-mutated breast, ovarian, prostate and pancreatic cancers. The combination of epigenetic modulators, such as DNA methyltransferase inhibitors, with PARP inhibitors may help the considerable number of patients who are or become refractory to these agents by exploiting the DNA vulnerability of BRCA and other HRD-mutated tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) are one of the most important hospital-associated, multidrug- resistant organisms affecting critically ill patients and are considered a major public health threat by the WHO and CDC. Treatment of VRE bloodstream infections poses immense therapeutic dilemmas in clinical settings due to the lack of reliable antibiotic options, making these infections untreatable in certain scenarios. Using a contemporary prospective cohort of patients with enterococcal bacteremia, this proposal seeks to provide a robust characterization of the clinical impact of VRE bloodstream infections, deliver epidemiological insights into the genomic characteristics of infecting isolates and develop innovative approaches to optimize the diagnosis and treatment of these organisms causing recalcitrant infections in vulnerable patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Central clocks within the brain regulate 24-h rhythmicity including the sleep-wake cycle. Although the intracellular molecular mechanisms by which these clocks operate are well characterized, little is known about how their neurons interact to generate coordinated and robust 24-h signals. In this proposal, we test the hypothesis that part of the essential mechanisms by which these neurons interact is a 24-h change in the structure of synaptic contacts between neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep is critical for health and quality of life; however, little is known about the prevalence or impact of non- obstructive sleep apnea (non-OSA) sleep disorders in people with stroke. The proposed study aims to characterize the proportion of people with stroke that have non-OSA sleep disorders and their impact on recovery of activities of daily living, functional mobility, and participation along the continuum of recovery in people with stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High blood pressure and blood pressure that does not decrease by at least 10% during sleep are both associated with cardiovascular disease and death. The overall objective of the proposed study is to determine specific sleep and circadian rhythm factors that contribute to high blood pressure during sleep. A better understanding of these factors will help us design specific interventions to lower blood pressure during sleep and reduce cardiovascular disease and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: DNA packaging into open euchromatin and more compacted heterochromatin is essential for normal development and this packaging is disrupted in disease. Our research aims to define mechanisms that control heterochromatic compaction during embryogenesis and to understand the requirements for this compaction in regulating early transcription. Understanding the mechanisms that drive heterochromatin establishment in normal development is a critical first step toward designing approaches to restore appropriate DNA packaging to diseased tissues, while defining requirements for heterochromatin in the early embryo will elucidate the relationship between genome organization and the emergence of gene expression programs that control development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Stability of intracranial aneurysms is affected by local hemodynamic flow stress, which can trigger growing and rupture, resulting in severe morbidity and high mortality. The goal of this project is to characterize the endothelial signaling pathways induced by abnormal flow stress in intracranial aneurysms, and cellular mechanisms which contributes to unstable wall remodeling at high risk for rupture. The knowledge gained in this project will be fundamental to the development of accurate and reliable prediction tools or drug treatments for unruptured intracranial aneurysms.

PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal seeks to determine if neuroepigenetic mechanisms are involved in the pathophysiology of obesity. The aims of this proposal will be addressed using a recently developed animal model of obesity and will combine molecular biology and behavioral techniques. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic-resistant microbial pathogens are a grave and urgent threat to public health. With rising rates of drug- resistant infections and a diminishing arsenal of new antibiotic treatments, there is pressing need for approaches to better understand, predict, and prevent the emergence of antibiotic resistance, particularly in the human gut microbiome, which is an important source of antibiotic resistances. We are developing an automated, high-throughput technology that can reproduce key features of the human gut ecosystem, and enable us to evolve antibiotic resistance in pathogenic bacteria directly in the laboratory to understand how resistance emerges.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Ending Veteran homelessness remains a major federal priority. The US Department of Housing and Urban Development-Veterans Affairs Supportive Housing (HUD-VASH) program is the largest supported housing program for homeless Veterans. Before COVID-19, HUD-VASH case management was provided in-person. During the pandemic, case management shifted to virtual care. The pandemic provides an opportunity for the first time to examine changes, both positive and negative, associated with virtual care in the HUD-VASH program nationally. A mixed methods design will be used to: 1) Determine the effect of HUD-VASH’s shift to virtual care during the COVID-19 pandemic on case management services; 2) Evaluate the effect of HUD- VASH’s shift to virtual care during the pandemic on Veteran’s health care utilization and continuity of care; and 3) Examine Veteran and provider experiences with virtual case management in HUD-VASH. The results will inform the future use of virtual care in HUD-VASH and help prepare for the next public health emergency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  A key component of success for most viruses is the antagonisim of the production of interferons, potent signaling proteins that drive the induction of an antiviral state. Critically, viruses must maintain this antagonism throughout all members of the the population, as detection of any single viral particle and subsequent interferon production endangers them all. This proposal seeks to understand how this difficult challenge is achieved by influenza A virus in the face of highly promiscuous replication machinery, in the hopes that such an understanding may provide insight into novel therapeutic targets as well as an improved understanding of viral evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer’s disease and related tauopathies, are a major therapeutic challenge. Gene therapy shows great promise for treating neurological disorders; however, non- invasive, and brain-specific gene delivery remains a challenge. Our study seeks to optimize the application of combining transcranial focused ultrasound with intrathecal delivery of AAV vectors to treat the adult brain overall more effectively as well as to target disease-critical regions, determine mechanisms for this action, and validate this method for the treatment of tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative The mosquito disease vector, Aedes aegypti, is troubling because it spreads viruses that cause diseases such as dengue, yellow fever, and Zika, which infect >100,000,000 people/year. The identification of opsins as the first bitter taste receptor in mosquitoes offers the potential for identifying receptor antagonists to improve the efficacy of attractive toxic sugar baits, and reduce populations of insect disease vectors, and human disease. In addition, identifying mammalian opsins as the first receptor for the bitter compound, naringin, which is a common bitter ingredient in grapefruit and other fruit, provides the possibility of isolating antagonists for this receptor, to improve the palatability of many nutritious fruit that promote human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Michael A. Webster  PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular and Molecular Imaging Core Modern neuroscience research requires access to newly emerging technologies and instruments that are often difficult and impractical to support in individual laboratories. Building on its successful operation and support of outstanding investigators at the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR), the COBRE Cellular and Molecular Imaging (CMI) core facility seeks continued funding to transition to a sustainable core to provide support to COBRE faculty investigators and others with an emphasis in gaining fundamental knowledge about the basic function, development and disorders of the nervous system. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging of the vascular endothelial cells is a key event in the decline in organ function and frailty. This proposal will examine how lipid mediators that protect blood vessels become dysfunction in old age, and this knowledge will be used to develop new ways to achieve healthy blood vessels in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In order to make major advancements in our treatment and understanding of developmental epileptic encephalopathies we need novel model systems that faithfully recapitulate human disease pathophysiology. By virtue of being human cell derived and having a complex multi-layered 3D architecture, human brain organoids are distinct from models traditionally utilized in biomedical research, and have the potential to make an immediate impact on disease treatment. In the following proposal we will use disease-to-dish induced pluripotent stem cells from 3 patients with epilepsy associated SCN8A gene variants, neural network modeling, and the latest brain organoid generation and fusion techniques to gain novel insights into how this gain of function sodium channel mutation alters neural network formation and function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Mutations in the SHANK3 gene are a well-established risk factor for ASD. This proposal aims to delineate how SHANK3 deficiency causes cellular and molecular malfunctions that underlie abnormal neural circuitry and social and reward behaviors using two novel mouse models. These studies may lead to identifying novel therapeutic targets for treating social and reward deficits in ASD and other neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at substantially increased risk for long-term difficulties into adulthood, including academic underachievement, substance abuse, and criminal behavior. In our effort to improve these outcomes, we have worked on identifying highly-reliable motor measures that could be used to help better guide ADHD treatment, leading to the discovery of two brain-based measures that are abnormal in children with ADHD and, importantly, also predict the severity of ADHD behaviors. We aim to determine whether these two measures, performed with brief and safe Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS), are reliable and meaningful enough to be used to help improve precision of individually-targeted and effective ADHD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic gastroparesis is a significant complication of diabetes associated with symptoms of uncontrolled nausea, vomiting, sensation of feeling full quickly after eating, becoming full rapidly, abdominal pain, and bloating. There are limited, effective treatments for this condition, which is related to disruption of the brain-gut axis. This proposal aims to evaluate a novel treatment using repetitive magnetic stimulation targeting the spinal nerves in the thoracic region, ThorS-MagNT, as a potential treatment for diabetic gastroparesis in a randomized controlled trial (TNM-DGp Trial) and understand how it works.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study represents an important step in understanding why offspring of depressed mothers are at increased risk for depression themselves and will help to clarify the development of a key risk factor, attentional biases for facial displays of sadness, and its role as a mechanism of risk for the intergenerational transmission of depression. These results could help provide important information not only about where to intervene but when to intervene with offspring of depressed mothers. As such, the results could pave the way for more focused interventions for at-risk youth.
